DOC.HEAD: Rotary Launches Environmental Campaign
DOC.TEXT: The Rotary clubs launched a project Friday to encourage members to help clean up the Earth, a sure sign that even the ``sensible middle'' has gone Green, a federal official said. ``These people are not environmental radicals,'' said Richard J. Smith, a special negotiator on environmental affairs for the State Department, after addressing about 350 members of the Evanston, Ill.-based Rotary International. ``These are a very solid, center group ... who are tremendously influential (and) are beginning to think carefully about the environment,'' he said. Rotary International claims some 1.1 million members in 25,000 Rotary clubs worldwide. The civic group traditionally has confined itself to service projects such as the eradication of polio. In tackling the environment, Rotary turns itself to what some may consider a more political arena. But the group's world president, Paulo Costa, said the demand for an improved environment is too urgent to ignore. ``The rush for development has pushed our ecosystem to the breaking point,'' the Brazilian told the group. ``We have to change our habits.'' People at the conference planned workshops to develop specific strategies for improving the environment through their clubs. Costa urged members to begin by educating themselves of the problems in their own backyards. ``Education is the true, real key,'' said Costa, who said the threat to the rain forest in his nation first prompted him to consider the new Rotary project. ``I see Rotary as an umbrella organization, a clearing house of information,'' he said. Rotary members were encouraged to start environmental resource centers, address ecology issues in their own communities, and use environmentally sound practices in their everyday lives. They were also issued a list of ``101 ways you can help `Preserve Planet Earth.''' Among the tips: sweep rather than hose down sidewalks; clean air conditioner filters monthly; and fix broken things rather than junking them. ``You represent the sensible middle _ and that's what we have to engage if the job's to be done,'' Smith told the group.

DOC.HEAD: Minister Closes Italian Roads To Trucks From Austria
DOC.TEXT: A ``war of trucks'' between Italy and Austria has escalated with Italy's transportation minister closing Italian borders and roads today to most commercial trucks from Austria. Transportation Minister Carlo Bernini's move came after Italian truck drivers claimed they were discriminated against by Austrian authorities, who limited the number of transit passes to reduce pollution along the roads and protect the local environent. In a communique, the Italian Transportation Ministry announced the suspension of the authorization for the crossing of trucks through the border points at Brenner, Tarvisio, Prato Drava and Resia pass. The ministry said the ban did not apply to trucks transporting perishable goods.

DOC.HEAD: Greek Police Report 35 Albanian Asylum-Seekers Cross Border
DOC.TEXT: Thirty-five Albanians, most of them ethnic Greeks, have fled across the tightly guarded border and requested political asylum in Greece, the Athens News Agency said. The semi-official news agency reported Friday the Albanians crossed into northern Greece in several groups late Thursday and early Friday. Greek officials estimate that more than 250,000 ethnic Greeks live in Albania, which has a total population of about 3.2 million. In July, more than 4,000 Albanians were allowed to leave their orthodox Communist homeland after seeking refuge in embassies in the capital, Tirana. Albanian authorities recently began building a wall around the embassies. A U.S. congressional group that recently visited Tirana said Thursday that Albania still holds a large number of political prisoners, limits religious practice and restricts minority rights.

DOC.HEAD: First Soviet Arrested For Insulting President
DOC.TEXT: An unemployed man who displayed a defaced portrait of Mikhail S. Gorbachev has become the first person arrested on charges of insulting the Soviet president, a newspaper reported. Gennady Smirnov strolled through Moscow on July 29 carrying the portrait, the newspaper Vechernaya Moskva reported Friday. According to law enforcement officials, Smirnov had penned insulting and slanderous words and drawings on it. The 40-year-old man could face a $4,800 fine or a two-year prison camp term. Smirnov is undergoing a medical examination to determine his mental condition, Vechernaya Moskva reported. The Soviet legislature passed the law on slandering the president in May after a May Day demonstration in which protesters shouted insults at Gorbachev and other leaders in Red Square.

DOC.HEAD: Monkey Business in the Urban Jungle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The city's wildest tourists are up from South America. They've enjoyed the cuisine and spent their nights swinging around town. They also have razor-sharp teeth, and can carry parasites and viruses. They are 25 recently liberated squirrel monkeys, and they've turned a quiet Queens neighborhood into a wild kingdom since they were stolen from a local business and turned loose three weeks ago. ``It's like vacationing in a faraway land,'' said Constance Quinn. ``You look out the window and there's a monkey hanging on the wash line or swinging in the trees.'' The monkey business began when the animals were swiped from South America Unlimited, which imports the primates and sells them to research laboratories. The thieves' apparent plans to peddle the monkeys to pet stores fell through, and they released them, police said. Ever since, it's been monkeys in the middle of everything. They pop up in back yards, dangle from telephone wires, lead local kids on wild chimp chases. One found a new home in Mrs. Quinn's garage. ``I walked out there, and the monkey was just sitting on the car,'' Mrs. Quinn said of her Monday monkey meeting. ``Then it started flying all over. It was just hysterical.'' Her encounter with the monkey has made Mrs. Quinn somewhat of a celebrity. In addition to calls from reporters, she made an appearance Friday morning on a radio station. ``What part of Queens do you live in? The Amazon section?'' the host asked her. Actually, the Glendale section, which along with neighboring Ridgewood is where the visitors are hanging out. The monkey in Mrs. Quinn's place escaped despite the best efforts of a policeman and an ASPCA worker; since then, two of the small brownish beasts have been recovered. One was put to sleep because of the potential health risk; the other is safe and sound in an undisclosed location, said Kathi Travers, director of the ASPCA animal port at Kennedy International Airport. The cute little critters are as dangerous as they are adorable, Travers warned; they will bite if confronted, and they can carry dozens of dangerous diseases, including potentially fatal Hepatitis B. But after spending their time in cages since leaving South America, the beasts are now busy living it up during their summer in the urban jungle. ``We're worried, but these monkeys are having a party,'' said Travers. Foodwise, they've discovered a smorgasbord: plenty of greenery, trees and flowers to munch on, along with the occasional spider or other insect. One homeowner already reported losing his backyard grape harvest to the ravenous critters. But the good times will soon end, Travers warned. The monkeys thrive in the heat, but a New York winter would mean their demise: ``Forget it. They'd have no shot,'' she said. ``They are cute and adorable, but they don't belong in the trees of New York,'' said Travers. ``They belong in the trees of South America.''

DOC.HEAD: Women Launch Support Group For Loved Ones Left Behind
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The telephone calls from worried relatives and friends of U.S. military personnel in the Persian Gulf start streaming into Pat Enninga's kitchen about 5:30 a.m. ``People are just crying,'' said Enninga, an organizer of a burgeoning support group known as S.O.C.'M. _ Support Our Country's Military. In less than two weeks, S.O.C.'M.'s three main organizers have comforted thousands of callers from around the country and spawned several Twin Cities chapters and a letter-writing campaign to American soldiers. The activity has been an outlet for people at a loss for companionship and information since Operation Desert Shield disrupted their lives. It also has rekindled some patriotism, although the group insists it is not political. ``All we are trying to project is love,'' said Enninga, whose 21-year-old son, Shayne Hawkins, is with the Army's 82nd Airborne division. ``As long as they are there and they have to be there, we want to support them and look out for each other.'' Yvonne Minor, another S.O.C.'M. organizer, said the group would like to send American flags to the families of active duty soldiers who request one. ``Morale is important to us,'' said Minor, whose 20-year-old son, Shane, shipped out Aug. 6, about two weeks after he was married. ``I wanted patriotism back in this country. I didn't want it like Korea or the Vietnam war.'' Minor, 45, of Savage, said she isn't alone. Many S.O.C.'M. callers are volunteering to write letters to soldiers whom they don't know and a magazine publisher is considering shipping unused magazines to the troops, Minor said. She declined to identify the publisher. ``Kids are sending little postcards and pictures of Ninja Turtles,'' she said. But the group's primary mission has been to console families who have been left with very little information about their loved ones overseas. ``A lot of what we're doing is talking,'' Enninga said. ``We've got people calling from Texas, New Jersey, South Dakota, Ohio, California. We just try to get together and cry on each others' shoulders or hold each other up.'' She said the biggest fears surround the possible use of chemical weapons by Iraq, but many callers have unique troubles. Enninga remembered a call from a young woman with 2-year-old twins who planned to marry an American soldier a week before he was summoned to the Persian Gulf. ``All of a sudden he's gone and she doesn't know where he is,'' said Enninga, 40, of Brooklyn Center. ``She sounded so young. She's just totally devastated.'' S.O.C.'M. makes frequent use of the Red Cross and officers in each branch of the military to answer questions, many of which have to do with mailing, Enninga said. A meeting Monday in the Twin Cities also will feature a chaplain and a veteran of the war in Vietnam, she said. Enninga and Minor helped start S.O.C.'M. after the idea of a support group was aired on Twin Cities television by Betty Walters, 52, of Crystal. Walters has a son and grandson in active military units and most of her family lives in South Dakota. Enninga said she has heard of similar support groups at U.S. military bases. Attendance at the first two S.O.C.'M. meetings totaled about 100, but the group doesn't yet have membership scrolls and has not logged the number of calls it has received. Minor estimates she handles about 100 calls a day, but Enninga says she has no idea how many calls she has received. The calls begin about 5:30 a.m. and last until about 10 p.m., she said ``If you're done with a call, you don't even bother to hang up,'' Enninga said. ``You just press the button once on the receiver and take the next call.''

DOC.HEAD: Gatorade Plant Producing on Overtime For Soldiers in Mideast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: It started out as just another hot, lazy summer and workers at the Quaker Oats plant figured the Gatorade they were making was for weekend warriors on tennis courts and softball diamonds. Now that it's quenching the thirst of full-time soldiers in the Middle East, work doesn't seem so dull anymore. Thousands of gallons of the drink produced at the Newport plant are bound for the Persian Gulf, and more is on the way. ``This started about two weeks ago when we received a rush order for two truck loads of 12-ounce Gatorade,'' plant manager Bill Wolford said Friday. Through some overtime effort, the plant got the order of about 500,000 quart bottles completed in time for delivery to Camp LeJeune, N.C., and an airlift to the Middle East. Since then, the plant has delivered about 23,000 cases of the beverage to Charleston, S.C., where it was loaded onto container ships headed to Saudi Arabia. The plant currently is working on another order of 20,000 cases of liquid Gatorade for the military and it's anticipating potentially larger orders for the drink in powdered form. In Newport, a town of 8,000, there's a sense of mission at the 600-employee Quaker Oats plant. ``The folks here at the plant are very much aware of where this product is going and we are keeping them abreast,'' Wolford said. ``We have several employees in the plant that have children in the armed service and also in the reserves,'' general supervisor Thom Pasinger said. ``It's a small town, so everybody knows where the shipments are going. The guys in the warehouse are proud, we've got a lot of veterans,'' said warehouse manager Mel Wadlinger said. Gatorade was developed for athletes in the 1960s to prevent dehydration and heat illnesses. It didn't get its first taste of military action until recently in Panama. The military's demand isn't expected to cause any less of the product for the domestic market, said Peter Vitulli, president of Quaker's grocery specialities division, at corporate headquarters in Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Cutbacks Threaten Cradle of Liberty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A crack in an old bell is nothing compared with new maintenance problems at Independence National Historical Park, which may start closing buildings as early as October because of budget cuts. In fact, the once-troublesome, now-revered crack in the Liberty Bell is one of the few sights that may remain open to the public if the park is forced to get by on the funds they now expect. ``We have literally reached the point where we can't maintain the park,'' Bernie Goodman, the park's acting superintendent, said Friday. Independence Hall is developing a leaky roof, original wood is rotting and everything from light poles to brick and flagstone walkways are in disrepair. Signs at the far end of the three-block mall north of Independence Mall near downtown Philadelphia warn: ``Danger: Uneven walking surface. Enter at your own risk.'' Sand has been thrown over some of the brick surface, rippled by roots from trees that shaded what used to be a popular picnic area. Plastic bags cover light poles once topped by globes. None of the 11 fountains works. Park officials said there are two problems: insufficient funds to make regular repairs, and not enough to pay the staff needed to keep buildings open. Officials said they need about $8.5 million in the budget year beginning Oct. 1 to maintain what they did this year for $7.9 million _ which included some temporary building closings. But they expect to be about $483,000 short. In addition, park officials say they need a bigger chunk of money from a maintenance fund for parks in the region. Only $60,000 of the requested $175,000 for re-roofing Independence Hall came from the fund this year, so only a fourth of the job was done. Pieces of metal have been shoved under some of the red cedar shingles to keep out water until workers can do more. Money shortages could cause the closing of all but Independence Hall, the Liberty Bell Pavilion and the Visitor Center in October, Goodman said. Potential targets: Congress Hall, where George Washington was inaugurated for a second term; Old City Hall, former home of the Supreme Court; and Franklin Court, where steel ghost structures outline the site of Benjamin Franklin's home and print shop. Goodman said those buildings attract about 1.3 million people a year. The situation has Goodman and visitor services director Kathy Dilonardo showing off the weak points of a park they'd rather boast about. On Friday, their guests included Rep. Robert Borski, D-Pa. ``It's a very strange position to be in because we all have a great deal of pride and keep a great deal of pride in how well we operated the park in the past,'' Goodman said. Borski and five other Philadelphia-area congressmen this week appealed for help for the park in a letter to the regional director of the Interior Department, James W. Coleman Jr., whose office is a short walk from Independence Hall. Like other national historic parks across the country, the Philadelphia park is federally funded via the National Parks Service, which is part of the Interior Department. Borski said he expects Congress to respond when the problems are publicized. ``The whole Congress was here just a few years ago to celebrate the bicentennial of the Constitution,'' Borski said. ``All Americans as well as all congressmen will want to see this place maintained properly.''

DOC.HEAD: Hard-Charging Air Force General Heads Saudi Operation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: RIYADH, Saudia Arabia (AP)_ The biggest U.S. military operation since the Vietnam War is run out of a cramped room in a downtown office building by a gregarious general called in from South Carolina. ``Just what you thought for the commanding general, right?'' Lt. Gen. Charles A. Horner said with a laugh as he pointed around quarters about 12-by-20 feet. The sound of the Moslem call to prayer, which is piped into the modern building, reverberates through the room. Horner, 53, head of U.S. Central Command Air Forces at Shaw Air Force Base in Sumter, S.C., is a down-home fellow whose life has been running at fast-forward since he was tapped to oversee Operation Desert Shield. Horner hasn't ventured into the field yet, but he's hoping that will change soon when Gen. Norman Schwazkopf arrives to assume the helm. Schwazkopf is head of the central command, which is responsible for U.S. forces from Pakistan to Kenya and is headquartered at MacDill Air Force Base in Tampa, Fla. In desert boots and regulation camouflage work pants and shirt, Horner, a beefy, Davenport, Iowa, native, is indistinguishable from his troops _ except for his authoritative tone, the three stars pinned to his chest and a $3 watch with Arabic numerals. ``A gift from a mujahedeen,'' explains Horner, referring to the fierce anti-communist rebels in Afghanistan. Horner arrived even before President Bush announced Aug. 8 that U.S. forces would be deployed in Saudi Arabia. He accompanied Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to plot the defense of the oil-rich nation with King Fahd four days after Iraq invaded neighboring Kuwait Aug. 2. When Cheney returned to the United States, Horner stayed behind to start the wheels in motion for the arrival of more than 40,000 troops and 500,000 tons of materiel. ``Secretary Cheney looked at me and said, `Good Luck, Chuck,' Horner recalled in an interview. ``I swallowed hard.'' Since then it's been adreneline-charged, 15-to-18 hour days as the decorated fighter pilot manages the most important assignment of his career. His command post is in the capital about 200 miles from Dhahran, the gulf city where most of the U.S. troops and materiel are arriving. Logistics _ and dealing with Saudi officials _ are major components of the job. Desert Shield is a cooperative venture with the Saudis; the forces operate essentially as a joint command. U.S. military and diplomatic officials say the movement of weapons, personnel and equipment has gone off without major glitches. With more than 4,500 hours of flying time, including 41 combat missions over North Vietnam, Horner is itching to get into the cockpit of an F-15. ``I love to fly,'' he said. Horner has known and worked with the American-trained top Saudi air force generals for years. He finds the Saudis bright, energetic, hard-working _ and different. ``The toughest thing is you have to accommodate to their customs,'' he said. They don't like to say ``no'' and would rather postpone a decision than risk a confrontation, he says. ``You're charging and trying to get things done,'' while the Saudis have a more indirect manner, he said. ``He's a gruff, take-charge kind of guy who is not taken to flowery speech,'' said a Pentagon spokesman. ``He is not a timid politician.'' The hours are also a switch. Saudis take time off during the heat of the day and often work until 1 a.m., with vital issues raised late in the evening. Despite the challenges, Horner said even generals get a little homesick. He misses his family. Horner's daughter is entering college, and she wrote him several letters telling of her anxiety about the choice of which sorority to pledge. Horner concludes an interview when his driver Col. Samir Turki, whom Horner calls Sammy, summons him for a meeting. ``Tell the people we are in good hands,'' Turki says.

DOC.HEAD: Nobel Laureate Elie Wiesel Prepares for Hate Conference
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: World leaders gather this weekend to discuss ways to counter hate, but the conference organizer, Nobel peace laureate Elie Wiesel, wishes he had called the seminar earlier. ``I wonder if the conference had been held six months ago, if it could have done something to avoid the problems we see now,'' Wiesel said Friday, referring specifically to the Persian Gulf crisis and unrest in South Africa. The Romanian-born author and human rights activist said the seminar, ``The Anatomy of Hate,'' which begins Sunday in Oslo, is expected to draw about 70 delegates from 30 countries. South African anti-apartheid activist Nelson Mandela, Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel, French President Francois Mitterrand and former President Jimmy Carter are scheduled to be key speakers during the four-day meeting. Wiesel and the Norwegian Nobel Peace Prize committee sent out a call last fall to statesmen, Nobel laureates, activists and thinkers to meet in this small Scandinavian city to discuss the problem of hate. At the time, Wiesel, a Nazi death camp survivor, said he feared that new freedoms won by East bloc nations would cause smoldering religious, ethnic and regional hatred to flare. He chose Oslo as the conference site because it is the home of the Peace Prize, which he won in 1986. ``Now in Europe the problem is hatred. Now in the Middle East the problem is hatred ... There is no issue so timely as the issue of hate,'' said the 61-year-old Boston University professor. Keynote speakers, including Mandela and Havel, will open discussions on racism and regional hatred in Europe, the Middle East and Africa in a search of ways to resolve conflicts through dialogue and democracy. ``The moment the Iraq crisis exploded, I expected people to cancel, but to our pleasure very few have,'' said Wiesel, a U.S. citizen. ``And when I read of the killings in South Africa I thought he (Mandela) was not coming. But he is coming anyway, and that is a good sign,'' Wiesel said. Hundreds of blacks have been killed in fighting between rival factions in South African townships recently. The violence prompted the government Friday to impose a state of emergency in black townships outside Johannesburg, giving police widespread powers to detain people and take action to stop the violence. One of those taking part in the hate conference is Chai Ling, a leader of last year's pro-democracy movement in Beijing. She was greeted with a standing ovation by Norwegian students she addressed Friday. Ling spoke of the violent June 4, 1989 military crackdown on the Chinese students and said: ``Tanks can crush student movements, but cannot crush love or respect between people.'' ``We still don't know what the meeting will do,'' Wiesel admitted. A joint declaration may be issued, possibly suggesting ways to counter hatred. Planners considered bringing together enemies in bitter conflicts, such as Irish Catholics and Protestants, but Wiesel said the idea was rejected. ``This is not a forum for those who hate.''

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Stings Dollar, Empties Tourist Pocketbooks
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Americans traveling in Europe this summer find the purchasing power of the already weak U.S. dollar sapped even further by the crisis in the Persian Gulf. From London to Athens, the dollar buys far less than it did a year ago. Once-cheap destinations, bargain basements no longer, are raising eyebrows and flattening pocketbooks. ``We sat in a sidewalk cafe yesterday and were shocked a small beer cost $8,'' said Christopher Kirk, 42, of Seattle, who was visiting Paris. ``Everybody's been asking us for $5 for a coffee and roll for breakfast.'' Poring over brochures at the Champs-Elysees tourist office, Kirk and traveling companion Janet Stanford ruled out a shopping spree for designer wear. Any fashions they take home will come from mid-priced department stores. They number among tens of thousands of Americans visiting Europe whose greenbacks have lost about 20 percent in value to benchmark European currencies since this time last year. The gulf situation has pushed the U.S. currency even lower. A dollar bought 5.38 francs Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait. On Friday, it fetched 5.21 francs. Things are tough even in Greece, a haven for budget holidaymakers. Mary Mandis of Fort Lee, N.J., couldn't understand ``why my dollars are buying less drachmas at the bank when I thought Greece was so cheap.'' A Paris-based financial analyst said the dollar is weak for many reasons: ``Slowdown in the U.S. economy, lower interest rates. More people interested in Euro currencies.'' The gulf situation added to the reasons for the slide. Higher oil prices resulting from Iraq's takeover of Kuwait renewed the threat of a U.S. recession, pushing the dollar down, the analyst said. The Deutschmark grew mighty in the last year as investors saw West Germany as the economic powerhouse of a bigger Europe, the analyst said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The dollar is at a historic low against the mark, dropping from about 1.75 marks to 1.54 in just two months. In Britain, the pound is nearing the benchmark $2 level. In Italy, the dollar has plunged to its lowest level against the lire since 1981. Just a few years ago, footsore Yanks saw Rome as crowded and smoggy but a bargain for a well-cut suit or big meal. Today only the crowds and smog remain. ``We learned the first night,'' said Missy Prowell of Huntington Beach, Calif., traveling with her husband, Court. ``We had a very nice dinner in a restaurant, but we had to pay 190,000 Italian lire (about $190),'' Mrs. Prowell said. ``That was outrageous. Now we share dishes and split desserts.'' Americans are also staying out of the clothing shops. ``I'd love to buy shoes,'' sighed Lydia Lavin, from Olean, N.Y. ``But I content myself with looking at them.'' The potential oil shortage has boosted gasoline prices in Europe as well as the United States. Touring English country lanes costs 5.8 cents more per liter of gasoline more than it did a month ago. ``We rented a car, and I thought gas prices were going up at home,'' said Richard Ralston. ``I filled up a small Ford for $46.'' Expatriate workers feel the pinch of the currency exchange rate, and so do those who depend on their salaries paid in dollars. Like Harry Spittler, who hawks cuckoo clocks and nutcrackers to an almost exclusively American clientele of GIs and tourists from his gift shop in Kaiserslauten, West Germany. ``We are very much affected by this. Our business has gone down almost 20 percent in the past month,'' Spittler said. ``Many Germans haven't realized the benefits they accrue from the GIs over here. But now they're starting to see.'' It's hard to tell if fewer Americans are visiting Europe. Most tourist ministries don't analyze statistics until September. But Hartmut Emmich of the Reisedienst der Wirtschaft travel office in Frankfurt feels that the low dollar hasn't changed travel plans for many Americans. ``They booked these trips months ago. They have a set price when they are booked and there haven't been many cancellations,'' Emmich said. ``But it will certainly affect bookings for next year.''

DOC.HEAD: Sheep Burned Alive, Veal Trucks Seized by Angry Farmers
DOC.TEXT: Farmers hurt by foreign competition stopped trucks carrying veal calves from Britain, two days after masked men burned alive more than 200 imported sheep. The incidents in western France signaled a worsening situation in a 2-month-old movement to keep out foreign animals that livestock herders say undercut domestic prices. The farmers in Caen captured two veal trucks Friday morning and drove them to the city hall before allowing the animals to be taken to slaughterhouses. The protest was relatively peaceful compared to the incident Wednesday at Thouars, in the Deux-Sevres region, where masked men stopped an English truck carrying 440 sheep. After threatening the driver and a passenger, the men doused the truck in gasoline and set it afire, killing 219 animals. Farmers' unions have demanded immediate relief from falling prices. But Agriculture Minister Henri Nallet said Thursday that the government does not have the millions of francs needed for an all-encompassing bailout.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Lebanon-Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of events in the holding of American kidnap victims in Lebanon:

_ The Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco abducted in Beirut. _ Jeremy Levin, Beirut chief for U.S. Cable News Network, kidnapped earlier in west Beirut, gains his freedom. He says he escaped; Islamic Jihad says it freed him. _ Terry Anderson, chief Mideast correspondent for The Associated Press, abducted on Beirut street. _ David P. Jacobsen, American director of American University Hospital, kidnapped. _ American Thomas Sutherland, acting agriculture dean at American University, kidnapped. _ American Presbyterian pastor Benjamin Weir freed after 16 months in captivity. _ CIA officer William Buckley, a hostage since March 16, 1984, killed after Israeli air raid on PLO headquarters in Tunisia.

_ American University librarian Peter Kilburn, an American, and two other hostages, British educators Leigh Douglas and Philip Padfield, found shot to death east of Beirut two days after U.S. air raids on Libya. _ Revolutionary Organization of Socialist Moslems says it has killed kidnapped British journalist Alec Collett in retaliation for British complicity in U.S. attack on Libya. _ Jenco freed. _ American educator Frank Herbert Reed kidnapped in west Beirut. _ American University accountant Joseph Cicippio abducted on west Beirut campus. _ American writer Edward Austin Tracy kidnapped in Beirut. _ Jacobsen is released in Beirut. _ First reports surface that the United States arranged arms shipments to Iran in exchange for hostage releases.

_ Anglican Church mediator Terry Waite kidnapped. _ Three Americans _ Jesse Jonathan Turner, Alann Steen and Robert Polhill _ and Indian Mithileshwar Singh, all faculty members of Beirut University College, kidnapped from the campus. _ American journalist Charles Glass kidnapped; turns up two months later and says he escaped. _ Kidnappers issue videotape of Anderson in which he appeals to President Reagan to win the hostages' release, saying, ``There is a limit for how long we can last.''

_ U.S. Marine Lt. Col. William R. Higgins, member of U.N. observer force in Lebanon, abducted. _ The last three French hostages in Lebanon are set free. They say a fourth French hostage, Michel Seurat, died in captivity. _ Indian professor Mithileshwar Singh is freed.

_ Lebanon's most influential Shiite Moslem cleric, Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, says the foreign hostages should be freed. _ Israeli commandos abduct Sheik Abdul Karim Obeid, a clerical leader of fundamentalist Shiite group Hezbollah, from his Lebanese home. Organization of the Oppressed on Earth kills Higgins and says it was reprisal for Obeid's kidnapping. _ Kidnappers release photo of Anderson, accompanying another demand for release of comrades jailed in Kuwait. _ U.S. releases $567 million in frozen Iranian assets. _ Two Swiss Red Cross workers abducted in Lebanon.

_ Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani says he believes the hostage issue ``is moving toward a solution.'' The Revolutionary Justice Organization, one of several groups holding hostages in Lebanon, said it did not intend to release its hostages. _ Polhill freed April 22 after 39 months in captivity and turned over to Syria. _ Reed freed April 30 after 43 months as a hostage and turned over to Syria. _ Swiss Red Cross worker Emmanuel Christen released Aug. 9. _ Another Swiss Red Cross worker, Elio Erriquez, released Aug. 13. He was kidnapped in October along with Christen. _ Irishman Brian Keenan released Aug. 24 after more than four years in captivity.

DOC.HEAD: List of Western Hostages of Lebanese Kidnappers
With PM-Lebanon-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of the six Americans and other non-Lebanese kidnap victims still missing in Lebanon: 1. Terry A. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, kidnapped March 16, 1985. 2. Thomas Sutherland, 59, acting dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut, abducted June 9, 1985. 3. Joseph James Cicippio, 59, acting comptroller at the American University in Beirut, kidnapped Sept. 12, 1986. 4. Edward Austin Tracy, 59, west Beirut resident.Revolutionary Justice Organization claimed on Oct. 21, 1986, to have abducted him. 5. Alann Steen, 51, a communications instructor at Beirut University College, kidnapped Jan. 24, 1987. 6. Jesse Jonathan Turner, 43, professor of mathematics and computer science at Beirut University College, kidnapped Jan. 24, 1987. OTHERS: 1. Terry Waite, 51, British envoy of the Anglican Church, disappeared Jan. 20, 1987. 2. Alec Collett, 68, British journalist, kidnapped March 25, 1985. 3. John McCarthy, 33, British television journalist, kidnapped April 17, 1986. 4. Alberto Molinari, 70, Italian businessman who lived in Beirut, kidnapped Sept. 11, 1985. 5. Jack Mann, 76, British missing in west Beirut since May 12, 1989. 6-7. Heinrich Struebig, 49, and Thomas Kemptner, 28, West German relief workers, kidnapped May 16, 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Reservists Get The Call
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS reports from California, Oklahoma, Oregon, North Dakota; South Dakota call up ordered
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: The mobilization of military reserve and National Guard units ordered by the Bush administration is expected to reach almost 50,000 by October. Here is a partial list of the units called up or placed on alert by President Bush's order. Many of the units were only partial mobilized; numbers are given where available.

DOC.HEAD: Blanchard Boots Veteran Griffiths Off Ticket
Retransmitting with `p' category code for political desks.
DOC.TEXT: Lt. Gov. Martha Griffiths, who served in Congress 20 years and was a force behind passage of the Equal Rights Amendment, was dropped Friday from the 1990 gubernatorial ticket by Gov. James Blanchard. Blanchard praised Griffiths as ``the premier stateswoman'' and ``a wonderful friend'' but said he asked her to step aside because he no longer considers her ready to assume the governor's post at a moment's notice. ``I've always tried to do what's right for the people of Michigan,'' Blanchard told a news conference. He did not give a reason for his decision and said a search was on for a new running mate for the fall campaign against John Engler, the Republican Senate majority leader. Griffiths was giving a speech in Ann Arbor at the University of Michigan and was unavailable for comment, her office said. Griffiths, 78, ran with Blanchard in his successful campaigns of 1982 and 1986. Amid speculation she would not run again, Griffiths surprised her boss on May 10 when she said she was ready for a third term. As recently as Aug. 7, Blanchard told reporters, ``It's been a great team, a successful team. I'd hate to break it up.'' Griffiths served in the Michigan House from 1949 to 1952. Two years later she entered Congress from Michigan's 17th District, and she held the seat until her resignation in 1975. Her shining moment came when she got the 218 signatures from House members needed to pull the Equal Rights Amendment out of committee and onto the floor, clearing the way for its eventual approval in 1972. The amendment eventually fell three states short of the 38 needed to ratify it in order to add it to the U.S. Constitution. A spokesman for Engler's campaign said the appearance that Blanchard had dumped her off the ticket was potentially damaging. ``Democrats would probably have a stronger ticket if Martha Griffiths booted Jim Blanchard off instead of the other way around,'' said the spokesman, John Truscott. Blanchard declined to speculate on the political fall-out of the move. ``If the decision that I have made were only based on how to win the election, there would be no question of who I would choose to share the ticket _ Lieutenant Governor Martha Griffiths,'' he said in a prepared statement. The governor said he met with Griffiths last week to discuss the matter, and advised her of his decision before he made the announcement. The governor credited Griffiths with helping him win his first gubernatorial campaign in 1982 and said the decision to remove her from the ticket was ``one of the most personally trying and difficult decisions I have ever had to make.'' Griffiths became Michigan's first elected lieutenant governor when she helped Blanchard beat Republican Richard Headlee. A native of Pierce City, Mo., Griffiths graduated from the University of Missouri and the University of Michigan law school.

DOC.HEAD: Resident of House Damaged by Chemical Blast Upset by Prosecution Threat
DOC.TEXT: The city threatened to prosecute a man because his house failed to meet building-code regulations after being damaged last month by an explosion at a chemical plant. The July 19 explosion at a BASF Corp. plant rocked George Heard's house across the street, said Harvey Wilbekin, the city's director of buildings and inspection. Of 271 buildings that were inspected, only Heard's house was condemned, Wilbekin said. His department recently sent Heard a letter saying that if he failed to bring the house up to minimum standards under building-code regulations, he risked prosecution for a first-degree misdemeanor. That carries a maximum penalty of six months in jail and a $1,000 fine. ``It's the grossest kind of insensitivity. It is the worst aspect of bureaucratic response,'' Heard's lawyer, David Altman, said Friday. ``It is not at all appropriate for a government to respond like this to a citizen who suffered from a disaster that was not his fault. ``They treated Mr. Heard like a guy who let his house go to disrepair, rather than a guy whose house was destroyed by an explosion,'' Altman said. Wilbekin apologized after learning about the letter. ``The reason it was done was to alert the owner that he had a serious condition,'' Wilbekin said. ``We do not intend to be following up with any prosecution. We admit that it was not handled as delicately as it should have been.'' Investigators said the explosion, which killed two people, occurred when a cloud of cleaning vapor solvent ignited at a reactor in which chemicals are mixed and heated. The plant remains closed. In a lawsuit filed against BASF earlier this week in Hamilton County Common Pleas Court, Altman demanded that all residents whose houses were damaged be reimbursed for all repair and temporary relocation expenses. The company declined immediate comment on the lawsuit. Spokesman Charles Coe said BASF has received about 1,500 reimbursement claims and has settled about half of them, but did not reveal how much has been paid out.

DOC.HEAD: Chilean Hospital Retains Newborn As Guarantee For Payment
DOC.TEXT: The Chilean Supreme Court has forced a private clinic to release a newborn baby it held 11 days as collateral for a $1,000 unpaid medical bill. The Santiago daily La Tercera said the baby was handed to his parents, Fernando Onetto and Elena Culell, on Wednesday after the Supreme Court ruling. The Providencia Clinic, where the incident occurred, refused to comment. The mother said she was initially told the bill would be $430, according to the paper on Thursday. Eventually, however, she was charged $1,000 and couldn't come up with the money immediately. ``The owner of the clinc had ordered that the baby should not be handed to me until the entire bill was paid,'' she told La Tercera. The court ruling ordered the baby's release but the final result of the pay dispute was not reported.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Recommends Small Pay Raise for Federal Employees
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is recommending a 3.5 percent pay raise on Jan. 1 for federal employees. That is only a small fraction of the 22 percent to 40 percent increases that Bush's pay advisers recommended to keep pace with salaries in the private sector. But in a letter Friday to leaders of Congress sent from his vacation home, Bush said, ``Pay raises of this magnitude are clearly unacceptable.'' Bush's plan would boost the top salaries among senior government executives to $108,300. The lowest-paid job on the civil service pay rung would pay $10,951 a year. The highest salary on grade 18 of the civil service scale would be $96,756. Members of the president's Senior Executive Service would get salaries ranging from $87,000 to $108,300. The pay scale for the foreign service would range up to $79,675. The White House also released a separate scale for health officials in the Department of Veterans Affairs, with a top scale of $104,085 for the deputy chief medical director.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Dealt Sharp Blow by Persian Gulf Crisis
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: OPEC is reeling from the sharp blow delivered by the Persian Gulf crisis, which has badly crippled the cartel's ability to exert control over oil pricing and production. ``For the moment, it's an irrelevant organization,'' said Bryan Jacoboski, a vice president at Paine Webber brokerage in New York. ``Everything occurring in the oil markets is outside of OPEC's influence.'' The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was thrown into one of its worst crises when the unthinkable happened: one of its members invaded and annexed another in a dispute over oil, land and money. Years of effort to polish the group's image as a reliable business organization appear to have ended in failure. ``At this point, the organization has very little credibility,'' said Peter Bogin, associate director for oil markets at Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Paris. ``The future of the crisis will determine the future of OPEC.'' Since Iraq seized Kuwait on Aug. 2, OPEC has chosen, despite pleas from Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, not to hold an emergency meeting to discuss the turbulent situation in the oil markets. At least seven of the 13 member nations have agreed to talk informally in Vienna on Sunday, but Saudi Arabia's influential oil minister, Hisham Nazer, may not show up. Iraq and Kuwait also were expected to stay away. Without going into a formal session, there is little the ministers can do to try to calm the jittery markets. Crude prices, lifted by fears of military escalation in the gulf and cutbacks in oil supplies, have spiraled above $30 a barrel, a level untouched since the mid-1980s. ``OPEC is not really a feature in the fundamentals of this (price) move,'' said Peter Gignoux, director of the international energy department at Shearson Lehman Hutton in London. Last month, the cartel agreed to restrain production at 22.5 million barrels a day in the last half of the year in an effort to drive prices up to a new target of $21 a barrel. The benchmark was reached _ and exceeded _ almost immediately. An international embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil has meant a loss of about 4 million barrels of crude a day to the world markets. Saudi Arabia, which holds about a quarter of the world's oil reserves, has said it intends to increase crude pumping by as much as 2 million barrels a day, with or without OPEC's blessing. But analysts say the kingdom would like the cartel's nod to go over its newly set supply quota of 5.4 million barrels a day. ``It would be better for Saudi Arabia and the organization as a whole to have it done under the umbrella of OPEC rather than as a unilateral action,'' said Bahman Karbassioun, an oil consultant in Vienna. ``No one likes unilateral action.'' Some see the organization divided into two camps _ those who want much higher prices and those who don't. ``There's a terrific battle between the OPEC `hawks' and `doves','' said Gignoux. Iran, considered a hawk on prices, has said there is enough oil in storage in the industrialized world to make up for the loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude. Some of the smaller members, with less capacity to produce oil, also may be delighted by the surge in prices, bringing a windfall to their governments' coffers. Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates have been considered among the price doves or moderates, who worry about the effects of sharp price swings on the world economy. Despite the cartel's hesitation to act over the Iraqi invasion, analysts say it would be foolish to write its obituary. ``Calling OPEC dead is a little bit premature,'' said Bogin. ``They've come back from a lot.'' The cartel has weathered other crises in just the past decade. The 1979 revolution in Iran, a major oil-producing nation, was marked by a sharp drop in crude production. World oil prices soared, almost hitting the $40 mark and sending the world economy into a tailspin. In the mid-1980s, a production free-for-all sent oil prices crashing, and the organization was near collapse. Throughout most of the 1980s, Iran and Iraq were at war, which ended in a cease-fire two years ago. Referring to the present crisis, Bogin said that if the Iraqi leadership is replaced by a more moderate one friendly to the West, ``OPEC again can play a role in the oil world.'' But if Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's military might prevails in the high-stakes contest, he said, ``OPEC will be spelled I-r-a-q.''

DOC.HEAD: After-Tax Corporate Profits Down
DOC.TEXT: The newest report on corporate America's performance gives further evidence of an overall weak economy, analysts say. The assessment came Friday after the Commerce Department reported that corporate profits in the second quarter of this year dropped 0.2 percent from a year ago. The quarter began in April and ended in June. The decline is the first since a 5.9 percent drop in after-tax profits in 1989's third quarter, July-September, the Commerce Department reported. Profits rose 1.7 percent in the final quarter of 1989, followed by a 0.5 percent increase in the first quarter of this year. The government also reported Friday that the gross national product for the second quarter expanded at a lackluster rate of just 1.2 percent. Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co., said the profit picture is likely to worsen in coming months, especially if the country enters a recession. While profits normally drop between 15 percent and 20 percent in the typical recession, Sinai said he was looking for only about a 5 percent drop in profits next year because he expects that any downturn will be a mild one. Even analysts who are not yet forecasting a recession are looking for corporate profits to remain soft in coming quarters. ``Although oil companies are likely to have bigger profits in the second half of the year because of higher oil prices, that will be offset by a weaker showing in other sectors,'' said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch. After-tax profits totaled $166.7 billion at an annual rate in the second quarter. The decline from the first quarter reflected in part weak earnings in the transportation and public utilities sectors. Among the details of the profits report: _Before-tax profits, which totaled $297.6 billion at an annual rate in the second quarter, were up a slight 0.2 percent from the first quarter. Before-tax profits had risen 2.4 percent in the first quarter. _Corporate profits, after adjusting for depreciation and inventories, climbed 3.3 percent in the second quarter to an annual level of $306.5 billion. They had been up 2 percent in the first quarter. _Corporate cash flows, a measurement intended to show the funds corporations have for investment, rose 2.3 percent in the second quarter to an annual rate of $402.3 billion, after falling 0.7 percent in the first quarter. Dividend payments to stockholders increased 2.1 percent to an annual rate of $133 billion in the second quarter after increasing 2 percent in the first quarter.

DOC.HEAD: Performance Artists Lose Appeal To NEA
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for four ``performance artists'' who were denied federal grants say they will take the National Endowment for the Arts to court for making what they call a political decision that violates the First Amendment. The lawyers from the Center for Constitutional Rights said a federal court case is the only option because the NEA on Friday rejected an appeal of its decision in June to turn down the grant applications. ``As in its initial denial letters, the NEA gives no substantive reasons for the denials,'' the non-profit center said in a statement from its New York headquarters. The four performers in question are Karen Finley and Holly Hughes of New York, and Tim Miller and John Fleck of Los Angeles. Their solo stage acts consist of songs and monologues on such themes as sexual oppression, politics and racism. The acts sometimes include explicit sexual content. NEA critics had cited the four as examples of the endowment's willingness to subsidize works that might be considered obscene. The performers' applications for federal grants were approved last spring by an NEA ``peer review'' panel. But NEA Chairman John E. Frohnmayer vetoed them on June 29, with the concurrence of the 26-member National Council on the Arts, the endowment's presidentially appointed advisory body. At a fund-raising party in Washington for local artists' organizations, Ms. Hughes and Miller said they were disappointed but not surprised by Frohnmayer's decision to deny the four grants, which Ms. Hughes said totaled about $23,000. ``I think it's really clear that Frohnmayer is going ahead with the idea of presenting us as sacrificial lambs to Congress so he can ask for more money for the NEA ... to perpetuate safe, dead artists,'' Ms. Hughes said. ``Now it's a matter for the courts and the constitutional lawyers,'' Miller said. Fleck could not be reached for comment. In response to repeated telephone calls, an NEA spokeswoman said she could not confirm the report and had no comment. Frohnmayer was vacationing and could not be reached by telephone. Although Frohnmayer gave no reasons for rejecting the artists' applications or their appeals, he warned a meeting of arts professionals in Seattle in June that ``political realities'' made it likely he would have to veto some grants recommended by NEA panels of artists. Two days later, he rejected the grant requests by the four performance artists. Each had received NEA grants in the past. Frohnmayer apparently was referring to growing criticism from religious fundamentalists and conservative members of Congress led by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C. They have complained that the arts endowment uses taxpayer dollars to subsidize obscene and sacrilegious works. Last October, at Helms' urging, Congress amended the NEA's current $171 million budget to prohibit use of federal funds for any works that ``may be deemed obscene,'' including depictions of homoeroticism, sadomasochism, sexual exploitation of children and ``individuals engaged in sex acts.'' Although Frohnmayer has said repeatedly that he opposes the Helms statute as unnecessary, he is requiring all NEA grant recipients to sign a pledge that they will not use federal funds to produce obscene art. The pledge has provoked widespread protests in the arts community, and the advisory council voted overwhelmingly in early August to recommend that Frohnmayer eliminate the requirement. The NEA chairman said recently he will keep the anti-obscenity pledge until a federal judge in New York rules _ possibly within a month _ on a lawsuit challenging it as unconstitutional.

DOC.HEAD: Operation PUSH to Continue Boycott
DOC.TEXT: Operation PUSH says it will keep urging a black boycott of Nike after a three-hour meeting with executives of the sports shoe company produced no promise of a comprehensive affirmative action program. The meeting Friday was ``congenial, amiable,'' PUSH founder Jesse Jackson said afterward. But he said Nike executives showed no willingness to yield to the black self-help group's demands for more minority representation in the company. Nike officials and Georgetown University basketball coach John Thompson, who has an endorsement contract with Nike, said progress had been made in the talks. But they declined to predict how the conflict will be resolved. ``Obviously, we're encouraged,'' said Nike President Richard K. Donahue. ``If this meeting had taken place first, there never would have been a boycott.'' Chicago-based PUSH says Nike uses black athletes to advertise its expensive shoes among black youths yet has no minorities on its board of directors and does not advertise in black-owned media outlets. Nike released an affirmative action hiring plan last week in response to the boycott, promising to appoint a black to its board within 24 months. But after Friday's meeting, Jackson suggested he was dissatisfied with that offer as well. ``John Thompson is eminently qualified to be on that board immediately,'' Jackson said. The two sides agreed Friday to provide each other basic information about their organizations, and Jackson said that Nike seemed ``obsessed'' with learning whether PUSH has any contractual agreements with Reebok. Nike has accused PUSH of conspiring with Reebok, a chief Nike competitor. Jackson denied any connection between PUSH and Nike's rival. The civil rights leader also complained that Nike had failed to provide details on the exact job duties of the minorities who make up 14 percent of its 3,000-member work force. ``We suspect that the majority of them are on the bottom,'' Jackson said. PUSH, which has launched successful boycotts against a half-dozen other corporations, has been urging consumers to stop buying Nike products or to cover the Nike emblem on the goods they already own. Tyrone Crider, president of PUSH, said he will travel to different cities in the next week in hopes of expanding the boycott. Jackson and the Nike officials said they would not set a date for future meetings until each side has assessed information provided by the other. ``I expect it would be a week .. or 10 days'' before that happens, Donahue said.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts: Air Power The Key in Gulf Conflict
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. air power in the Persian Gulf, ranging from radar-evading Stealth fighters to carpet-bombing B-52s, will be decisive in any fighting with Iraq, military analysts say. The Americans' technological superiority give its pilots a critical edge over Iraq's war-seasoned veterans, they say. The United States, backed by Britain, has built up an awesome strike capability in the weeks since the Iraqi army invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. As of Friday, the Americans and their allies had an estimated 700 combat aircraft in the region. The Iraqi air force has about 500 planes. ``Air power alone cannot win wars. But the strength of U.S. and British air forces in the gulf, and their electronic and technological capability, is enough to be extremely effective in any conflict,'' said Don Kerr of London's International Institute for Strategic Studies. Allied air power ``can give the Iraqis a very hard time, in the air as well as against strategic targets and Iraq's tank formations,'' he said in an interview. ``But more significantly, they can carry out long-range penetration inside Iraq to hit lines of communication and supply beyond Kuwait,'' he said. The Iraqis fought Iran for eight years and most of their pilots, known as ``eagle warriors,'' have combat experience. But for most of the 1980-88 war, they were up against a seriously depleted Iranian air force, weakened more by shortages of spare parts than combat losses. They became adept at blasting attacking Iranian ground forces and mounting long-range raids on Iranian oil terminals in the southern gulf. Dogfights were rare, so they have little experience with air-to-air combat. ``They also never had to contend with the kind of operations the Americans and British can carry out and they're not very experienced in electronic warfare,'' Kerr said. ``They'll have a lot of difficulties.'' Strategic bombing offensives against Iranian industry were never sustained long enough to do lasting damage. Most of Iraq's pilots are not considered high quality by Western analysts. But they have a core of top guns flying Soviet-made MiG-29s and some French-made Mirage F-1s, the best jets in Saddam's arsenal. Superiority in the air is vital, because the United States is outnumbered and outgunned on the ground. The Iraqis have an estimated 200,000 troops and 1,000 tanks in Kuwait. They have another 3,500 tanks in Iraq. The Americans have about 40,000 men with light armored vehicles in place, backed by Arab forces. These include Saudi Arabia's 450 battle tanks. Some analysts deem allied air power, augmented by the army's anti-tank missiles and tank-killing Apache AH-64 helicopters, sufficient to counter an Iraqi thrust south from occupied Kuwait. But they believe the United States won't be able to mount a major offensive until it has built up its heavy armor. U.S. units and tanks are en route to Saudi Arabia. But it could take weeks before the Americans have marshalled enough armor to have a lethal punch. In the gulf region, the U.S. aircraft carriers Independence and Saratoga have a combined air strength of more than 100 fighter planes. The USS Dwight D. Eisenhower in the eastern Mediterranean has more than 50 aircraft capable of hitting Iraq from the west. Two more carrier battle groups led by the USS John F. Kennedy and the USS Midway are heading for the Middle East with 100 more fighters. Britain's Royal Air Force has 12 Tornado F3 fighter-bombers in Saudi Arabia and a squadron of Jaguar ground-attack jets in Oman. Backing them is the Saudi air force's nearly 200 combat aircraft, with another 150 from other gulf states. Kuwaiti pilots got most of their 36 fighters to Saudi Arabia before the Iraqis overran the emirate. U.S. F-16s, deployed in the gulf area, are considered more than a match for Iraq's Mirages and MiG-29s. Most of Iraq's air force is composed of older Soviet-built fighter planes. Moscow is reported to have recently supplied Baghdad with long-range Su-24 fighter-bombers, which could pose a threat. But analysts believe the U.S. and British pilots can handle the planes.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Cuts Helicopter Program to Save $7.8 Billion
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney says his decision to cut in half the number of planned purchases of a new generation helicopter for the Army will save close to $8 billion over the long run. The Army will buy 1,292 of the attack and reconnaissance helicopters, which are still on the drawing board, instead of the previously planned 2,096, Cheney said Friday. The yearly rate of production will be 120 instead of 216. The change will cut the program's total cost to $34.2 billion from the originally projected $42 billion, the Army said. But it will increase the cost of each helicopter produced because the research and development costs will be spread among fewer aircraft. The Army said each helicopter is expected to cost $8.9 million, up from the previous estimate of $7.5 million. Cheney said the demonstration phase of the program will be extended by two years to allow for full testing of a prototype. Two corporate teams are competing for the production contract. One is comprised of McDonnell Douglas Helicopter Co. of Mesa, Ariz., and Bell Helicopter Textron of Fort Worth, Texas. The other is Boeing Helicopters of Philadelphia and Sikorsky Aircraft Co. of Stratford, Conn. A McDonnell Douglas spokesman said the company views Cheney's announcement to build a prototype as a positive step in the development of the helicopter. ``It is an endorsement that the LH (light helicopter) concept is the best solution for the Army's next generation of reconnaissance, armed helicopters,'' said spokesman Ken Jensen. ``We have suggested that the prototype would be the next logical step,'' A single contracting team for full-scale development of the helicopter is to be chosen next February. ``I am convinced that the Light Helicopter is essential to our long-term strategy of meeting worldwide requirements with a smaller, lighter Army force structure,'' Cheney said in a prepared statement after a department review of the program. The new helicopter is designed to perform reconnaissance at night, in adverse weather conditions, at high altitudes and in hot climates, the Pentagon said. The Bush administration's budget request for the 1991 fiscal year that begins Oct. 1 includes $465 million for research, development, testing and evaluation of the new-generation helicopter, but Congress is expected to approved a smaller total.

DOC.HEAD: Eleven States Get Preliminary Population Reports
DOC.TEXT: Hawaii and Nevada have topped the 1-million population mark, according to the Census Bureau, which is issuing preliminary 1990 counts for 11 states. While 10 of the states showed population gains in data released Friday, Ohio recorded a decline from the 1980 national head count. The bureau said that it had counted 10,777,514 people in Ohio, down from 10,798,000 in 1980. Officials stressed that the reports are preliminary. They are designed to give local officials a chance to raise questions if they find areas where they believe people have been missed or overcounted. The final, official, census counts are scheduled for release on Dec. 31. Friday's report brings to 40 the number of states for which preliminary counts have been published. The rest are expected in the next week or two. Newly released state counts, and the census count in 1980 are: _Alaska, 545,774, up from 402,000. _Arizona, 3,619,064, up from 2,718,000. _Colorado, 3,272,460, up from 2,890,000. _Hawaii, 1,095,237, up from 965,000. _Kansas, 2,467,845, up from 2,364,000. _Maryland, 4,732,934, up from 4,217,000. _Nevada, 1,193,287, up from 800,000. _North Carolina, 6,552,927, up from 5,882,000. _Ohio, 10,777,514, down from 10,798,000. _Virginia, 6,127,680, up from 5,347,000. _Washington, 4,826,675, up from 4,132,000.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq's Invasion Allows China Public Relations Coup
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Communist China has turned Iraq's invasion of Kuwait into a badly needed public relations coup by helping stranded ethnic Chinese from Hong Kong and Taiwan flee the Middle East. ``Beijing has done beautifully,'' read an editorial by Ming Pao, an independent Hong Kong daily that often criticizes Beijing. ``Without much effort, it saved a group of fellow Chinese and won the approval of Taiwanese and overseas Chinese.'' So far, China has helped 159 ethnic Chinese from Taiwan and Hong Kong leave Kuwait and Iraq following Baghdad's Aug. 2 invasion of its oil-rich neighbor. Taiwanese had difficulty returning home because their government doesn't have diplomatic relations with Kuwait or Iraq, which both recognize China. Hong Kong residents had problems because they carry Hong Kong-British passports, which made them British citizens in the eyes of the invading Iraqis. Iraq has refused to allow most of the estimated 21,000 Westerners leave Iraq and Kuwait, including about 3,000 Americans. China apparently easily persuaded Iraq to free its ``compatriots,'' as Beijing's official Xinhua News Agency refers to ethnic Chinese. At least until the invasion, China has been one of Iraq's top arms suppliers and has maintained close economic and military ties with Baghdad. The episode is ironic because Beijing has technically been at war with Nationalist Taiwan since 1949 when Chinese Communist troops forced the Nationalists from mainland China. And few people in Hong Kong have any love for the Communist government, especially since June 4, 1989, when China crushed a student-led movement for freedom in Beijing in which hundreds, perhaps thousands died. More than 1,000 people emigrate from the British colony each week, having lost faith in China's promise to maintain the freewheeling economic and social system for 50 years after 1997, when Beijing resumes control of the territory. In Hong Kong, the episode gave China badly needed good press. In Taiwan, prestigious political analyst Chiou Hung-ta warned of a ``potential danger'' of people losing confidence in the Nationalist government if China continues to successfully employ such tactics to win the hearts of Taiwanese. One Western diplomat said China's quick response to requests for help in the gulf was aimed at convincing the people of Taiwan and Hong Kong they ultimately must recognize Beijing as their capital. China's two main foreign policy questions in the 1990s will be its upcoming takeover of jittery Hong Kong and its hopes to re-unite with Taiwan. Beijing has yet to abandon its threat to attack Taiwan in order to force unification. ``The Chinese are saying, `When the chips are down, you've got to admit that Beijing is the boss,''' the diplomat said on condition of anonymity. In Beijing, a Foreign Ministry spokesman offered an explanation to illustrate Chinese thinking on the issue: ``The people on the two sides of the Taiwan Straits are all Chinese. Naturally, we should offer assistance within our capacity to our Taiwanese compatriots who have run into difficulties in other countries.'' The type of assistance China provided also won it praise. The Chinese Embassy issued Taiwanese travel permits and not passports, avoiding the sticky question of forcing the Taiwanese to accept Chinese citizenship. The episode in the gulf highlights what many Chinese intellectuals call ``the crisis of Chinese identity.'' ``We all consider ourselves Chinese but the crisis comes when we have to choose a government to represent us,'' said Joseph Y.S. Cheng, a leading educator in Hong Kong. For thousands of years, Chinese have considered themselves united as a people not because they shared a capital, but because they shared a common culture, rooted in a common written language. The events in the gulf ``rang a bell with almost all Chinese intellectuals,'' Cheng said. ``We realize that we can't just be culturally Chinese,'' he said. ``We must also belong to a political group. For many of us, the time for choosing is now and the choices are few.''

DOC.HEAD: Experts Find Big Risks in Tying Ad Campaigns to Iraq Crisis
With PM-US Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Madison Avenue hypesters have seldom been shy about waving the flag to boost sales. But commercial-makers have so far stayed away from ads tied to the U.S. military effort in the Saudi desert. Advertising experts say they don't expect many will try _ at least as long as there is a chance the Persian Gulf could explode into war. ``Companies tend to jump on things that they know have no enormous downside _ things like the Wall coming down in Berlin,'' said Jack Trout, a marketing consultant. The Persian Gulf has a big downside, Trout said. The region could erupt into all-out war, exposing any effort to draw a connection with the troops as crass commercialization. Short of that, he said a campaign tied to the gulf could antagonize Americans who are opposed to U.S. involvement there. ``Marketers want to deal with 100 percent,'' Trout said. ``They don't want to be associated with an event that still has a negative potential with a piece of their marketplace.'' Dave Hudgens, a spokesman for Chevrolet, said the automaker has no plans to run commercials tied to the Gulf. ``That is too volatile a situation to try and capitalize on it in a commercial way,'' he said. Burger King Corp. and Coca-Cola Co. each said they had no plans for Gulf-related ads. Stephen A. Greyser, professor of consumer marketing at the Harvard Business School, recalled that in the aftermath of the Soviet Union's invasion of Afghanistan in the late 1970s, some vodka makers developed marketing campaigns that exploited anti-Soviet sentiment to lure drinkers away from Russian vodka. During World War I, he said U.S. vendors of sauerkraut began calling their product Liberty Cabbage to avoid any possible connection with the German enemy. But Greyser said there are no products sold here that are so clearly associated with Iraq to inspire any similar counter-marketing efforts. Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. But what about companies that may be providing products American troops are using to do their jobs? Quaker Oats Co., for instance, supplies the drink Gatorade to military bases, and it announced Thursday that it had ``stepped up its efforts to supply the U.S. armed forces'' for use in the desert in Saudi Arabia. Spokesman Ronald Bottrell said the company had shipped more than 20,000 cases of the drink for use by troops in Saudi Arabia and had orders for 100,000 more cases. But aside from announcing the order, Bottrell said the Chicago-based company had no plans to tout it in advertising. ``Our feeling this week was not to hype this,'' he said. So why put out in a news release to the media? Bottrell said he issued it only after receiving about a dozen calls from reporters who were writing stories about supplying the troops. ``We felt we wanted to get on the record,'' he said. Harvard's Greyser said the public would accept advertising that makes a connection between a product and the Persian Gulf crisis if there was ``a legitimate connection'' between the product's performance, its use in a desert setting and its use in civilian life.

DOC.HEAD: Magellan Team Rests After Emotional Highs and Lows
LaserPhotos LA1
DOC.TEXT: Magellan engineers tried to recover today from an emotional roller-coaster ride after the unruly spaceship gave them great pictures of Venus and ``moments of terror and of great happiness.'' ``We've got to get the team rested,'' Magellan project manager Tony Spear told a news conference Friday at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. Magellan was launched from the shuttle Atlantis on May 4, 1989. It started orbiting Venus Aug. 10 on a $744 million radar-mapping mission to make the best pictures and maps yet of the cloud-covered planet. The spacecraft returned its first pictures of Venus last week. New pictures released Friday, including a spectacular three-dimensional image, show a 20-mile-wide meteorite impact crater with a floor covered by lava flows. Science and mission planning manager Tommy Thompson said engineers and scientists felt ``a little strung out'' after the spacecraft malfunctioned and lost contact with Earth twice: first for 14 hours starting Aug. 16, then for 17{ hair-raising hours beginning Tuesday night. ``It's kind of like having a date for the prom, stubbing your toe the night before, getting up the next morning and stubbing a toe on the other foot,'' Thompson said. While Magellan mission control is staffed around the clock, many other team members were resting this weekend, he said. Until engineers identify and fix the problem that cut the radio link, ``I think it's likely to happen again,'' Spear said earlier Friday. If contact is lost again, engineers are ready with new computer commands to ``kick start'' Magellan's automatic safety systems and make the spacecraft re-establish contact with Earth immediately, Spear said. ``My heart can't stand this 17-hour loss of signal'' again, he said. ``There are moments of terror and of great happiness after we recovered the signal.'' The emotional wear-and-tear showed a bit Friday as National Aeronautics and Space Administration officials contradicted each other on one possible explanation for the communication problems. During the news conference, spacecraft system engineer John Slonski said the braking rocket Magellan used to slow down and go into orbit around Venus might have failed to separate fully, or might have burned some cables as it was jettisoned. ``It's a possibility we're investigating that the solid rocket motor really hasn't gone away _ that it's still hanging on'' and bumping into Magellan, Slonski said. Spear called that possibility remote and contrary to available evidence, but also said it was conceivable the rocket yanked out some cables on Magellan as it separated from the spacecraft. Two hours later, the laboratory's public relations office issued a statement saying there was ``currently no doubt the separation was complete.'' Spokesmen refused to elaborate when asked to explain the contradiction between that statement and those made by Slonski. Even if the rocket had not completely separated, it wouldn't prevent Magellan from conducting its mission, Spear said. The official mapping effort is likely to start no earlier than mid-September, two weeks later than planned, he said. Engineers also were considering the possibility the communications failures were caused by problems with Magellan's computer hardware or programs, or the unlikely chance Magellan is being affected by previously unknown electrical fields around Venus. One of the biggest joys was that Magellan's first pictures of Venus, made during an Aug. 16 radar test, lived up to NASA's promise of being 10 times more detailed than the best obtained from radar on Earth or from the Soviet Venera 15 and 16 spacecraft in the mid-1980s. The meteorite impact crater shown in pictures released Friday has a very smooth floor and a central peak. The smooth floor indicates the crater was flooded by volcanic lava, either during or sometime after the impact, said Steve Saunders, Magellan's chief scientist. He said the crater is relatively young geologically, 100 million to 150 million years old. It is named after Soviet sculptor Anna Golubkina, who lived from 1864 to 1927. Other pictures from Magellan showed intense ``Venusquake'' faulting, lava flows and a network of intersecting ridges and valleys.

DOC.HEAD: South African Police Face Tough Odds in Township War
DOC.TEXT: Police face a shortage of both manpower and credibility as they confront black factional fighting in the townships ringing Johannesburg that has claimed more than 500 lives. In many instances, only a handful of police have been present to prevent battles between hundreds of angry Zulus and Xhosas, warring since Aug. 12. Also, many township residents view the police as an enemy rather than a protector. They accuse police of bias and even active participation in the bloodletting. ``We have evidence that there are elements in the police force that seem to be interested in the violence spreading,'' said Pallo Jordan, a spokesman for the African National Congress, the country's leading black opposition movement. Police emphatically deny the charges, and many neutral observers believe the police have been far more restrained than in recent years. A four-year national state of emergency lifted in June had given police extensive powers, and officers routinely used force to break up even peaceful demonstrations. ``The suggestion that police either disarm or tear gas certain sectors of the community in order to facilitate Inkatha attacks ... is unfounded,'' said Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok. The government acknowledges it needs more police and is adding 10,000 policeman to the 70,000-strong national force, responsible for a vast country with a population of 30 million people. Some accusations of police bias appear based on anger that police won't let the two sides fight it out. Other blacks point fingers because officers won't side with them against their opponents. Policemen are often the most visible symbol of white authority in black townships, and there is inevitably suspicion of their actions. Many township residents say police favor Zulus, tied to the conservative Inkatha political movement, in their township battles against mostly Xhosas who back the ANC. In Kagiso, a hard-hit township west of Johannesburg, residents said police simply stood watch at night as Zulus attacked homes with stones, gasoline bombs and guns then took money, televisions and radios from the unarmed residents. ``The police do nothing to stop the Zulus,'' said one Kagiso resident who gave his name only as Joe. ``We call the police, but they do not respond.'' Associated Press reporters saw several uniformed black municipal police officers fighting alongside the Zulus in Kagiso. Other Zulus said the officers were Zulus living in hostels and were defending themselves. Municipal police work for particular townships and are distinct from the national police who have borne the brunt of the fighting. But regular police in Kagiso reacted swiftly on several occasions Thursday to intervene between Zulus living in a migrant workers hostel and township residents who said they wanted to destroy the hostel. Police fired tear gas at both sides to prevent clashes between heavily armed gangs. When residents could not reach the hostel, they threw gasoline bombs and stones at police. Police responded with more tear gas. Several residents were hurt and others were arrested.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News ^LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Connie Chung got booed and hissed in absentia when she sent a videotaped apology to a journalists' convention where she was to have given the keynote address. The 44-year-old Chung last month put her CBS-TV series, ``Face to Face With Connie Chung,'' on hold, saying she wanted to try to have a baby. In a videotape screened Friday before the Asian American Journalists Association, she made no mention of why she couldn't attend, other than to say, ``It was very important for me to be here.'' Some in the audience showed their displeasure. ``I wish I could be there with you,'' Chung said. ``If I could have been, I would have been.''

Milton Berle has an illegitimate son he sometimes runs into at Hollywood parties, but the comedian has never disclosed their relationship, an associate confirmed. ``My son always comes up to me and says, `Hello, Milton. How are you?' Little does he know he's talking to his father,''' the National Enquirer quoted Berle as saying in its Sept. 4 issue. Michael Bass, producer of a television special Berle is preparing on his 75 years in show business, said Friday the Enquirer's story is accurate. Berle, 82, says his 51-year-old son was born to an actress he met at the Beverly Hills Hotel. ``It was very early in our careers and neither of us was looking for any long-term involvement,'' he said. He refuses to tell his son the truth ``because his mother is still alive, and I keep silent out of respect for her. I want to wait until she dies.'' He did not identify her. ``I dream of him many a night,'' Berle said. ``And in those dreams I tell him. In case I die without ever telling him, he's taken care of in my will.'' Berle has married twice and has four children.

Mayor Sidney Barthelemy says he'll swim in a tankful of sharks after losing a bet that New Orleans' Aquarium of the Americas wouldn't open on schedule on Labor Day weekend. ``I know it's risky, but this represents my commitment to the City of New Orleans,'' Barthelemy said Friday. ``If I have to swim with the sharks to prove my commitment, I will.''
