Barthelemy said he'd pay on Tuesday the bet he made with Ron Forman, the aquarium's executive director, that the $40 million aquarium wouldn't be completed by its Sept. 1 deadline. The aquarium will have more than 10,000 aquatic specimens _ including 30 sharks and a 14-foot sawfish in the Gulf of Mexico exhibit that Barthelemy said he'll swim in.

A bugged Gov. Jim Florio sent a biting letter to a Bahamas-based hotel and casino that advises gamblers to steer clear of rival casinos in Atlantic City because the mosquito is ``New Jersey's state bird.'' Christopher Raphael, senior vice president in charge of The Carnival Crystal Palace's casino in Nassau, said its print advertisements were ``only in good fun'' and that Florio was overreacting. The ads say that while the islands' ``gentle trade winds keep our summer so cool and breezy,'' gamblers in Atlantic City have to endure hot summers. ``It's muggy out there,'' the ads say. ``That's why they've made the mosquito New Jersey's state bird.'' Florio said the ads pestered him, so he fired off a letter to the casino expressing disappointment with the campaign. ``Millions of people from around the world choose to come to the Jersey shore every year because it's fun, it's clean, it's inexpensive and, may I add, largely free of mosquitoes,'' Florio wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Troops Seal U.S., Other Embassies in Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 21st `He quoted...' to UPDATE with stated deadline passing with no Iraqi action immediately reported. Pickup 22nd graf `Baghdad has...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi soldiers sealed off the U.S. and at least eight other embassies in Kuwait on Friday, and Baghdad threatened to forcibly remove any diplomats whose governments defied orders to close their missions. U.S. Ambassador Nathaniel Howell and a skeleton staff of about 10 remained at the palm-fringed U.S. compound near the Persian Gulf coast. Richard Boucher, a State Department spokesman, said Howell and his staff would stay, keeping in touch with the 2,500 Americans trapped in Kuwait ``as much as circumstances allow.'' They were keeping telephone conversations short because Iraqis were listening in, Boucher said in Washington. In Amman, Jordan, a Spanish diplomat said Baghdad had threatened to use force to remove diplomats remaining at their posts in Kuwait city on Saturday. Electricity and water were cut to the British and Greek embassies, officials in those countries said. West Germany's foreign ministry said the Iraqis had warned embassies they would take such action if they do not close. In London, a Foreign Office spokesman said later that Iraqi tanks had moved into position to back up troops outside the British Embassy in Kuwait, where Ambassador Michaely Weston and three staff members remained. ``The ambassador and his staff are in good heart and, the last time we heard from them, they were drinking champagne by candlelight,'' said the spokesman, who cannot be identified under briefing rules. The spokesman said the embassy staff had stocked up food supplies in case the Iraqis tried to starve them out. Britain's foreign secretary, Douglas Hurd, said his embassy's staff would decide for themselves how to oppose any Iraqi move on the mission. ``I don't expect, no one expects, unarmed diplomats to give physical resistance to physical force,'' he said. About a dozen Iraqi soldiers surrounded the Canadian Embassy in Kuwait, preventing individuals from entering or leaving the mission. In Gaspe, Quebec, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said Iraq ``is well on the way to becoming ... a pariah nation.'' More than 100 U.S. embassy personnel and dependents, including the Marine guards, left the U.S. embassy in Kuwait on Thursday and were staying in the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad, said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Fitzwater said the Iraqis had promised earlier to allow the group to leave Iraq, then reneged. He said Iraqi forces ``of one kind or another'' were surrounding the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait but ``have not made any moves against the embassy or intruded in any fashion.'' ``It would appear that people are not being allowed to enter or leave the embassy,'' Fitzwater said in Kennebunkport, Maine. Iraqi troops were also surrounding or patrolling near the French, Japanese, Norwegian, Swedish, Romanian and Hungarian embassies. The official Iraqi News Agency said Iraq would only detain the male embassy employees _ including diplomats _ of those countries that refused to close their embassies in Kuwait. But there was no indication that dependents, including the U.S. women and children who had traveled to Baghdad, were being allowed to leave. INA quoted an unidentified official spokesman in Baghdad as saying Iraq ``is determined'' to implement its decision to shut down the embassies in Kuwait. President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, who seized Kuwait in a lightning assault on Aug. 2 and later annexed it, had given foreign governments until 9 p.m. Friday to vacate their embassies in Kuwait. Spain's ambassador to Jordan, Ramon Armengod, told a news conference in Jordan on Friday that Iraqi authorities later told the embassies in Kuwait that they had until 8:30 a.m. Saturday to close. He quoted Iraqi authorities as saying that once the Saturday deadline passed, troops would ``proceed with the forced evacuation'' of diplomats. The deadline passed with no immediate report of action by Iraqi troops. Baghdad has said that keeping the embassies open would amount to an ``act of aggression'' and that diplomats remaining in Kuwait would no longer be considered protected by diplomatic immunity. The United States, Canada, Japan, Bangladesh, Switzerland, Austria, Poland, Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia, Egypt and the 12 European Community nations were among those countries who declared they would defy the order. They have evacuated most of their staff and dependents, leaving behind only skeleton staffs. Egypt has refused to close its embassy or reduce its staff of 20, and its foreign ministry announced Friday that it would hold Iraq responsible for any harm to its mission. In Cairo, four truckloads of riot police remained outside the Iraqi Embassy, where they have been stationed since the invasion of Kuwait. The United States and other countries said their embassies have a right to remain in Kuwait because they do not recognize Iraq's annexation of the oil-rich emirate and need to provide assistance to citizens trapped there. About 3,000 Americans and 4,500 Britons are among the roughly 21,000 Westerners trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. Among the countries complying with the Iraqi order to close their embassies were Lebanon, Jordan and the Philippines. The Soviet Union, Malaysia and India evacuated all of their embassy personnel from Kuwait, but said they did not consider their missions closed. Saudi Arabia refused to close its embassy, but its legation in Kuwait has been locked since the invasion and the Saudi ambassador is back in his country. About 60 countries have embassies in Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Altered Antibodies Could Fight Drugs, Pollution, Poison Gas
DOC.TEXT: Scientists who successfully bonded metal ions to an antibody say it's the first step toward creating super-antidotes that could neutralize chemical weapons, drug overdoses and most poisons. The metal ions act as catalysts that can convert poisons to harmless substances inside the human body, said Stephen J. Benkovic, a chemistry professor at Penn State. ``It could be used as a detoxifying agent for people who have taken a drug overdose and can be used against environmental pollutants,'' Benkovic said in an interview. When the U.S. military learned of the early laboratory success, it asked for a briefing about applications in chemical warfare, he said. The ``metalloantibodies'' can be made by altering the amino acid sequence of protein to make it easier to bind with a metal, said Sheila A. Iverson, working on the project at the Research Institute of Scripps Clinic at La Jolla, Calif. Antibodies occur naturally in the body and are integral components of the human immune system. They attack invading bacteria and viruses. Using metal ions could broaden their range to combat strong toxins the human body cannot fight. Through different modifications, antidotes could one day be developed for any poison, making metalloantibodies a logical defense against chemical warfare, said David Lenz, an Army pharmacologist at the Aberdeen Proving Ground in Maryland. ``It can be used not so much to demoralize the enemy, but to reduce the threat of him using chemical weapons at all,'' Lenz said. ``They won't use them if they're not going to work.'' Development of antibodies for humans is years away, but recent laboratory successes are promising, he said. ``By having a metal ion embedded in the protein, it can now catalyze many diverse chemical reactions,'' said Benkovic, whose work with Richard Lerner of the Research Institute was published in the Aug. 10 issue of Science magazine. A metalloantibody could be developed to treat cocaine overdoses, Benkovic said. ``The antibody can convert poisons by acting as a catalyst,'' he said. ``It changes the first toxin it sees, then keeps on going until there's no toxin left. The antibody can be engineered to bind toxins or chemically change them.'' With zinc or copper attached, the new antibody could be injected into a person even before exposure. Chemical poisons rendered harmless would be excreted. In research conducted between April and June, Benkovic and Lerner experimented on genetic material exposed to fluorescein, which emits a known amount of energy. After altering the genetic material's antibodies with a copper ion, they exposed the new product to fluorescein. Energy changes in the original foreign substance took place. ``When metal binds to fluorescein, it should change the energy level,'' Ms. Iverson said, so researchers knew the metal ion had been successfully added to the antibody. To make the process work on animals or humans, scientists must explore the structure of other antibodies and determine what what chemical alterations are needed to make the metal attach to them. If successful, antidotes could one day be mass-produced, Benkovic said. ``We have shown that you can bind a metal ion to an antibody,'' Benkovic said. ``It's a start.''

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Dispute Complicating Unity Process
DOC.TEXT: A sizzling abortion debate in both East and West Germany threatens to hold up a treaty that would merge the laws of the two states. The newly adopted Oct. 3 unity date is not endangered, but failure of the treaty would leave a number of legal issues to be settled by an all-German parliament. All-German elections are not set until Dec. 2. The opposition Social Democrats have threatened to torpedo the treaty following a government decision that West German women who after unity try to take advantage of East Germany's permissive abortion law can be prosecuted. The Social Democrats have insisted West German law should only apply to West German turf. Party chief Hans-Jochen Vogel said Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government cannot ``force a special regulation that discriminates against women.'' Kohl needs a two-thirds majority for the treaty to pass Parliament and thus needs the backing of the Social Democrats, West Germany's second-biggest party. The treaty covers a grab bag of issues, including distribution of sales tax revenues among the German states, how to settle claims by West Germans on property they once owned in East Germany, and abortion rights. For weeks women's rights groups, politicians and government officials in both Germanys have feuded over the best abortion law for a united Germany. In West Germany, abortions are allowed only if there is life-threatening risk to the mother, if the pregnancy resulted from rape or incest, or if the birth would create extraordinary social and economic hardship for her. East German women, on the other hand, have a fundamental legal right to an abortion, as long as it occurs within the first 12 weeks of pregnancy. East Germany, with a population of about 16 million, last year recorded 73,000 abortions. The figure was 75,297 in West Germany, which has a population abour four times greater than its eastern neighbor. The two Germanys have agreed to keep their respective abortion laws until a single set of statutes can be worked out, which could take years. There is strong pressure from East German women to not scrap their nation's abortion law. Many conservative West Germans insist their law is the correct one. The Roman Catholic Church and the Lutheran Church added their powerful voices to the debate Friday. In a joint statement, the two churches criticized East Germany's abortion statute, saying it fails to ``stress that every death of a human being stands in contradiction to the foundations for a humane system of laws.'' The statement was authored by Bishop Martin Kruse, head of the German Lutheran Church, and his Roman Catholic counterpart, Bishop Karl Lehmann. Kohl, however, is feeling pressure from within his coalition to be more liberal on the abortion issue. Leaders of the Free Democrats, Kohl's junior coalition partners, reluctantly agreed that West German women who go to East Germany for abortions after unity should face prosecution. But many party members now say that decision was a mistake, and they won't support it in a parliamentary vote. A weekend meeting is planned to try to resolve the dispute.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Olympic Official Hopes To Host Games In Year 2000
DOC.TEXT: China, having built international sports facilities for the 11th Asian Games, has now set its sights on hosting the Olympics in the year 2000, a senior official said. He Zhenliang, president of the Chinese Olympic Committee, said China was ``taking an active attitude'' toward bidding for the 2000 Olympics, the official Xinhua news agency reported late Friday. Plans to bid for the games would depend on the success of the 11th Asian Games that China will host Sept. 22-Oct. 7, he was quoted as saying. The Asian Games will be China's first major international sports event. Organizers have rushed to complete facilities that have been widely expected to be not just for the Asian Games but also in preparation for bidding to host the Olympics.

DOC.HEAD: Five Convicts Kill Prison Guard, Flee With Four Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Five inmates killed a guard, took four hostages and escaped from a maximum security prison in southeastern Brazil, a television network reported. TV Globo, Brazil's largest network, said one guard died after being shot in the head by the convicts when the incident began during the prison lunch hour Friday. The jailbreak took place at the Contagem prison in Belo Horizonte, about 290 miles northwest of Rio. After taking two guards as hostages, the prisoners demanded an armored car to make their getaway, Globo reported. Officials delivered the armored car in the late afternoon and the prisoners fled, after trading the guards for four state troopers, Globo reported. The network said a helicopter and 20 police vehicles were following the armored car, which as of late Friday night was heading south on a major road.

DOC.HEAD: Reverse Peace Corps Brings Foreigners to Work with Poor in U.S.
DOC.TEXT: The Peace Corps usually conjures up images of idealistic American youth aiding the poor in distant lands. In a new twist, a former Peace Corps volunteer has started a program for foreigners to work at soup kitchens and homeless shelters in America's inner cities. The first two Peace Corps-in-reverse volunteers arrived in Boston this summer from Ghana and Czechoslovakia. Ghana was the first country to receive American volunteers, and the latter one of the latest. The two already have worked in soup kitchens and an inner-city day camp, planted gardens at a homeless shelter and aided the elderly. Both said the poverty they encountered surprised them. ``I knew there possibly would be some problems, but not to this extent,'' said Charles Hutchinson, 29, a biology teacher taught by Peace Corps volunteers as a teen-ager in southern Ghana. More than 130,000 volunteers and staff have served in the Peace Corps in 95 countries since John F. Kennedy founded the overseas development agency in March 1961 in his first major initiative as president. Hutchinson and Ester Boszormenyiova, 24, of Czechoslovakia, spoke outside the John F. Kennedy Library about the two-month pilot program, funded by $6,000 in private donations. ``I think everybody who comes to the United States, they think this is a very rich country ... a kind of Hollywood life,'' Boszormenyiova said. Boszormenyiova said she has few illusions about the darker side of capitalism. She was particularly disturbed by the problems of American youth. Hutchinson said learning about urban poverty here will serve him well when he returns home. ``Many of our countries in Africa are going through very fast development in terms of urbanization,'' he said. Tracy Mathieu, a former Peace Corps volunteer, started up the pilot program, and hopes to extend it next year so that 100 volunteers _ two for every state _ can come to the United States for the summer. ``We're getting a lot of interest in it,'' said Mathieu, who once supervised a water sanitation project in West Africa. ``It's really taking off.'' Supporters include Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., economist John Kenneth Galbraith and Citizens Energy Corp. President Michael Kennedy, a nephew of the late president. A reverse Peace Corps project was first proposed in 1961 by former Ghanaian Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah. For two years, between 1966 and 1968, overseas Peace Corps volunteers came to the United States and worked in VISTA, the Volunteers in Service to America progam for improving the living conditions of impoverished Americans. But the program was never approved by Congress, Mathieu said. Both of this year's volunteers, who plan to attend school in the United States when the program ends, said they are inspired by Kennedy's call to American youth: ``Ask not what your country can do for you, ask what you can do for your country.'' Boszormenyiova said Kennedy's words hold significance for Czechoslovak youth who want to foster democracy in the midst of Eastern Europe's political upheavals. ``It was something I really started thinking about,'' she said. ``I feel that I must give something to my country. I'm proud of Czechoslovakia, as John Kennedy was proud of America. People in Czechoslovakia are waking up.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Passenger Jumbo Jetliners Barely Avoid Collision
DOC.TEXT: Two jumbo jetliners with a total of 942 people aboard barely avoided colliding over western Japan, flying within about 330 feet of each other before veering away, aviation authorities said. The incident took place near Osaka International Airport Thursday evening, the Transport Ministry said in a release seen today. The release said the incident occurred about 27 miles south of the airport when an All Nippon Airways Boeing 747 and another Boeing 747 owned by Cathay Pacific Airways were approaching the airport. The planes were both flying at an altitude of 13,000 feet. The pilots of both airliners barely avoided a collision by turning at the instructions of air traffic controllers at the Osaka flight tower, officials said. ANA flight 530, carrying 521 passengers and 15 crew members, was arriving from Kumamoto in southwestern Japan, and CPA flight 564, with 22 crew members and 384 passengers, was on a flight from Hong Kong via Taipei. Officials of the Civil Aviation Bureau in the ministry are investigating why the two planes were flying at the same altitude, the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
United Nations Approves Use of Force to Back Economic Sanctions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with U.N. resolution; Pickup 6th, `Iraq's Parliament; Edits to Trim.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY15
DOC.TEXT: The United Nations sanctioned the use of force to back up a U.N. economic embargo of Iraq early Saturday, while Sadam Hussein made diplomats his latest target, ringing foreign missions in Kuwait with Iraqi troops. On Friday, the Soviet Union announced it was ending its objections to the U.S. initiative, clearing the way for passage of the resolution. That move came after Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned Saddam Hussein the Persian Gulf situation was ``extremely dangerous'' and suggested in an urgent message his country might now support a military blockade of Iraq. In Baghdad, Saddam detained a group of U.S. Embassy dependents and staff who had been promised safe passage from his capital. He said they would not be released until Kuwait's U.S. Embassy was vacated. Britain said tanks surrounded its embassy, and the water and power were cut. It later reported on Saturday that the tanks were withdrawn and electricity restored. The Middle East conflict on Friday came home to hundreds of U.S. military reservists called up in the first such summons since Vietnam. Iraq's parliament speaker, Sadi Mehdi Saleh, warned the same day the presence of U.S. forces in the gulf might ignite a war that would set the region and its oil reserves afire and kill thousands of Americans. At the United Nations, the 15-member Security Council voted for a U.S. initiative that puts teeth into U.N. sanctions against Iraq. The resolution by the 15-member council passed with 13 votes in favor and 2 abstentions. It calls on nations with naval forces in the Persian Gulf region ``to use such measures commensurate to the specific circumstances as may be necessary under the authority of the Security Council to halt all inward and outward maritime.'' Yemen and Cuba abstained from the vote. At least nine embassies in Kuwait _ including the U.S. and British missions _ were guarded by troops Friday as diplomats defied an Iraqi order to close their doors. With its Aug. 2 conquest of Kuwait and its quick annexation of the small oil state, Iraq now considers Kuwait to be Iraqi territory. A European envoy said Baghdad threatened to use force to remove diplomats remaining at their posts on Saturday. The Iraqis also threatened to cut water and power to the missions, and the Foreign Office in London said they did just that on Friday at the British Embassy. Like other embassies staying open, the U.S. mission had a skeleton staff of about 10. More than 100 U.S. Embassy staff and dependents, including about 30 children, left Kuwait only to find new trouble in Baghdad, where they were detained. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Friday the Iraqis had promised earlier to allow the group of Americans to leave, but then reneged. ``They are safe,'' he said _ but stuck. The official Iraqi News Agency said later that Iraq would only detain the male embassy employees _ including diplomats _ of those countries that refused to close their embassies in occupied Kuwait. But there was no indication the dependents were being allowed to leave. The Foreign Ministry in Rome said three Italian diplomats who left Kuwait Thursday were kept from leaving Baghdad on Friday, and that the reason cited was that Italy's Embassy in Kuwait had defied orders to close. Besides the diplomats, about 21,000 Westerners _ including 3,000 Americans _were caught in Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait by the invasion and President Bush said they must be considered hostages. Getting out of Iraq was becoming harder even for people from countries not considered hostile toward Baghdad. Jordan, however, still let refugees cross over from Iraq despite Wednesday's announcement that the border would be closed to them. Jordan said coping with thousands of refugees had become too much of a burden. The European Community and others moved to help with money and supplies. Turkey, another escape route for refugees, said it might close its border with Iraq unless countries whose nationals are coming through take steps to ensure quick transport elsewhere. In his message, Gorbachev had urged Iraq to comply immediately with U.N. Security Council resolutions. The Soviet ambassador to the U.N., Valentin V. Lozinskiy, later announced in New York that Moscow was ending its resistance to backing the U.N.-ordered embargo with military muscle. He also indicated the Soviets would be willing to join an international force to police the embargo. In Moscow, Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh said that the Soviets had pulled all staff from their Kuwait embassy _ but insisted they had not formally closed it. The Soviets _ long an ally of Iraq _ immediately cut off weapons supplies to Baghdad following the invasion. At the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, Ambassador Nathaniel Howell and a dozen other Americans remained. The White House said the Iraqi troops outside the embassy in Kuwait ``are not allowing people to enter or leave.'' Troops were reported surrounding or patrolling near the American, British, Canadian, French, Japanese, Norwegian, Swedish, Romanian and Hungarian embassies. Nations including Venezuela, the Philippines, India and Lebanon complied with the embassy-closing order. Spain's Ambassador to Amman, Ramon Armengod, said in Madrid that Iraqi authorities warned the Western diplomats that troops would forcibly remove them from their missions starting Saturday. Also, the Japanese Foreign Ministry said Iraqi soldiers told the two Japanese diplomats remaining in Kuwait Friday that their diplomatic immunity had been revoked but made no attempt to remove them from the embassy. The 12 European Community members indicated they would seek an a ``explicit, firm condemnation'' by the Security Council of Iraq's behavior if their embassies were interfered with. In the Arabian desert, Iraqi troops are confronting tens of thousands of U.S. troops deployed to deter further aggression by Saddam. The American forces were being bolstered by reservists from half a dozen states, who were packing their bags and preparing to report for duty. Teresa Mason, 21, of Columbus, Ga., shipping out for Saudi Arabia, said goodbye to her husband and 3-month-old baby. ``I wasn't real thrilled with the idea of her going over there, but when you have to go, you go,'' said her 23-year-old husband Joseph. The mobilization is expected to continue at least until Oct. 1. Bush has the authority to call up as many as 200,000 reserves for up to 180 days without declaring a national emergency. Oil ministers from most of the 13 nations making up the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to attend the talks in Vienna on Sunday, the cartel's headquarters, Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez said in Caracas. Oil prices helped set off the crisis. Saddam cited Kuwaiti overproduction that drove down prices and a land dispute as his reasons for the invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Resolution On Enforcement Of Embargo Against Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Following is the English language text of the Security Council resolution authorizing military action to halt all maritime trade with Iraq: The Security Council, Recalling its Resolutions 660 (1990), 661 (1990), 662 (1990) and 664 (1990) and demanding their full and immediate implementation; Having decided to impose sanctions in accordance with Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations; Determined to bring an end to the occupation of Kuwait by Iraq which imperils the existence of a member State and to restore the legitimate authority and the sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Kuwait which requires the speedy implementation of the above resolutions; Deploring the loss of innocent life stemming from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and determined to prevent further such losses; Gravely alarmed that Iraq continues to refuse to comply with Resolutions 660 (1990), 661 (1990), 662 (1990) and 664 (1990) and in particular at the conduct of the Government of Iraq in using Iraqi flag vessels to export oil; 1. Calls upon those member States cooperating with the Government of Kuwait which are deploying maritime forces to the area to use such measures commensurate to the specific circumstances as may be necessary under the authority of the Security Council to halt all inward and outward maritime shipping in order to inspect and verify their cargoes and destinations and to ensure strict implementation of the provisions related to such shipping laid down in (sanctions) Resolution 661 (1990); 2. Invites Member States accordingly to cooperate as may be necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of Resolution 661 (1990) with maximum use of political and diplomatic measures, in accordance with paragraph 1 above; 3. Requests all States to provide in accordance with the Charter such assistance as may be required by the States referred to in paragraph 1 of this resolution. 4. Further requests the States concerned to coordinate their actions in pursuit of the above paragraphs of this resolution using as appropriate mechanisms of the Military Staff Committee and after consultation with the Secretary-General to submit reports to the Security Council and its Committee established under Resolution 661 (1990) to facilitate the monitoring of the implementation of this resolution. 5. Decides to remain actively seized of the matter.

DOC.HEAD: People Spooked by Alleged Ghost in Disney Film
LaserPhoto SAN1
DOC.TEXT: Video stores have been besieged with requests for cassettes of ``Three Men and a Baby'' amid speculation that the ghost of a child lurks in a scene in the Disney film. ``Everybody who's walked into the store today wants this movie,'' said operations manager Ryan Bicknell of Music Plus in the Los Angeles suburb of Marina Del Rey. All the store's copies of the 1987 comedy about three bachelors who rear a baby were rented out Friday morning, he said. ``Three Men and a Baby'' already is the No. 1 rental in video history, according to Billboard magazine. Viewers have been transfixed by an eerie figure in a scene in which actor Ted Danson and Celeste Holm, co-starring as Danson's mother, walk by a window in a home shared by Danson and his buddies, played by Tom Selleck and Steve Guttenberg. Partially obscured in the window is the figure of what looks to many to be a young boy, seemingly hiding behind a curtain. ``I was never a firm believer in ghosts or anything, but I'll tell you the truth, it made the hair stand up on my arms,'' Jon Roup of Network Video in Pittsburgh said Friday. Callers from Milwaukee, Pittsburgh, Los Angeles, Utah and Vancouver, Canada, have inquired at Disney's video division about the scene for weeks, said Buena Vista Home Video spokesman Steve Feldstein. Popular Los Angeles radio station KLOS reported on the controversy Friday, setting off a rush for the video in this city. Feldstein said some viewers believe the figure is the ghost of a child who either died or committed suicide in a house where the film was shot. But he said the mysterious figure is actually a cardboard cutout or standee of a man in top hat and tails. It was part of the set dressing in the film that was made on a sound stage in Toronto, he said, not in anybody's house. ``It's a prop,'' he said of the standee, a promotional device for a role played by Danson. Some bought Disney's explanation. ``It doesn't look like a ghost,'' said sales rep Aaron Chu of Movies and More in West Los Angeles. ``There's no third dimension to the figure,'' he said, adding that it appeared to be the likeness of a young man. Yet many people believe something supernatural is going on. After all, ``Three Men'' was directed by Leonard Nimoy, the former host of ``In Search Of,'' a television show tracking strange phenomena. ``I put standups up all the time in here, and it isn't big enough,'' said Tony Hostler of Best Video Rentals in Pittsburgh. ``You can't make out the kid's face, and on a real standup they make sure you can. But you can make out the body real clear. ``I believe it's just some kind of freak of nature or something,'' he said. Roup said he and other employees at Network Video examined the footage carefully on a video machine with ``crystal-clear'' freeze frame. ``If you look at it, it's way too small to be Ted Danson. And it doesn't have any feet or anything,'' he said. As for Disney's explanation, he said, ``I think that's an excuse...they're saying (it) not to scare people.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Their actions have torn at the very fiber of our democratic form of government. This case crosses all political, racial and regional lines. Public corruption, we have learned, knows no such boundaries.'' _ U.S. Attorney Bart Daniel after five South Carolina lawmakers were indicted for selling their votes.

``It's kind of like having a date for the prom, stubbing your toe the night before, getting up the next morning and stubbing a toe on the other foot.'' _ Tommy Thompson, science and mission planning manager of Magellan, after the spacecraft malfunctioned and lost contact with Earth twice.

``Pennsylvanians would be well served if the Commonwealth accepts this decision and stops squandering taxpayers' money to promote government interference in personal matters and threaten women's lives.'' _ Elizabeth Hrenda-Roberts, executive director of Planned Parenthood Pennsylvania Affiliates, after a federal judge struck down provisions of the state's restrictive abortion law.

DOC.HEAD: Five Legislators Indicted On Corruption Charges
DOC.TEXT: A federal grand jury issued indictments against five state legislators accused of accepting bribes in exchange for their support for a bill legalizing betting on horses and greyhounds. A 16-month FBI sting operation led to the indictments issued on Friday. Prosecutors said they expect a federal grand jury to issue more anti-corruption charges against other state lawmakers over the next few months. ``This investigation is continuing,'' U.S. Attorney Bart Daniel said at a news conference. State Reps. Robert Kohn, Luther Taylor, Robert Brown, Danny Winstead and state Sen. Rick Lee were indicted under the Hobbs Act, a federal law banning acceptance of money or gifts in return for votes or favors. Winstead also was indicted on a second charge of obstruction of justice. ``The indictments, simply put, allege that each of these public officials sold their votes for cash,'' Daniel said. Conviction under the Hobbs Act carries a maximum penalty of 20 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Taylor, indicted on six counts, faces a maximum sentence of 120 years in prison and a $1.5 million fine if convicted. Winstead faces a total of 30 years in prison and a $500,000 fine if convicted on obstruction of justice. The five lawmakers either refused comment or did not return calls made to their homes and offices. In July, the campaign spending records of all 124 representatives and 46 senators were seized in the sting operation, code-named ``Operation Lost Trust.'' The sting employed a former House member-turned-lobbyist, Ron Cobb, and an undercover FBI agent who went by the name of Joe Williams. Cobb purported to represent The Alpha Group of Atlanta, which supported efforts to legalize parimutuel betting on horses and greyhounds in South Carolina. Without elaborating, Daniel said the sting began as a drug investigation. Daniel said the indicted legislators broke ``a sacred trust'' public officials hold. ``Their actions have torn at the very fiber of our democratic form of government,'' he said. ``This case crosses all political, racial and regional lines. Public corruption, we have learned, knows no such boundaries.''

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Ruling Sets Appeals Process in Motion
DOC.TEXT: A judge's rejection of provisions in Pennsylvania's restrictive abortion law provides a chance for the Supreme Court to review its 1973 decision in Roe vs. Wade that legalized abortion, both sides in the case said. Senior U.S. District Judge Daniel H. Huyett struck down provisions in the 1982 state law, saying much of it was just a repeat of provisions previously ruled unconstitutional. The state said it would appeal to the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals and, if necessary, to the Supreme Court. ``If the (Supreme) court is looking to overturn Roe v. Wade, this case provides an opportunity to do that,'' said Linda Wharton of the Women's Law Project, an attorney for the plaintiffs in the case. ``Everything is happening the way we thought it would happen,'' said Republican Rep. Stephen Freind, the leading anti-abortion voice in the Legislature. ``No doubt we are going to win in the Supreme Court.'' In 1986, the Supreme Court declared unconstitutional much of Pennsylvania's Abortion Control Act. The Legislature amended the act in 1988 and 1989, but Huyett called the new law ``nothing more than a reenactment'' of the old one. In his 191-page ruling, Huyett said women's rights are being ``subjected to the vicissitudes of the legislative process.'' The U.S. territory of Guam had banned all abortions except where the mother's life is threatened. A federal judge on Thursday ruled that law unconstitutional. The Guam ruling is the only other potential challenge to Roe vs. Wade ``in the pipeline,'' Wharton said. Planned Parenthood of Southeastern Pennsylvania and five abortion providers challenged the amendments. The judge's ruling stops the state from enforcing them. ``Safe, legal abortion continues to be accessible to women in Pennsyvlania because of the court's decision today,'' said Elizabeth Hrenda-Roberts, executive director of Planned Parenthood Pennsylvania Affiliates. ``Pennsylvanians would be well-served if the Commonwealth accepts this decision and stops squandering taxpayers' money to promote government interference in personal matters and threaten women's lives,'' she said. An appeal could be heard sometime next year, and could reach the Supreme Court in 1992, Wharton said. Robert Gentzel, spokesman for Attorney General Ernie Preate Jr. said Friday's ruling was ``disappointing but not unexpected.'' Huyett ruled against Pennsylvania's requirements that a woman notify her husband before getting an abortion; wait 24 hours before getting an abortion; and that minors obtain the consent of at least one parent, or a court order, before an abortion. The judge upheld a provision allowing the state to collect data from doctors and clinics on abortions performed as long as it was kept confidential. He also upheld a section requiring a test to determine the age of the fetus.

DOC.HEAD: Retired Judge Returns to Courtroom as Juror
DOC.TEXT: A Superior Court judge who retired in February returned to the courtroom to hear evidence in a murder case _ but this time as a juror. During jury selection Thursday, Martin L. Haines, 70, described himself as a ``struggling journalist.'' Since retiring from the bench, he has been writing for the New Jersey Law Journal. First assistant county prosecutor Michael E. Riley and defense attorney Jorge C. Godoy said they did not consider moving to strike Haines as a potential juror. Haines was one of two judges named ``most competent'' in a 1989 survey of court officials carried out by the New Jersey Law Journal. His opinions were considered among the most influential handed down by the Superior Court during his tenure on the bench. The jury began hearing evidence Friday in the trial of Lee Roy Foxx, 56, of Burlington City, who is charged with shooting to death William Orange, 59, of Willingboro, in March. Haines wasn't the only juror in the case with legal connections. Another juror is an attorney.

DOC.HEAD: Tamil Rebels Thwart Government Advance Across Lagoon
DOC.TEXT: Tamil separatist rebels have thwarted the army's efforts to cross a heavily mined causeway and enter the guerrillas' chief stronghold in the far northern city of Jaffna, military officials said today. For the past three days the Tamil Tiger guerrillas, entrenched in bunkers on a small island in the Jaffna lagoon, have prevented government forces from reaching Mandativu Island, officials said. The island is a key stepping stone in an arc of islands facing Jaffna town. Officials denied that the army, which landed Wednesday on nearby Kayts Island, had bogged down in its latest offensive against the Tigers. But they acknowledged their attempts to break the Tiger siege had slowed. The officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, claimed at least 170 Tigers have died since the offensive began Wednesday to crush the rebels in their Jaffna Peninsula stronghold. Troops also hoped to rescue a government garrison under siege for more than two months in Jaffna Fort. The causeway leads from Kayts Island to Mandativu Island and on to the 17th century, star-shaped fort 4 miles away. Most of the rebels were killed by helicopter gunships strafing boats and jungle roads, they said. They claimed only four soldiers have been killed and 16 wounded in the 4-day-old offensive. Government troops landed Wednesday on Kayts Island. The following day, Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne, chief architect of the war effort, predicted they would reach the fort in two or three days. The Tigers, in statements issued in London and Geneva, claim to have killed ``a large number'' of government troops. They denied the government had inflicted heavy losses, charging instead that 300 civilians died in government aerial bombing and strafing and troops' gunfire. No independent reports of the situation in Jaffna Peninsula, home to 850,000 people, have emerged. Communications with the peninsula, 185 miles northeast of Colombo, were severed after June 11. On that date, the Tigers broke a 13-month cease-fire and attacked government police stations and army camps. The combatants use radios to communicate with colleagues outside the peninsula. The government claims 5,000 people have died in the past 10 weeks in northern and eastern Sri Lanka, bringing to 14,000 the death toll since the Tamil insurrection began in 1983. The Tamil Tigers are fighting for a separatist homeland for their ethnic minority, which has long accused the Sinhalese majority of discrimination in jobs and education. Tamils comprise 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. They predominate in the north, while the east is about equally divided among Sinhalese, Tamils and Moslems. Fighting has tapered off in the east, where the government is concentrated in the towns and the Tigers have retreated to the jungles. Sinhalese, who make up 75 percent of the population, have controlled the government and military since the Indian Ocean island became independent from Britain in 1949.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in Northeast; Fog and Cloud Covers East and Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Rain lingered in parts on the Northeast today, and fog or low clouds covered much of the East and the nation's midsection during the morning. Low pressure was expected to bring rain from southern Maine to North Carolina today. Except for thunderstorms in Florida, sunny skies and temperatures in the 90s were expected in the rest of the region. Hot summer weather was predicted for the South, Midwest and Southwest. A large storm system was forming over the Pacific Northwest, with showers extending from Montana to Northern California. Highs in the 80s were expected for areas with rain, while the rest of the country was looking for temperatures in the 90s and 100s. In northern Texas, temperatures were expected to climb to 110 degrees with lows around 80. But showers over Northern California could include snow in the higher elevations of the Sierra Nevada. The high temperature for the nation Friday was 106 degrees in Phoenix and Bullhead City, Ariz. DOC.HEAD: Anonymous Kidnapper Releases Iguana
DOC.TEXT: An anonymous midnight caller told deputies where they could find the bundled kidnap victim. Unhurt and in good spirits was Iggy, a 3-foot-long iguana nabbed from his pen at Upper Tampa Bay Park. The pen was found empty Wednesday morning, and its door bolt was broken. Authorities don't know who took him, but park ranger Joe Humble speculated the 40-pound lizard could have been put up for sale. Iguanas are worth up to $200 on the black market, and it's not uncommon for the lizards to be stolen and sold to pet stores, he said. The iguana-nappers might have become scared and decided to return Iggy Thursday night after the theft was reported, Humble said. ``A lot of people know Iggy,'' the park ranger said. ``He's kind of a celebrity. We take him around to local schools and use him to teach kids about exotic wildlife.''

DOC.HEAD: 22 Soldiers in Kashmir-bound Convoy Killed in Mountain Accident
DOC.TEXT: A truck in a Kashmir-bound army convoy skidded off a mountain road and plunged 1,500 feet into a river, killing at least 22 soldiers, a police official said today. The crash occurred late Friday on the road linking Jammu and Srinagar. Five injured soldiers were rescued, deputy inspector general Gopal Sharma said. The truck was thought to be carrying about 40 soldiers, and the search for more victims was continuing, he said. The crash occurred near Ramban, about 45 miles northeast of Jammu, on a winding section of road hewn from the mountainside above the Chenab River. Sharma said the truck skidded out of control and plunged off the mountain. Heavy military contingents are deployed in Kashmir in an effort to quell a separatist revolt by Moslems. Additional troops were deployed recently after clashes between Indian and Pakistani troops along the disputed Kashmir frontier.

DOC.HEAD: Irish Academic Traded Violence of Belfast For War In Beirut
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to remove `reportedly'; Pickup 6th, `American educator...'; Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Irishman Brian Keenan, who spent most of his life in strife-torn Belfast, dismissed the dangers of Beirut when he went there to teach English in 1986. ``There's a war there. There's a war here at home and life has to go on,'' his sisters remember him saying. For four months, Keenan taught at the American University in Beirut, writing home about the beauty of Lebanon and the fine cuisine and nightlife in Beirut. On April 11, 1986, he rushed out of his apartment, late for an 8 a.m. lecture, and was abducted by gunmen. No group had claimed responsibility for kidnapping Keenan, but a previously unknown group called the Organization of the Islamic Dawn announced he would be freed Friday. American educator Frank Reed, who was freed on April 30, said he spent almost three years with Keenan and British journalist John McCarthy _ either in the same room or the same house _ and had seen them two days before his release. For at least part of the time, they were blindfolded and chained to radiators. Keenan and McCarthy, who became like ``blood brothers,'' exercising daily and reading voraciously, Reed said. They kept each other's spirits high and Keenan had used his Irish gift for storytelling to relate anecdotes lasting more than an hour, Reed said. The Organization of the Islamic Dawn is believed part of Hezbollah, or Party of God, a Shiite fundamentalist umbrella organization whose factions hold most of the 13 Western captives in Lebanon. Keenan's sisters, Brenda Gillham and Elaine Spence, said their brother's mistake was to forget his Irish passport when he left his apartment. They believe his kidnappers thought he was American or British, rather than a citizen of a small neutral country. Although born in Northern Ireland, which is part of Britain, Keenan decided about 15 years ago to adopt Irish citizenship, his sisters said. Any Northern Irelander is entitled to dual Irish and British citizenship. But Keenan's choice was unusual since he is Protestant, and most Protestants identify with Britain rather than the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Irish Republic. Even though Keenan only has an Irish passport, he has never renounced British citizenship, so both Britain and Ireland had worked for his release. Keenan was dubbed Britain's ``forgotten'' hostage because his plight did not receive the same publicity as that of Anglican Church Envoy Terry Waite and McCarthy. After two years of campaigning for his release, Mrs. Gillham said: ``The trouble is nobody seems to want to know. We have not had much help. We wrote to some MPs (members of Parliament) but only one replied.'' Keenan never joined a political party, but his sisters said he believes fervently in the non-violent unification of Ireland. With great affection, Mrs. Gillham and Mrs. Spence describe their bachelor brother as somewhat eccentric _ a scruffy, impulsive, artistic man who gets around Belfast on an old bicycle, loves poetry, Irish culture, conversation and his dog, which is with his mother Minnie in east Belfast. The dog's name is Saiorse _ the Irish word for freedom. When Keenan was born on Sept. 20, 1950, Northern Ireland was still relatively conflict-free. But by the time he graduated from Orangefield Boys Secondary School near his home in mainly Protestant east Belfast in 1970, the province was in the throes of sectarian rioting, the British army had arrived, and the Irish Republican Army was being resurrected. Keenan graduated from the New University of Ulster at Coleraine near Londonderry in 1974 with a bachelor's degree in English, and spent the following year in San Sebastian, Spain, working as an English tutor. In 1975 he returned to his old school, Orangefield, and spent two years teaching English and coaching rugby. From 1977 to 1984, as sectarian and political strife continued, Belfast City Council employed him as a community worker, dealing with Protestants and Catholics, young and old. ``He tried to build communication on both sides,'' Mrs. Gillham said. ``He loved his country.'' He also pursued his graduate studies, receiving a post-graduate certificate in community studies from Aberdeen University in 1978, a master's degree from the New University at Coleraine in Anglo-Irish literature in 1984 and a doctorate in English literature from the New University's Magee College in 1985. Later that year he left for Beirut.

DOC.HEAD: Judas Priest Cleared of Liability in Suicides of Two Fans
DOC.TEXT: The lead vocalist of the British rock band Judas Priest says the heavy metal group is ready to get back to work after being cleared by a judge from liability in the death of two young fans. ``Our immediate reaction is obviously one of great relief,'' Rob Halford said Friday. ``It's a great day for Judas Priest.'' In a telephone interview from from Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, Halford said he and his fellow band members ``simply just want to get on with what we do, playing rock 'n' roll and heavy metal music.'' Earlier Friday, Washoe District Judge Jerry Carr Whitehead ruled that subliminal messages exist on the band's 1978 ``Stained Class'' album, but they were not intentional and did not cause the two youths to form a suicide pact, as their families charged in a lawsuit. He said the words ``do it'' on the song ``Better By You, Better Than Me'' were a ``chance combination of sounds.'' Raymond Belknap, 18, died from a single blast from a shotgun held in his mouth two days before Christmas 1985. James Vance, then 20, blew away the lower portion of his face the same day but lived until November 1988. The families of the two victims sued the band and CBS records, claiming messages hidden in Judas Priest's song touted Satanism and promoted suicide. They had sought $6.2 million in damages. Ken McKenna, a lawyer for Belknap's family, predicted the judge's finding of subliminal content will open the way for similar lawsuits. ``This finding, although not a victory, certainly gives hope to attorneys pursing similar cases in the future,'' he said. Defense lawyer Suellen Fulstone agreed, saying she was pleased with the result but adding: ``The judge is certainly more open to the possibility of subliminal communication than I think the scientific evidence warrants. I don't think this will be the end of cases alleging such effects.'' The defense maintained during the four-week trial that what sounded like ``do it'' was actually Halford exhaling combined with the sound of guitars. The judge agreed reluctantly, saying that a listener probably would not have perceived such phrases in the record ``without the power of suggestion.'' In a small victory for the plaintiffs, Whitehead ordered co-defendant CBS Records to pay $40,000 to their. He said the company refused to find the original multitrack recordings of other songs on the ``Stained Class'' album. He said the defaults were not caused by the courtroom lawyers, but by in-house counsel of CBS. The judge added that even if the master tapes had been found, ``the court does not believe that the ultimate outcome of the trial would have been any different.''

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Approves First Military Action Enforcing Embargo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Iraq, Cuban, China comment, more Pickering quotes. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY25,6,7,LaserColor NY125
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council today overwhelmingly authorized military action to enforce its trade embargo against Iraq, in an unprecedented step meant to force Saddam Hussein's troops to pull out of Kuwait. Approval came after the Soviet Union on Friday dropped its opposition to the U.S.-backed resolution. As one of the five permanent members of the Security Council, the Soviets have veto power. It was the first time in its 45-year history that the council had authorized such military action to enforce its own sanctions _ a sweeping economic embargo against Iraq. Iraq's envoy condemned the council action as illegal and warned that acting on it could lead to all-out war. ``This use of force by the United States or any of its allies or puppets will lead inevitably to a number of explosions which will burn all in their path,'' said Iraqi Ambassador Abdul Amir Al-Anbari. U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering hailed the decision. ``Iraq has evaded resolutions of the Security Council and thumbed its nose at all humanity,'' he said. ``This has prompted the council to take one of the most important decisions in its history.'' The vote early today was 13-0 with two abstentions, from Cuba and Yemen, after informal meetings through the night. Yemen's ambassador, Abdallah Saleh Al-Ashtal, warned that any military action backing the sanctions might lead to war, while Cuban Ambassador Ricardo Alarcon said the council's move was in defiance of the U.N. charter. The vote gave Security Council blessing to a loose military arrangement, without a U.N. flag or command, whereby navies in the region could take unspecified steps to enforce the U.N. embargo. Today's resolution calls on countries deploying warships in the Persian Gulf region ``to use such measures commensurate to the specific circumstances as may be necessary under the authority of the Security Council to halt all inward and outward maritime shipping'' in order to implement the embargo. Language calling for ``minimum force'' was dropped Friday at the insistence of the Soviet Union and other nations, but diplomats emphasized that the vague language adopted clearly did not exclude the use of military might. ``It is sufficiently broad as to allow the use of force,'' Pickering said of the measure. ``This is not an act of war,'' he added, ``but an enforcement of sanctions which have been flagrantly violated.'' The sanctions against Iraq were ordered by the United Nations on Aug. 6 to punish Iraq for invading Kuwait on Aug. 2 and later annexing it. Most countries have cut off trade with Iraq, whose main export is oil. But but some Iraqi ships have gotten around the embargo, Pickering said. Jordan has allowed trucks to transport supplies into neighboring Iraq from ships that unload at the Jordanian port of Aqaba. It was not immediately clear what effect the resolution would have on those shipments, as they have been difficult to differentiate from Jordanian imports. The resolution covers only maritime shipping and not airlifts to Iraq. It was the fifth in a series of strong council resolutions since Iraq invaded Kuwait. Other resolutions have condemned the invasion and demanded immediate and unconditional withdrawal; imposed sweeping economic sanctions against Iraq; declared the annexation of Kuwait to be null and void; and demanded the immediate release of all foreigners held against their will. There is no precise precedent for such U.N. authorization of military action. In 1950 in the Korean conflict, it approved an international force under a U.N. flag and a U.S. command. British Ambassador Crispin Tickell said the latest move was ``the result of mounting evidence of breaches of sanctions on a large scale. There is a string of tankers carrying Iraqi oil from Iraqi ports going outward.'' He said the resolution ``shows a new spirit and creative approach of the international community to deal with an unprecedented crisis.'' The confirmation of Soviet support by Ambassador Valentin V. Lozinskiy on Friday removed the final major hurdle to Security Council approval of the U.S. initiative. For about 10 days the Soviets had balked. But Lozinskiy emphasized that use of any force should be the ``last resort.'' He said political and diplomatic efforts should come first in defusing the crisis precipitated by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Chinese Ambassador Li Daoyu said his government is also opposed in principle to military involvement by big powers and is ``not in favor of using force in the name of the United Nations.'' He said China had argued to delete the reference to ``use of force'' from the amended resolution. On Friday, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev sent an urgent message to Saddam that urged him to obey U.N. resolutions or face ``corresponding additional measures.'' President Bush had said he wanted the Security Council's endorsement of the use of force to halt Iraq's shipping. But he also said the United States already had the right to enforce the U.N. trade sanctions against Iraq. The five permanent council members are the United States, Britain, China, France and the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: African Force Reportedly Lands in Liberia
DOC.TEXT: A multinational African force sent to Liberia to end its civil war landed safely in the port city of Monrovia and met no resistance from government or rebel soldiers, a news agency reported. The landing occurred Friday night, the News Agency of Nigeria said. The report, monitored in Abidjan, said Nigeria's naval headquarters was in touch with the 3,000 troops sent to Liberia aboard six ships. Earlier Friday, gunfire in Monrovia had kept troops from the five West African states from landing, delaying their attempt to end Liberia's 8-month-old civil war, which has killed more than 5,000 people, mostly civilians. Charles Taylor, a leader of one of two Liberian rebel groups, has threatened to fight the multinational task force, saying their announced intention to stop the fighting is a ploy to keep President Samuel Doe in power. Taylor's National Patriotic Front has about 10,000 fighters and is stronger than either Doe's forces or those of Prince Johnson, a leader of a rebel faction that has grown hostile to the Taylor's group. The port of Monrovia is controlled by Johnson's forces who also hold most of the capital city. Johnson's forces and troops loyal to Doe declared a truce Monday, and said they would welcome the West African intervention. They also said they were ready to join forces to resist any attacks by Taylor. Taylor said through his chief spokesman, Tom Woewiyu, that the soldiers of the task force will be regarded as the ``enemy and we will shoot at them.'' Taylor's forces control most of the country outside the capital. Fighting has raged in Monrovia since late June. Taylor led his forces into Liberia from Ivory Coast on Dec. 24, saying Doe's government was corrupt and that he wanted to oust it. Johnson later split with Taylor. West African leaders decided to intervene on Aug. 6. They said the war was no longer an internal conflict because thousands of their citizens were trapped in Liberia and 400,000 Liberian refugees were burdening neighboring countries. The task force's chief of staff, Brig. Cyril Igwueze of Nigeria, said on Nigerian state television Thursday that the West African troops have no desire to shoot their way into Monrovia. But he also warned, ``We are able and willing to defend ourselves if attacked.'' Troops from Ghana, Nigeria, Sierra Leone, Gambia and Guinea are in the force. Togo said it would send troops but did not. U.S. forces stationed on a warship off Liberia's coast have evacuated U.S. citizens and residents of other countries trapped by the fighting. The U.S. Marines have also landed in Liberia to defend the U.S. Embassy compound.

DOC.HEAD: New Tropical Depression Joins Storm Gustav
DOC.TEXT: Tropical storm Gustav headed west toward the Lesser Antilles today as another tropical depression strengthened in the eastern Atlantic, forecasters said. Gustav, the seventh named tropical storm of the 1990 Atlantic hurricane season, was headed west at 13 mph with top sustained winds of about 45 mph, said hurricane specialist Hal Gerrish of the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. At 6 a.m. EDT, Gustav was centered near latitude 13.6 north, longitude 50.6 west about 690 miles east of the Lesser Antilles. It was expected to maintain that motion through today and gain strength, Gerrish said. The depression, ninth of the season, formed about 10:30 p.m. EDT Friday, said hurricane specialist Lixion Avila. ``It looks like it's becoming better organized, and we think it could become (Tropical Storm) Hortense before the end of the day,'' he said. At 6 a.m. EDT, the depression was located near latitude 12.5 north, longitude 37.2 west, about 850 miles west southwest of the Cape Verde Islands. It was moving west with maximum sustained winds of 35 mph and was expected to maintain that motion today, said hurricane specialist Max Mayfield. It would become a tropical storm if wind speed increased to 39 mph. The Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 to Nov. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Austrian President Meets with Saddam
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Kurt Waldheim of Austria met today with Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein on the fate of thousands of foreigners held in Iraq, an Austrian diplomat said. Waldheim, the first Western leader to meet with Saddam since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2, arrived aboard an Iraqi presidential plane, accompanied by his foreign minister, Alois Mock, and other Austrian officials, according to diplomats, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Saddam and other senior Iraqi officials greeted Waldheim at the Baghdad airport, they said. An Austrian diplomat said Waldheim was expected to use his friendship with Saddam to raise the issue of the 21,000 Westerners, including more than 70 Austrians and 3,000 Americans, stranded in Iraq and Kuwait. Waldheim became acquainted with Arab leaders during his 10 years as United Nations secretary-general. He has been shunned by Western leaders in recent years since it was disclosed that during World War II Waldheim served with a German army unit in the Balkans implicated in atrocities, and later misrepresented his war record. In Vienna, Austrian radio said Saddam held an impromptu news conference for Austrian reporters accompanying Waldheim before the talks started. Saddam had not talked with Western reporters since the crisis began. The radio quoted Saddam as saying that Iraqi troops don't plan to withdraw from Kuwait, and confirming that foreigners have been brought to strategic points, including missile bases and oil refineries. ``This is not done to protect Iraq against the U.S. but to protect the foreigners,'' the radio quoted Saddam as saying. The radio quoted Saddam as saying the United States had occupied Saudi Arabia and other holy places of Islam and the ``Arab world condemns this.'' He termed the Western military action ``a naked aggression,'' the phrase Westerners applied to his invasion of Kuwait. ``The leadership of Saudi Arabia is corrupt,'' Saddam reportedly said. But he said Iraq respects the sovereignty of every Arab country and would not attack Saudi Arabia. The radio quoted Saddam as saying Iraq also respected the sovereignty of Kuwait, ``but the corrupt regime there made a conspiracy against its motherland.'' He said he was happy about the visit of Waldheim, whom he described as ``an especially fair politician who could mediate.'' The Austrian president arrived from Amman, Jordan. Austria's ambassador to Amman, Franz Pernegger, told The Associated Press that Waldheim was not accompanied by Jordan's King Hussein. Earlier, it was believed that the king also might attend the meeting with Saddam. Waldheim told reporters Friday in Amman that he would discuss ``humanitarian issues'' with Saddam.

DOC.HEAD: Jordan, Turkey Getting Relief from Crush of Refugees
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jordan and Turkey kept their borders with Iraq open today to a diminishing flood of mostly Arab refugees as Saudis and Europeans moved to help with money and supplies. Of 205,000 evacuees who crossed into Jordan in the past 18 days, only 35,000 remain, mostly Arabs and Asians, said Salameh Hammad, interior ministry undersecretary. Jordan has been allowing in 20,000 refugees a day. A senior Jordanian security official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said ``a much fewer number of people are crossing my borders now and we were told by Iraqi authorities that the number of people on their borders is in the hundreds.'' He said authorities were transporting away 7,000 people stranded for two days at the Ruweishid border post, 210 miles northeast of Amman. The Jordanian security official also said 5,000 foreigners were at the Iraqi border post of Rutbah, 75 miles west of Ruweishid, awaiting entry to Jordan. The refugees reached Rutbah, 590 miles west of Baghdad, after grueling desert treks that left them in need of food, water and whatever personal items they were not able to bring along. Saudi Arabia's King Fahd ordered six planes to assist the Egyptian airlift of its nationals reaching Jordan, according to state-run Riyadh radio. Saudi Arabia also is sending $75 million to help Egyptian authorities resettle the workers who fled Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. The European Community earlier this week said it gave Jordan $1.3 million to help it deal with refugees. Spain said today it planned to send a transport plane bearing medicine, food, blankets and tents to Jordan on Monday. Jordan had announced Wednesday it would close its border with Iraq, saying it could not handle the financial strain of coping with tens of thousands of refugees. But Amman announced Friday it was officially reopening its borders _ which had never really closed _ and it asked the United Nations for emergency assistance. Turkish Premier Yildirim Akbulut warned Friday that his nation faces similar problems and might have to close its border post where more than 4,500 foreigners have crossed from Iraq. Some 21,000 Westerners, including 3,000 Americans and 4,500 Britons are stranded in Iraq and Kuwait. They have been barred from leaving Iraq by President Saddam Hussein, who is using some of them as human shields at potential military targets. In Thailand, the Bangkok Post reported today that the Palestine Liberation Organization offered to assemble bus convoys and escort 250 Thai workers a day from Kuwait. The PLO has been seeking official recognition from Thailand, and about 3,500 Thai workers remain in Kuwait, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: European Government Hail U.N. Security Council Vote
With PM-UN-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with British, French, Greek reaction, edit for transition. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `Juan Lena...'
DOC.TEXT: Several European governments today joined the United States in welcoming the United Nations Security Council resolution authorizing military enforcement of the economic embargo against Iraq. The resolution, adopted 13-0 with Cuba and Yemen abstaining, called on all countries deploying maritime forces in the Persian Gulf region to use ``such measures commensurate with the specific circumstances as may be necessary'' to end commerce with Iraq. The French Foreign Ministry called the measure ``a very important act which is testimony to the international community's firmness and solidarity,'' and said French forces would apply the resolution ``with the necessary resolve.'' Though France was coordinating with other countries on the placement of forces, ``each force remains under national control and master of its mission,'' the Foreign Ministry said in a statement. Britain refused to say immediately what force British vessels would use to back up the embargo. ``We will use, obviously, the minimum force necessary,'' William Waldegrave, the second-ranking official in Britain's Foreign Office, told a news conference. He hailed the passage of the resolution. ``It is important that, contrary to what some people might have expected _ I think what Saddam Hussein expected _ the unity of the international community is not fraying, it is actually getting more close as time goes on,'' Waldegrave said. The White House said today the resolution ``further strengthens the world resolve to force Iraq out of Kuwait.'' Greek government spokesman Vyron Polydoras called the Security Council decision ``an act of historic significance and a landmark in the further course of international relations.'' ``It demonstrates the will of the international community to serve justice and ethics,'' he said in a statment. Greece has said that it will send a frigate to join the multinational armada but has not said when it will sail or what its mission will be. Danish Foreign Minister Uffe Ellemann-Jensen said the Security Council move ``is so fine that I almost don't know how to express it.'' He said his country is now prepared to contribute a corvette and a supply ship to the forces in the gulf, subject to parliamentary approval. ``With the historic U.N. resolution we now have a clear basis to participate actively in the multinational blockade of Iraq,'' Ellemann-Jensen said in an interview with Danish public radio. Juan Lena, spokesman for the Spanish Foreign Ministry, said in a statement that the Security Council vote ``coincides with the Spanish posture since the start of the Persian Gulf crisis in seeking to provide effective enforcement of the U.N. embargo against Iraq within the framework of the United Nations.'' Dutch Foreign Minister Hans van den Broek said the resolution would discourage would-be breakers of the embargo, ``because now they are going to run a certain risk.'' ``Navy ships in the area will not any longer be condemned to strict passivity when freight ships refuse to divulge their cargo,'' van den Broek said in an interview on Dutch radio.

DOC.HEAD: Police Jail Backers of Ousted Prime Minister Bhutto
DOC.TEXT: Police said Saturday they arrested 60 supporters of ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto and raided her party's suburban headquarters. Ms. Bhutto claimed the arrests were aimed at manipulating general elections scheduled for Oct. 24. ``Such unwarranted action . . . is designed to openly create a state of panic and thereby pave the way for rigging of the coming elections,'' Ms. Bhutto said in a statement. On Aug. 6, President Ghulam Ishaq Khan dismissed Ms. Bhutto's 20-month-old government on charges of corruption, nepotism and ineptitude. Ishaq Khan said Ms. Bhutto had been unable to curb ethnic and political violence that has caused at least 500 deaths since May in Sindh, her home province and political power base. The arrests were in connection with a shooting spree Wednesday in Karachi that killed 30 people and injured dozens more. The victims were members of the refugee people's movement, representing Indian immigrants who came to Pakistan after it gained independence from British India in 1947. Police said marauding gunmen opened fire on brightly colored booths set up throughout the city to welcome the movement's returning leader, Altaf Hussein. He had been receiving several months of medical treatment in London for a kidney ailment.

DOC.HEAD: 2 Killed, 3 Injured in Canyon Shooting Near Boulder; Suspect Captured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with capture of suspect. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `The five...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BLD1
DOC.TEXT: An escaped convict suspected in four slayings, including an attack on a group of target shooters that killed two, was wounded and captured early today after an extensive manhunt, authorities said. Michael G. Bell was shot in the neck as he ran from a bar and attempted to escape in a car, said Boulder sheriff's Lt. Joe Gang. Officers who had been tipped off were waiting in the car. He was taken to Boulder Community Hospital, where he was in serious condition, a nursing supervisor said. Bell, 36, escaped from the Four Mile Correctional Center in Canon City on Aug. 5. He is suspected of being the man who rounded up five men as they practiced target shooting in the mountains Friday, and then opened fire. Two men were killed and a third seriously injured. Bell also is being sought for questioning in the fatal shootings of a 36-year-old transient on Tuesday in Boulder Canyon and a 20-year-old convenience store clerk in Broomfield on Aug. 15, Gang said. After Friday's attack, roadblocks were set up in Boulder and on roads throughout the pine-covered mountains and steep canyons northwest of the city. It was described as Boulder County's largest manhunt in 15 years. Authorities said Bell contacted someone he knew and asked the person to provide a car so he could escape. Instead, Gang said, the person tipped off authorities. When Bell arrived at the Boulder City Limits, a bar, deputies were waiting in the car he planned to take. Identities of the two men killed Friday were withheld pending notification of relatives. The wounded were Timothy Bendel, described as in his 20s, who was shot in the head and was listed in serious condition at Boulder Community Hospital, and Michael Victor, 22, was treated and released after a bullet grazed his head, hospital official said. Matthew Hickey, 19, who fell while trying to escape the shootings, was treated for a knee injury and released, said Assistant Boulder County Sheriff Dave Voorhis. The five men were in an area of the mountains used for target shooting and motorcycle riding when the shooter drove up in a blue car and represented himself as an off-duty park ranger, Voorhis said. He took the serial numbers of the victims' weapons and began to march them back down to a road, Voorhis said. ``As the five were going down to the road he began shooting them,'' he said. The car, which was stolen near Canon City on Aug. 6, was found abandoned in Boulder later Friday. Spokeswoman Liz McDonough of the state Department of Corrections said Bell, 36, was admitted to the state prison system in 1988 and was serving a 12-year sentence for check fraud and theft. She said Bell had an Illinois prison record, including for attempted murder in 1972.

DOC.HEAD: Summer of Shortages Brings a Difficult Fall
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: For much of the summer, two dozen cardboard shacks draped in plastic have sheltered a small squatter community a stone's throw from the magnificent gold-tipped domes of Red Square. Not long ago, police would have smashed the shacks and dragged the occupants away. Today, policemen protect the squatters from the occasional angry worker who wants to evict them from their grassy lot outside the Hotel Rossiya. So the squatters wait, as everyone here must for one thing or another. They sit with their hand-scrawled paper signs about grievances against the government, former employers, the Communist Party. As summer slid into autumn, bringing a cold rain, the ink of their printed plaints ran and smeared. ``We are here today,'' one sign says. ``You will be here tomorrow. We are all deprived of our rights in the U.S.S.R. Down with Communist slavery.'' Like everyone else, they wait to see what the government will do next. It has been a long summer of waiting: for consumer goods, for the government to prepare a new plan for a market economy, for yet another explosion of protest. The list of things people must wait for seems to grow as rapidly as the line that forms in the rain for a rare opportunity to buy German shoes. Drivers carry empty cans in their cars to fill when they find gasoline. Frustrated smokers block traffic in Moscow and other cities to protest a cigarette shortage. Ice cream kiosks close because there is none to sell. Even bread, traditionally abundant and just a few cents a loaf, is so scarce that rationing was introduced in Tarusa, south of Moscow. A riot broke out in Chelyabinsk, Siberia, after an angry crowd had demanded vodka and meat. Some things are plentiful. Old women sell freshly cut red, white and pink carnations outside nearly every subway station. Just in time for fall, while parents hunt for scarce school notebooks, inflatable beach toys fill the shelves of Detsky Mir, the huge children's department store. At tables inside subway stations, vendors sell posters featuring everything from pictures of the last czar to a topless woman putting a saddle on a horse. There's a bumper grain crop this year, but the fuel shortage hampers the harvest and tons of wheat may rot in the fields. Crime is increasing. Some tourists report their hotel rooms looted. Black marketeers hawk car parts, cigarettes and other goods on Moscow's ring road on Saturday nights. Newspapers are filled with reports of violent crimes, including rumors of a ``Jack the Ripper'' on the loose in Moscow. Two things are in great supply: anxiety and pessimism. Many people agree the Soviet Union must adopt a market economy, but worry about replacing a bad system with one that may be worse. Sergei Borinov, a 19-year-old college student, says he is not convinced the goverment can cure the shortages and the ailing economy. ``Lawmakers have visited shops several times to check the situation in the stores, and nothing ever changes,'' said Borinov, one of those who blocked traffic last week to protest cigarette shortages. ``I am indignant about such an attitude, and about just what is going on in our country.'' Two commissions, one appointed jointly by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his chief rival, Boris N. Yeltsin, and the other run by Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, are considering how to make the switch to a market system. Yeltsin, president of the Russian federation, says it should be done in 500 days. Gorbachev wants to go slower, lessening the shock of price increases. Yeltsin has accused Ryzhkov's government of sabotaging the reform effort by not divulging basic economic data, and has said the Russian federation will ogo its own way if the Ryzhkov plan is presented to the national parliament, scheduled to convene Sept. 3. Russia, largest of the 15 Soviet republics, is one of a dozen republics seeking to set their own courses, either through independence or a lesser form of autonomy. The separatist movements are related to the process of disintegration illustrated by the cardboard village near the Kremlin walls, where dozens of protesters clamor for the attention of the Soviet leadership. They have elected an unofficial mayor to coordinate their demands. Authorities have made no move to evict them. A policeman who spends eight hours a day keeping track of them was asked how long they would be allowed to stay. ``It depends on how fast their problems are solved,'' Lt. Sergei Petrykin said. ``The country has a lot of problems, and these are priorities.
