When the country resolves its own problems, it will be easier to deal with the individual problems of these people.'' In the meantime, he said, ``these people are just torturing themselves.''

DOC.HEAD: World Leaders Glued to TV as Crisis Unfolds on Cable Network
With AM-Walter Mears Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Turgut Ozal of Turkey tells of glancing at the television screen just in time to see and hear President Bush saying he was about to call him up. The Turkish president walked into his office and picked up the ringing telephone. It was Bush. That's the way it often is in the Persian Gulf confrontation. Cable News Network's constant, live broadcasts from scenes of crisis and diplomacy lets leaders a world apart look over one another's shoulders as events unfold. In another era, information on crisis situations moved to diplomats and warriors over secret, coded, back channels. The world knew only what these movers and shakers wanted known. The Gulf crisis is broadcast around the world in color, often live, 24 hours a day on CNN. Among the most avid watchers are the world leaders who make the news, including Britain's Margaret Thatcher, France's Francois Mitterrand, Libya's Moammar Gadhafi and King Fahd of Saudi Arabia. CNN staffers in Washington are reminded of this by a photograph tacked to their bulletin board. It shows President Bush and his top advisers watching an Iraqi newscast, the CNN logo prominent in one corner. ABC's Ted Koppel, broadcasting from Baghdad, paid a rival the ultimate compliment by saying that the Iraqi foreign ministry was following events by watching CNN. And Turkey's Ozal, a key player, says he has kept his television tuned to CNN since Iraq troops crossed into Kuwait Aug. 2. An Associated Press reporter arriving for an interview recently found the president chuckling over a brawl between the New York Mets and Philadelphia Phillies. Each morning, Iraqi television sends CNN's Atlanta headquarters two or three messages advising what stories it plans to carry. Such a message might advise that ``at 11:30 a.m. Eastern Time, Iraqi TV will be carrying a message from President Saddam Hussein to President Bush.'' Television has become a weapon in this war of nerves, just as it was when the Ayatollah Khomeini allowed U.S. camera crews to film frenzied mobs of Iranians denouncing ``The Great Satan'' America during the 1979-1980 hostage crisis. And it's getting on President Bush's nerves. Bush complained to reporters this week that they were asking harder questions of him than of Saddam Hussein in Baghdad. Ed Turner, CNN's executive vice president for news gathering, said the network tapes most Iraqi TV offerings and screens them before they are put on the network. But on Thursday, when Hussein appeared on television for 50 minutes with a roomful of English-speaking hostages, CNN stayed with Iraqi TV the entire time. The other American networks showed excerpts of the bizarre, profoundly disturbing scene. Turner, no relation to CNN founder Ted Turner, shrugs off any suggestion that the network is being used for propaganda by the Iraqis. ``The technology that permits all this is not going to be disinvented,'' he said. ``When we worry about being used or manipulated, or becoming a part of this story as opposed to being chroniclers, it seems to me that since the technology exists, it's a question of using it responsibly.'' Robert MacNeil, co-anchor of ``The MacNeil-Lehrer Hour'' on the Public Broadcasting service, said television is doing what wire services and newspapers have been doing for more than a century. ``It's just that television has speeded it up,'' MacNeil said. ``It's a kind of television version of the hot line that Kennedy and Khrushchev set up after the Cuban Missile Crisis.'' The international audience for CNN's broadcast is awesome. The network's broadcasts are seen in 95 countries, including 25 in Europe, 3 in the Middle East and 10 in Africa. ``We're virtually the primary source of news for many people, including many principals involved in the current crisis,'' said Peter Vesey, director of CNN International. ``It's gratifying, but it emphasizes once again our responsibility as journalists not only to get it fast, but to get it right.'' Ted Turner began with 1.7 million domestic subscribers and now has over 55 million. At any given time the evening newscasts of the other three commercial networks out draw CNN 10-to-1, but that is not a valid comparison since the cable network's audience is spread over a 24-hour day. Vesey estimates that CNN has nine million subscribers worldwide, but its audience is far larger, since the service is available unscrambled to people who have the right kind of equipment, but don't pay. The network observed its 10th anniversary last month and Newsweek, describing a celebration, headlined its piece ``CNN is the network of the new world it helped create.'' National Public Radio's Daniel Schorr, who was with CNN at the start, called it ``The world's intercom.'' CNN took out a three-age advertisement this month in the industry publication, Electronic Media, to brag about how far it's come. ``They laughed when we decided to create an all-news network,'' said the first page. ``Nobody's laughing now,'' says the second.

DOC.HEAD: Diplomats in Stand-Off With Iraqi Troops; U.N. Supports Force
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with electricity cut off at U.S. Embassy. Pick up 12th graf pvs, `Japan and...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LON2,NY9,11,12,22
DOC.TEXT: The United Nations Security Council voted today to put military might behind economic sanctions on Iraq, while diplomats inside embassies in Kuwait played a tense waiting game with Iraqi troops surrounding some of their compounds. U.S. officials said electricity to the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait was cut off today but Iraqi troops around the American compound have not attempted to close it. The Security Council vote came after the United States _ which has dozens of warships in the Persian Gulf _ sought U.N. authority to use force in stopping trade with Iraq. The embargo is aimed at pressuring Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to end his 3-week-old occupation of Kuwait. Iraq denounced the Security Council move as illegal and warned it could lead to all-out war. ``This use of force by the United States or any of its allies or puppets will lead inevitably to a number of explosions which will burn all in their path,'' said Iraq's U.N. ambassador, Abdul Amir Al-Anbari. Meanwhile, Japan's Foreign Ministry said today that Tokyo's ambassador to Iraq had protested the moving of about 20 Japanese from a Baghdad hotel to an unknown destination. A Foreign Ministry official said the Japanese nationals were put on a bus today with about 20 other foreigners, mostly Caucasians. Saddam has repeatedly threatened to use trapped foreigners as human shields to protect Iraqi installations against attack. In the embassy standoff, a European envoy had said Iraq threatened to forcefully remove diplomats remaining at their posts in Kuwait today. But diplomatic sources said it was unlikely that Baghdad would make such a move while Austrian President Kurt Waldheim was in the Iraqi capital for talks with Saddam. Waldheim arrived today and Saddam himself was on hand to greet him at the airport, according to diplomats who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Austrian president was the first Western leader to meet with Saddam since the invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2, which set off the Persian Gulf crisis. According to Article 45 of the Vienna Convention on diplomatic relations, foreign missions are to remain inviolable even in times of armed conflict. Iraq had said it would cut water and power to embassy compounds where diplomats defied an Iraqi order to close their doors. U.S. officials speaking on condition of anonymity said the power was cut at the U.S. compound but water and other supplies remained adequate. Japan and Italy said power had been cut at their embassies, but the British Foreign Office said electricity to its compound, cut Friday, was back on today and that Iraqi tanks previously surrounding the British compound had left. The British and U.S. embassies were among 10 missions ringed by soldiers. Today's U.N. Security Council vote was the first time in its 45-year history the council has authorized such military action to enforce its own sanctions. The sanctions against Iraq were imposed four days after the invasion. The resolution calls on nations with naval forces in the Persian Gulf region ``to use such measures commensurate to the specific circumstances as may be necessary under the authority of the Security Council to halt all inward and outward maritime.'' The U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, Thomas R. Pickering, called the resolution a historic decision and said it is ``sufficiently broad as to allow the use of force.'' The main sticking point prior to the vote was objections by Moscow, but the Soviet Union agreed to back the resolution and said it would consider joining the naval force. As a permanent council member, the Soviets had veto power over the measure. The Soviet reversal after 10 days of balking came shortly after President Mikhail S. Gorbachev sent an urgent message to Iraq suggesting Moscow might support a military blockade. He called the Persian Gulf situation ``extremely dangerous.'' The 15-member council adopted the resolution with 13 votes in favor and two abstentions, from Cuba and Yemen. Yemen said today it was fully committed to honoring the U.N. embargo and denied reports it serves as a base for Iraqi warplanes. But diplomatic sources in the gulf region contended that Iraq had flown 12 captured Kuwaiti jet fighters to Yemen, and that prior to the invasion it had based 36 Soviet-made Iraqi jet fighters at Ta'ez, 120 miles south of Yemen's capital, San'a. In occupied Kuwait, troops were reported surrounding, or patrolling near, the U.S., British, Canadian, French, Japanese, Italian, Norwegian, Swedish, Romanian and Hungarian embassies. Iraq now considers its oil-rich neighbor Iraqi territory. Several nations complied with the Iraqi order to close embassies, including Venezuela, the Philippines, India and Lebanon. Moscow evacuated its embassy but said the mission remained technically open. The Japanese Foreign Ministry said today that there were still soldiers posted outside the Japanese mission, and that water, electricity and telephone lines were cut. Japan also said one of 213 Japanese refugees from Kuwait _ now under virtual house arrest in a Baghdad hotel _ had made telephone contact with the Baghdad embassy and reported all the Japanese confined in the hotel were well. In Rome, Italy's Foreign Ministry said today that electricity at its Kuwait mission was cut off. Many embassies remaining open maintained skeleton staffs. Some, including Poland and Spain, had just one diplomat present. Greece's Foreign Ministry said today its embassy's telecommunications had been cut. Poland, too, said it has had no contact with its embassy today. Spain's ambassador to Amman, Ramon Armengod, said in Madrid that Iraqi authorities warned Western diplomats that troops would forcibly remove them from their missions starting today. But there were no immediate reports of Iraqi action. The U.S. mission, like most embassies staying open, was cut to a staff of about 10, including Ambassador Nathaniel Howell. On Friday, 100 dependents and staff traveled to Baghdad, from where they were scheduled to leave for home. But once they arrived, Saddam reversed an earlier promise and refused to let them leave the country, said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Later Friday, the official Iraqi News Agency said Iraq would detain only male embassy employees of those countries that refused to close embassies in Kuwait. But there was no indication the dependents were being allowed to leave. Italy's Foreign Ministry said three Italian diplomats who left Kuwait were also kept from leaving Baghdad on Friday. Iraq had said it would revoke the diplomatic status of embassy staff who refused to leave by a Friday deadline. After that date, diplomats were to be treated as any other foreigner. About 21,000 Westerners _ including 3,000 Americans _ have been held in Iraq and Kuwait since the invasion, and President Bush has said they must be considered hostages. Turkey and Jordan, which share borders with Iraq, said they were encountering difficulties sheltering and providing transport for the thousands of mostly Arab refugees streaming across their borders. Jordan said earlier this week that it would close its border, but the European Community and others moved to help with money and supplies, and the border remained open. Turkey requested similar assistance. In the Saudi Arabian desert, more than 100,000 Iraqi troops face tens of thousands of U.S. troops deployed to deter further aggression by Saddam. The American forces will be bolstered by reservists from half a dozen states called up Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Tests Europe's Ability to Take Joint Military Action
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis has presented Western Europe with a tough practical test of its dream of uniting into a superpower. The European Community began the summer with ambitious plans for deepening the economic and political union of its 12 member states. Then came the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, and suddenly the Europeans must think militarily as well. Their initial response was hesitant. The French appeared determined to go their own way. West Germany cited constitutional restrictions on deploying forces outside Europe. Britain, as ever Washington's most loyal ally, quickly sent ships and planes, but it was an American show from the start. That has helped squelch any notion in Europe that, with the end of the Cold War, America was fading away as a superpower. ``The United States has gained tremendous respect and people can no longer say that it is a failing superpower, unable to keep up with the EC or anybody else,'' said Vernon Bogdanor, an Oxford University expert on Europe. ``The European population is larger than that of the United States and they rely on (Arab) oil even more than the Americans do, but they are simply not able to organize their own defense.'' It took nearly three weeks for the Europeans to come up with a joint response. On Tuesday, the nine-nation Western European Union, the European arm of NATO, said it had agreed on a coordinated military response to back the U.N. embargo against Iraq. European Community foreign ministers, also meeting in Paris, announced the same day that member countries would defy Iraqi orders to close their embassies in Kuwait. Belgium, the Netherlands, Italy, Spain and Greece will join Britain and France in sending naval vessels to the gulf. West Germany said it would change its constitution to allow participation. Portugal, the ninth member of the Western European Union, expressed reservations and did not commit itself to sending ships. Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France described the Tuesday meetings as a response ``to a situation which is exceptional in its gravity and its implications.'' France's president, Francois Mitterrand, acknowledged the disadvantage of not having a joint defense structure. He said Europe ``must become more conscious of itself, which will become more possible once it has a political existence.'' Bogdanor said Europe was slow to act ``partly because there is no real European government to make decisions and partly because of the lack of a defense capacity.'' He said the Western European Union could act only through member governments and required unanimity, and the EC was preoccupied with internal problems. ``Germany is concentrating on reunification and the rest of Europe is looking at monetary and political union, so the gulf crisis has really highlighted the weaknesses of the Community,'' Bogdanor said. Josef Janning of the European Research Group at Mainz University in West Germany said the delay showed the Europeans had no concept of how to react quickly and were forced to scramble in a crisis. West Germany hid behind its own laws to avoid military action in the gulf, he said, ``but it is noteworthy that . . . changing the constitution is no longer being completely rejected.'' As the EC's economic powerhouse, Germany cannot escape ``the point that at some time military operations must be undertaken, even if they expose themselves to others who say `Ah, there come the Germans, who started World War II,''' Janning said. The EC has been firmer on diplomatic issues arising from the crisis. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd of Britain pointed to the united stand on Iraq's threat to the embassies in Kuwait. ``It's been very heartening that, against some predictions, we've all stuck together on this and none have yielded to the temptation to pull out the diplomatic staffs while the going was good,'' he said Friday, as Iraqi troops began surrounding the legations. ``Even those countries who have very small communities in Kuwait have stuck, and that is a good thing,'' Hurd said. Trevor Taylor, a defense expert soon to join the Royal Institute for International Affairs in London, said of the decision to sent naval forces: ``The notion that there would be such a coordinated European military action outside the NATO area was unthinkable a few years ago.'' Christopher Hill, lecturer in international relations at the London School of Economics, noted that the Western European Union meeting was the first to coincide with a conference of EC foreign ministers. ``Combine this with the German decision and . . . you have an extremely significant development,'' he said. Hill added, however, that the concerted action runs ``the risk of breaking the traditional Euro-Arab dialogue asunder.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Blame Renegade Soldiers in Philippines Bombing
DOC.TEXT: A car company was bombed in the financial district Saturday night and police said they suspected renegade soldiers. The military has said that blasts in Manila may be a prelude to a coup attempt against President Corazon Aquino. Police Col. Remy Macaspac said at least six cars were damaged but no one was hurt in the explosion at the Toyota sales office in Makati. It was the 14th bombing since mutinous soldiers bombed two buildings of the Department of Trade in Makati on Aug 14. Mrs. Aquino has survived six coup attempts since becoming president in February 1986 after a popular uprising drove the late Ferdinand Marcos into exile.

DOC.HEAD: One Killed, 7 Trapped in Ukrainian Mine Accident
DOC.TEXT: A cave-in at a Ukrainian coal mine killed one miner, injured several others and left seven miners trapped more than a half-mile below the surface, the Soviet news agency Tass reported Saturday. Rescuers worked several hours to drill holes to reach the trapped miners after Friday's accident at the Lenin coal mine near Gorlovka, Tass said. Water, food, medication and clothes were passed through the holes. The rescue team was continuing to drill holes in an effort to free the miners, Tass said. A government commission was investigating the cause of the accident.

DOC.HEAD: Electricity Cut Off To U.S. Embassy in Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 new grafs to UPDATE with White House confirming electricity cut off to U.S. Embassy in Kuwait and comments; edits to conform and tighten; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Electricity to the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait was cut off today but Iraqi troops around the diplomatic mission have not attempted to close it, U.S. officials said. ``They're operating under generator power,'' said White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk, adding that the Bush administration had ``made known our views about the current situation'' to Iraqi officials in Baghdad, Kuwait and Washington. But he said water and other supplies remain adequate for Ambassador Nathaniel Howell and his staff of about 10 diplomats, who are defying Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's order to shift the U.S. embassy operations to Baghdad. ``Power was cut to our embassy some time during last night,'' Popadiuk said. ``There are reports that power as well as other services such as water have been cut to other embassies.'' He said, however, that electricity may have been restored to some of the other diplomatic compounds. ``The embassy continues to function. It is carrying out its consular functions,'' Popadiuk said. He said a small contingent of Iraqi soldiers remained outside the embassy as they have since before Friday's deadline from the Iraqis for Western nations to close their embassies in Kuwait. Meanwhile, the State Department sought to assure 2,500 or so Americans trapped in Kuwait that the embassy was ``determined to continue working for your release from Kuwait and your safe return to your families.'' In a broadcast carried on the Voice of America and the British Broadcasting Corp., the State Department also cautioned Americans not to go to the embassy compound where Iraqi troops were posted. ``The United States government wants American citizens to be assured that your welfare is foremost in our thoughts,'' the broadcast said. In Baghdad, about 100 U.S. diplomats and dependents who were evacuated from the embassy in Kuwait still were unable to leave Iraq. ``Their situation has not changed,'' a U.S. official told The Associated Press in Washington. The group had been guaranteed safe passage. But en route to Baghdad from Kuwait City, the Iraqis imposed new regulations barring the departure of diplomats whose embassies remained open despite Saddam's order that they be closed Friday. Subsequently, the Iraqi news agency reported the dependents could leave. The State Department planned to evacuate them to Turkey today, but they remained in the Iraqi capital while U.S. diplomats took up the situation with the Iraqi foreign ministry, the officials in Washington said. In other developments today, the White House applauded the United Nations vote to allow military enforcement of trade sanctions against Baghdad, saying the move ``further strengthens the world resolve to force Iraq out of Kuwait.'' White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater also hailed Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's ``strong support'' of the sanctions, calling it ``a very important development.'' At the Pentagon, officials announced that elements of the 48th Tactical Fighter Wing were being deployed to Saudi Arabia from their base at RAF Lakenheath in Great Britain. The wing will deploy F-111 aircraft, which are long-range bombers, associated personnel and equipment to support the U.S. Central Command forces in Operation Desert Shield. F-111s from Britain were used in the raids against Libya. Fitzwater, in a written statement released at this rainy resort where President Bush is in the third week of a crisis-clouded vacation, said: ``President Gorbachev's statement (Friday) supporting the United Nations sanctions was a very important development. We welcome his voice to the world condemnation of the aggression by Saddam Hussein.'' Fitzwater added that the U.N. Security Council resolution adopted early today ``further strengthens the world resolve to force Iraq out of Kuwait. We are encouraged by the progress of events at the United Nations and by President Gorbachev's strong support.'' Gorbachev sent an urgent message Friday to Saddam urging him to comply with the U.N. orders to get out of Kuwait, and warning that the situation in the gulf was ``extremely dangerous.'' Bush stayed out of the public eye today, fishing from his speedboat Fidelity despite a morning downpour. The resolution by the 15-member Security Council passed with 13 votes in favor and Yemen and Cuba abstaining. It calls on nations with naval forces in the Persian Gulf region ``to use such measures commensurate to the specific circumstances as may be necessary under the authority of the Security Council to halt all inward and outward maritime.'' Fitzwater said: ``The unanimous vote further underlines the deep concern of the world community regarding the blatant aggression by Iraq against Kuwait. The resolve of the international community is strong.'' Iraq overran Kuwait Aug. 2 and annexed the emirate six days later. The Soviets had said they would back a U.S. resolution calling for ``minimum force'' to stop all shipping to and from Iraq. As U.S. Ambassador Thomas Pickering was marshaling support for that resolution at the U.N. on Friday, the White House charged that Iraq was circumventing the sanctions in a variety of ways, including ``aviation shipments into Baghdad.'' Fitzwater said called Iraq's refusal to let all the diplomats out ``a further step in the harassment that (Saddam) has undertaken.'' At least 20 countries kept their Kuwait embassies open in defiance of Saddam's edict. The British and Greek embassies previously reported they had no electricity or water, and troops surrounded a number of Western embassies and the Japanese embassy. Thousands of American troops and an armada of warships are within range of Iraq and Kuwait, but Bush has given no hint how he might respond if Saddam attempts to overrun the embassy. The Navy announced on Saturday that it had called up 127 reserve units. The Marine guards at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait left in the convoy, signalling that U.S. officials had no intention of resisting any Iraqi effort to storm the building.

DOC.HEAD: Irish Hostage Says He Saw Westerners During Captivity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with Keenan comment on Sutherland, McCarthy, reaction from Anderson's sister. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `Keenan was...'; restores byline
DOC.TEXT: Freed Irish hostage Brian Keenan said today he had seen American hostages Terry Anderson and Thomas Sutherland and other Westerners during his four-year captivity in Lebanon. Keenan, 39, looking pale but otherwise physically fit, was turned over to Irish Foreign Minister Gerry Collins today, almost 24 hours after he was freed by his captors. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was abducted March 16, 1985. He is the longest held of the 13 Westerners still believed held by Moslem zealots in Lebanon. ``I saw Terry Anderson some time ago,'' Keenan said, without specifying when. ``He's in good form. He received messages from his fiance and he appreciates the letters that he received from his family.'' He said he also saw Sutherland, who was kidnapped June 9, 1985, and British hostage John McCarthy, grabbed April 17, 1986. He did not specify when he last saw Sutherland, 56, of Fort Collins, Colo., but said he was with McCarthy, 33, ``only two nights ago.'' About Sutherland, he said, ``He's well. He has told us an entire repertoire of jokes also several times, and Dr. Sutherland is in good health and regularly exercising.'' He said McCarthy, a reporter for the London-based Worldwide Television News, was also well. ``His great sense of humor succeeded very early in driving me slightly insane. John's good humor mimickly was very much appreciated and brought in all of us who came in contact with him a real sense of the outside world,'' Keenan added. Of Anderson, he said: ``He has a picture of his daughter, Sulome, which is some great companionship for him.'' Anderson has never seen Sulome, 5, who was born almost three months after he was kidnapped. He is among six Americans, two West Germans and an Italian also remaining in captivity in Lebanon. Anderson's sister Peggy Say, told of Keenan's comments, said: ``I'm anxious to talk to Brian and to get more details about Terry's mental, emotional and physical health.'' ``Of course, I'm very pleased for the Keenan sisters and their family. But unfortunately, our experience has been in the past that when a single hostage is released, that doesn't nercessarily mean that we are going to see another one for some time _ six months and sometimes years,'' she said by telephone from her home in Kentucky. Keenan, who held a news conference at the home of the Dutch Ambassador Gerben Meihuizen, read a handwritten statement to reporters but took no questions. Keenan was turned over to the Irish foreign minister at the Syrian Foreign Ministry. Keenan's sisters, Eliane Spence and Brenda Gillham, also were waiting in the compound. Kenaan, his hair cut short and his beard neatly trimmed, struggled to hold back tears as he sat between his sisters on a sofa in the Syrian foreign minister's office. ``I am delighted to be with my sisters,'' he said, his voice choking. Collins, Mrs. Spence and Mrs. Gillham had flown in from Dublin an hour earlier. They were accompanied by a doctor and a nurse. They drove first to the home of the Dutch ambassador, then to the ministry. Keenan was the fifth Western hostage released in as many months. A little-known group calling itself The Organization of the Islamic Dawn had said the teacher was being freed Friday, and Ireland later confirmed Keenan had been handed over to Syrian army officers in Beirut, the Lebanese capital. Keenan was kidnapped April 11, 1986 in west Beirut while walking to the American University where he taught English. He was born in Belfast and was traveling on an Irish passport, but he has dual Irish-British citizenship. A statement by the Irish government said ``everyone in Ireland is overjoyed'' at the news of Keenan's release. Britain's Foreign Office also expressed delight and said Britain welcomed the helpful role played by Syria and Iran in Keenan's release and looked to their ``undoubted influence'' to ensure the release of other hostages. These include Church of England envoy Terry Waite, who disappeared in Beirut in 1987 while trying to negotiate the release of other hostages, and McCarthy, Alec Collett and Jack Mann. Collins had told a news conference Friday he hoped Keenan's release would signal the start of the release of all other hostages, and the Irish government intended to work toward that aim. Until the kidnappers' statement Friday, no group had claimed responsibility for Keenan from the time he was abducted until he was freed. The only other statement on hostages to come from The Organization of Islamic Dawn was when it announced April 30 it was releasing Frank Reed, an education administrator born in Malden, Mass. Hostage Robert Polhill of New York was freed April 22, and two Swiss Red Cross workers, Elio Erriquez and Emmanuel Christen, were freed this month. In London, Sky News television said on Friday that Reed, held with Keenan for almost three years, was to fly from Washington to greet Keenan on his arrival at Dublin. Reed, 57, promised after his release following 44 months of captivity that he would be with Keenan when the Irishman was freed.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Reported Reviving Nuclear Project, Increasing Poison Gas Output
DOC.TEXT: Iraq not only has become a major poison gas producer, but also has revived efforts to make atomic weapons, which were thwarted by Israel's 1981 bombing of a nuclear reactor, a report says. President Saddam Hussein's government each year turns out more than 1,000 tons of chemical warfare agents, including blister-causing mustard gas and nerve gas, according to ``Sword of the Arabs,'' a survey of Iraqi weaponry to be issued shortly by the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, a private research organization. Sustained production at that level would give Iraq the world's largest chemical weapons stockpile if the United States and Soviet Union carry out obligations of a treaty they signed last June to reduce their stocks to 5,000 tons by the year 2002. Current U.S. stockpiles are estimated at 30,000 tons, while the Soviets have an estimated 50,000. Iraq also has an active program to make germ weapons even though it has signed but not ratified a 1972 treaty prohibiting development or possession of biological weapons, said the report, obtained by The Associated Press. After Israel bombed Iraq's Osiraq reactor in 1981, the Iraqi nuclear weapons project remained dormant until 1987 when Baghdad turned to the gas centrifuge method of enriching uranium fuel, the study said. This could provide the ability to produce nuclear weapons in five to 10 years depending the amount of equipment and technology Iraq continues to draw from abroad, it added. Long before that, however, Iraq could make one or two small, low-yield atomic bombs using 12.5 kilograms (27.5 pounds) of French-supplied uranium in its possession, said report author Michael Eisenstadt. That uranium, however, is subject to international inspection and its diversion to weapons would be a formal breach of the Non-Proliferation Treaty signed by Iraq, provoking international censure and making it harder for Baghdad to acquire equipment and technology for the other process. Eisenstadt said Iraq was unlikely at this time to opt for the crude, smaller bombs. The gas centrifuge method, used by Pakistan and Brazil, is easy to disperse and conceal and ``might enable Iraq to clandestinely develop a nuclear weapons production capability while formally preserving its credentials as a signatory of the NPT (treaty),'' he said. Predicting that Iraq will stockpile chemical ``and possibly biological weapons for the foreseeable future,'' Eisenstadt said Iraq in the near future is expected to produce chemical missile warheads, ``vastly increasing the lethality of its strategic forces.'' Such capabilities enable Iraq to coerce its smaller neighbors and increasingly to deal with Israel ``from a position of strength,'' he said, noting inputs of Soviet, Chinese, West German, Austrian, Italian, Argentine, Egyptian and Swiss technology in Iraqi missile development. Development of strike systems capable of reaching Israel ``has led to the emergence of an uneasy deterrent relationship between Iraq and Israel,'' he said. ``Israel now has to consider that a preventive strike against Iraq could prompt retaliation and produce unacceptable losses. Iraq's strategic deterrent thus produces a protective umbrella for its nuclear weapons program.'' Eisenstadt, a research fellow in political-military affairs at the Washington Institute, also works as a civilian analyst for U.S. Army Intelligence and is a reserve Army intelligence officer. The Institute has a declared policy of promoting wide-ranging, informed debate about the Middle East. While regarded as supportive of strong U.S.-Iraeli relations the institute office said it receives no Israeli funds. Its advisory board includes former Secretaries of State George Shultz and Alexander Haig, former Vice President Walter Mondale, former U.N. Ambassador Jeane Kirkpatrick, U.S. News and World Report Editor Mortimer Zuckerman, former Assistant Defense Secretary Richard Perle and Stuart Eizenstat, counsel to former President Jimmy Carter.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Anxious For Successful Columbia Mission
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Columbia originally...', to CORRECT month of Challenger disaster to January sted February 1986.
DOC.TEXT: After struggling for weeks to fix fuel leaks, NASA intends to try once again this week to send Columbia up to study some of the hottest objects in the universe. The shuttle, sporting new hydrogen lines, is scheduled to lift off at 1:17 a.m. EDT Saturday with seven astronauts and the $150 million Astro observatory. The countdown is due to begin early Wednesday. As Columbia orbits 218 miles above Earth, Astro will probe high-energy ultraviolet light and X-rays emitted from stars, galaxies, quasars, even a comet and supernova. Such radiation is invisible from the ground. The mission, scheduled to last nine to 10 days, will be the first in five years devoted entirely to scientific research. It also will be the first shuttle flight since Discovery carried the flawed Hubble Space Telescope into orbit in April. That's the longest gap between missions since flights resumed following the 1986 Challenger disaster. ``We're certainly aware we will be getting a lot more public attention. Will that affect what we're doing? Not at all,'' said Jeffrey Hoffman, one of four astronomers on board to operate Astro. ``We were always going at it 105 percent.'' Columbia originally was scheduled to lift off with Astro in March 1986; one of the targets was to have been Halley's Comet. That mission and all others were put on hold after Challenger exploded in January 1986. This year, after a revamping of Astro's observation plans, launch was set for May 30, but hydrogen escaped from Columbia during fueling and the flight was called off. Atlantis took Columbia's place at the pad but also was found to have a hydrogen leak, and its classified military mission was delayed from July to November. Atlantis was rolled back to the hangar 2{ weeks ago, and a newly repaired Columbia reclaimed the pad. ``Yeah, it's frustrating,'' Hoffman said, noting all the delays. ``One of the things that you absolutely need in this business is patience and also the ability not to take all of these things personally.'' Besides coping with leaky shuttles, the space agency has spent the past several months investigating the cause of Hubble's blemished mirror. More recently, National Aeronautics and Space Administration engineers have been struggling with the periodic loss of radio contact with the Venus-orbiting Magellan spacecraft. Consequently, NASA expresses eagerness for success. ``Everyone is very anxious for our mission to go very well,'' said Gene Urban, deputy mission scientist for Astro. ``We're really a little nervous, I'd say, about having everything work right.'' ``I'm worried that it normally comes in threes, so maybe I have two more to go'' following Hubble, said Charles Pellerin Jr., NASA's director of astrophysics. Scientists' main concern with Astro is the instrument pointing system for the three ultraviolet telescopes. The pointing system has been used only once before, for solar observations in 1985, and numerous problems were encountered. About half of the 150 or so objects Astro will observe _ some of them millions of degrees _ will be new this time around, said mission scientist Ted Gull. Many of the May targets had to be replaced because they got too close to the sun for the instruments to see. Columbia's flight will be the first of five Spacelab missions dedicated to a single subject _ astrophysics. Among the questions astronomers hope Astro will answer on its first outing are how much helium existed shortly after the universe was created, and what powers quasars, the most distant objects in the universe. Columbia's crew is taking advantage of the mission's scientific focus to conduct ``Space Classroom,'' the first of what NASA hopes will become a regular series for youngsters. More than 40 middle school students at two NASA centers will question the astronauts through a two-way audio link. The crew hopes to contact the two cosmonauts aboard space station Mir by ham radio, marking the first time direct radio communications is made between a U.S. and Soviet spacecraft. Payload specialist Ron Parise, a licensed ham radio operator, also plans to contact amateur radio stations around the world. Commanding the mission is Vance Brand, who at age 59 will become the oldest astronaut to fly in space.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Rail Trestle Damaged by Fire after Violent Police-Indian Clash
DOC.TEXT: A railroad trestle was severely damaged by fire after the Royal Canadian Mounted Police clashed with Indian demonstrators and dismantled their rail blockade. Almost half the 165-foot railroad across the Portage River on BC Rail's main line was severely charred before volunteer firefighters extinguished the blaze, which began late Friday. The bridge is at Seton Portage near Lillooet, about 115 miles northeast of Vancouver. No damage estimate was available. There were no fire-related injuries, authorities said. About five hours earlier, police officers armed with clubs stormed about 150 Indians blocking the main road through Seton Portage to protest arrests at the rail blockade, which was dismantled earlier in the day. As police dogs on leashes snarled and two helicopters hovered overhead, the officers charged about 150 men, women and children standing at the barricade. The dogs, led by officers yelling, ``Get 'em! Get 'em!'' plunged into the crowd. Some protesters threw rocks at the officers. The confrontation lasted about 10 minutes. The roadway and rail blockades are being used to show area native support for Mohawks clashing with authorities in Oka, Quebec, and to call attention to native land claims. Police said arson was suspected in the trestle blaze, which BC Rail officials said will indefinitely halt traffic on the main line serving British Columbia's resource-rich interior. An Indian leader denied native involvement in the fire. ``There's no question it was set but I know it wasn't done by one of our members,'' said Rod Louie, Seton Lake Indian band chief. ``I've indicated to BC Rail our fight isn't with them. It's with the federal and provincial governments.'' The rail blockade on BC Rail's main line that was dismantled a few hours before the confrontation had been erected late Thursday. The 3-foot-high blockade of timber and rocks was the second rail blockade to be dismantled in a week. Sixteen people were arrested at the rail blockade. Fifteen were charged with violating a court injunction against such blockades and one was charged with obstruction.

DOC.HEAD: Marchers Protest Violence in South Africa, Fault Police
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with marches in other cities; picks up 3rd graf pvs, `More than...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Marchers protesting political violence and alleged police bias paraded through several cities Saturday to demand government action to restore peace. Some 250 women of all races of the African National Congress Women's League marched to parliament to present demands, including an immediate halt to black factional fighting. The Women's League organized similar marches around the country and drew even larger crowds in Port Elizabeth, on the southern coast, and Pietermaritzburg, in Natal Province. More than 5,000 blacks have been killed in Natal Province since 1985 in clashes between the Zulu-led conservative Inkatha movement and ANC-affiliated groups. The clashes spread to black townships around Johannesburg on Aug. 12, leaving more than 500 people dead. On Friday, the government declared the Johannesburg area townships ``unrest areas,'' which gave police widespread powers to suppress the violence. The marchers claimed thousands of lives would have been saved if the government had taken effective steps earlier. ``Had the conflict been in white residential areas or if the victims had been predominantly white, immediate steps would have been taken to end the conflict,'' said Nomatyala Hangana of the Women's League. The marchers also contended that police failed to protect black communities and had shown ``extreme partiality'' toward Inkatha members. Police and government officials have denied such charges. The marchers demanded a judicial commission of inquiry into the violence; that security forces play an ``effective and impartial role as peacekeepers;'' and creation of a crisis fund to help families repair damaged and looted homes. In a separate protest, several hundred people marched to the headquarters of the government-operated South African Broadcasting Corp. in Johannesburg to protest what organizers called secret and partial decision-making on restructuring. The protesters demanded a government-appointed task force on the restructuring be disbanded. They also demanded impartial broadcasting, union organizing at the corporation, racially balanced hiring and promotion policies, and an end to censorship.

DOC.HEAD: 30 People Injured By Gate Crashers At Rap Concert
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `About 555..', to CORRECT location of city to 20 sted 180 miles from San Francisco.
DOC.TEXT: About 40 youths scaled gates at an amphitheater during a concert by the rap group Public Enemy and randomly assaulted concert-goers and security guards, police said. Thirty people were treated for minor injuries at first aid stations after the attacks Friday Shoreline Amphitheatre, said Lt. Gary Smith. Three others, including one police officer, were treated and released from El Camino Hospital, he said. The assaults in the outer plaza of the amphitheater apparently did not disrupt the concert, which was attended by an estimated 8,000 people, Smith said. About 55 officers from Mountain View, a city approximately 20 miles south of San Francisco, and other police agencies were assigned to security at the amphitheater, but no arrests were made, Smith said. Victims told police the attackers were members of a gang, but Smith said no gang affiliation was confirmed. None of the attackers apparently was armed, Smith said. ``It was strictly with their fists. Some people didn't know what they had been hit with,'' Smith said. There was no indication robbery was a motive, he said. Messages left on answering machines of two of the group's publicists seeking comment on Saturday were not immediately returned. Public Enemy, whose recordings have been banned in some cities, was performing as part of a ``Sizzling Summer Tour 90'' that included the groups Digital Underground and Big Daddy Kane.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Resolution on Iraq Could Mean New Life for Moribund Military Body
With AM-Gulf-UN, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Since 1946, the officers of the U.N. Military Staff Committee have gathered doggedly every two weeks to formally confirm that there is no work for their moribund group to do. Suddenly, their role may change. The U.N. resolution passed Saturday, authorizing the use of force to carry out an embargo against Iraq, asks member states to coordinate their actions ``as appropriate'' through the Military Staff Committee. The resolution didn't say precisely what the committee should do. It could conceivably be a center for exchanging intelligence, or just receive reports of individual nations' activities. But the resolution is likely to give some visibility and a new lease on life to what had been one of the United Nations' most obscure institutions. The committee consists of senior military officers from United States, Soviet Union, China, Britain and France, the five permanent members of the Security Council. Since the committee's founding, it has met twice a month for about 20 minutes, often in a basement conference room, to officially take note that the Security Council hasn't ordered it to do anything. Meanwhile, on the 38th floor of U.N. Headquarters, civil servants have coordinated the U.N. forces the world is already used to _ the 15,000 peacekeepers assigned to trouble spots worldwide. The civilian secretariat members run the peacekeeping troops in a hierarchy completely separate from the Military Staff Committee. Under the U.N. Charter, the Military Staff Committee was to command any combined military force that the Security Council would establish. But the committee quickly became moribund because of the Cold War. During the Korean conflict, the United Nations assigned military command of U.N. forces to the United States, instead of attempting to activate the Military Staff Committee. Diplomats have favored continued meetings of the staff committee on the grounds that abandoning them would symbolize an end to the hope that the United Nations would ever be able to organize joint military action. The U.N. missions of the five powers pay the salaries of the officers assigned to it.

DOC.HEAD: Searches, Panic Buying, Rationing As Iraq Feels Bite of U.N. Embargo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to delete extraneous population figure. Figure in 6th graf stands.
DOC.TEXT: Reports filtering out of Baghdad tell of panic buying, rationing and house-to-house sweeps by militiamen hunting food hoarders as Iraq begins to feel the bite of the U.N. trade embargo. On Saturday, the U.N. Security Council approved military action to enforce the embargo imposed Aug. 6 to punish Saddam Hussein for invading and annexing Kuwait. It could be weeks before Iraqis really have to tighten their belts. But even before the sanctions were given sharper teeth, reports out of Iraq said essentials such as cooking oil, flour and fruit have virtually disappeared in the capital city of Baghdad and other areas. Armed units of the ruling Ba'th Party's militia, the People's Guard, were conducting random checks of stores and homes, looking in freezers and cupboards for surplus stocks, the dissident Kurdish Democratic Party said in a statement released in Nicosia. The reports were confirmed by sources in Baghdad, where about a quarter of Iraq's 17 million people live. Since Aug. 12, when Saddam told the nation to prepare for austerity, hoarding food and profiteering have been punishable by death. For the last three days, government agents have been conducting a census in Baghdad to prepare for national rationing based on the number of people in each family, according to sources who spoke on condition they not be identified. Militiamen and soldiers patrolled Baghdad's streets to disperse crowds of more than five people, the sources said. Government ministers and the official media have been asking people to reduce their consumption of some foods, while assuring them that Iraq has sufficient stockpiles to last months, the sources said. Exiled Iraqis and experts have varied opinions about how much food Iraq has on hand and how long it will last. The only certainty is that the country requires food imported with oil revenue. Last year, Iraq spent $2.9 billion importing 75 percent of what its people ate. With oil exports, Saddam's main source of revenue, now largely cut off, Iraq faces a harsh winter if it does not withdraw from Kuwait. ``The most important thing is the oil embargo,'' said Selim Fakhri, a former colonel in the Iraqi army and a leading figure in the resistance alliance in exile. ``Food is still coming in through Jordan, perhaps Yemen and Lebanon. But if Iraq can't sell its oil, then there will come a time when the country will not be able to pay for anything, even if it can bring it in. ``Without oil, the country grinds to a halt. I give it no more than a couple of months,'' he said in a telephone interview from London. Throughout the 1980-88 war with Iran and after, Iraq bought most of its food from the United States, Canada and Australia, all now committed to the embargo. In the 12 months ending June 30, Iraq bought 2.5 million tons of wheat, barley, rice and corn from the United States, said Jonathan Crusoe, an analyst with the Middle East Economic Digest. U.S. corn accounted for 650,000 tons of total Iraqi imports of 750,000 tons. Last year, however, the U.S. Agriculture Department reduced credit to Iraq, which then started seeking other suppliers of cotton, tobacco, wool, cattle hides and tallow. Around 100,000 tons of wheat had been ordered from the European Community for shipment in August and October, Crusoe said. Turkey, which supplied its southeastern neighbor with citrus fruits, tomato paste, lentils, chickpeas and cotton, could have helped fill Iraq's import gap, but joined the embargo on Aug. 8. Some U.S. agencies estimate that Iraq has enough wheat to last two months, rice for three months and corn for less than two weeks. All these stocks could be extended substantially by rationing. The eight-year war with Iran left its scars on Iraq's agricultural sector. But the real damage was done by 20 years of tight socialist control of the economy. Farmland between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers was ravaged. A campaign against rebellious Kurds in the fertile north resulted in the forcible relocation of tens of thousands of peasants. Even with the international military action to halt shipping to Iraq, some food still may get through. U.N. Resolution 661 allows food on humanitarian grounds. But President Bush's goal is ``total economic deprivation.'' To be successful, he said, ``this embargo is going to be all-encompassing, and it will include food.''

DOC.HEAD: Pa. Anti-Abortion Advocates Vow Tough New Control, Ultimate Court Victory
DOC.TEXT: Pennsylvania's anti-abortion advocates promised to restore restrictions overturned by a federal judge and predicted ultimate victory in the courts. ``The big enchilada is the U.S. Supreme Court and we're going to win,'' said Rep. Gerard Kosinsky, one of the Legislature's most vocal anti-abortion supporters. In a 191-page ruling issued Friday, U.S. District Judge Daniel H. Huyett III struck down provisions of Pennsylvania's abortion law that would have required a woman to notify her husband and to wait 24 hours before getting an abortion, and would have forced minors to obtain a parent's consent or a court order. Women's rights groups proclaimed victory after the ruling, but expressed concern the Pennsylvania law could become the case that would lead to the overturning the U.S. Supreme Court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision legalizing abortion. Kathryn Kolbert, the American Civil Liberties Union lawyer who argued the case, said it could reach the nation's highest court by fall 1991. She said the case ``continues to pose an ominous threat to reproductive freedom nationwide.'' Pennsylvania's law was considered the nation's most restrictive state statute. The nation's most stringent law _ enacted in the U.S. territory of Guam _ banned all abortions except when a woman's life was in danger and also made it illegal to recommend a woman have an abortion. A federal judge threw it out it Thursday. A stringent anti-abortion bill was passed this year by the Louisiana Legislature, but the governor vetoed it after the legislative session ended and legislators rejected a move for a special session. A spokesman for Pennsylvani state Attorney General Ernie Preate Jr. said an appeal seeking to uphold the law here would be filed with the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. Abortion-rights activists said Huyett's decision proved the law was unconstitutional and that the Pennsylvania Legislature was out of sync with voters. ``We feel it was the best decision we could have gotten,'' said Jenny Daughtry, executive director of the National Abortion Rights Action League. ``It was a very sensible and courageous decision. Judge Huyett saw through the anti-choice rhetoric and spoke to the lives of real women harmed by the restrictions.'' Ms. Daughtry said her group is working to defeat anti-abortion legislative candidates in the upcoming November election, particularly Rep. Stephen Freind, the Legislature's chief abortion opponent. Contacted by the Delaware County Times at the New Jersey shore, Freind said: ``No doubt we are going to win in the Supreme Court. I'm not the slightest bit discouraged. Everything is happening the way we thought it would happen.'' Rep. Karen Ritter, the state's most vocal abortion-rights legislator, said she was pleased by the ruling but concerned that women's reproductive freedom could be threatened nationwide. ``We are concerned that we may have problems keeping abortion safe and legal in the United States, not just in Pennsylvania,'' she said. Howard Fetterhoff, executive director of the Pennsylvania Catholic Conference, said the decision could not be viewed as a significant setback because he predicted it would ultimately be reviewed by the U.S. Supreme Court. ``For those people who think abortion is a legitimate medical procedure, (the law) does pose burdens. But for those of us who believe unborn children are deserving of legal protection ... the law does as much as it can under present circumstances to protect the unborn child,'' Fetterhoff said.

DOC.HEAD: Controversial Artists Plan Lawsuit Over Federal Support Policies
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, bgng: Two of, to CORRECT time element to Friday
DOC.TEXT: It was a night for sushi and tears as arts supporters rallied to denounce government censorship and plot a lawsuit against the National Endowment for the Arts for rejecting grants to a quartet of avant-garde theater performers. Two of the stage artists, Holly Hughes of New York and Tim Miller of Los Angeles, enlivened the fund-raising party Friday night with ribald monologues that heaped scorn on NEA Chairman John E. Frohnmayer and Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C. The mood of the party was dampened by word that Frohnmayer had just denied the appeals of the four performers _ Ms. Hughes, Miller, Karen Finley of New York and John Fleck of Los Angeles _ whose grants he had vetoed in late June. Ms. Hughes said Frohnmayer was using the four rejected grantees as ``sacrificial lambs'' to appease Helms and other conservative members of Congress who oppose federal support for works they regard as obscene and sacrilegious. Ms. Finley, whose performances sometimes include smearing her body with chocolate and filling her bra with gelatin, didn't make the party. But she issued a statement in New York charging that Frohnmayer's decision amounted to government censorship of the arts. ``This only underscores that we are being punished for the controversial content of our work,'' she said. ``The government wants art to be propaganda for the state, and we're not willing to do that.'' The non-profit Center for Constitutional Rights of New York said the NEA had disclosed Frohnmayer's decision in letters received Friday. ``As in its initial denial letters, the NEA gives no substantive reasons for the denials,'' the center said. The center said it would represent the four performers in a lawsuit in federal court charging that Frohnmayer's decision was based on political rather than aesthetic grounds and violates their First Amendment free-speech rights. Last October, after criticism of NEA support for exhibitions of controversial images by photographer Robert Mapplethorpe and artist Andres Serrano, Congress voted to prohibit the arts endowment from using federal funds to support works that ``may be deemed obscene.'' Frohnmayer warned a meeting of arts professionals in Seattle in late June that ``political realities'' might force him to veto some grants recommended by NEA review panels. Two days later, on June 29, he rejected panel-approved grants for Ms. Finley, Ms. Hughes, Miller and Fleck. At Friday's party, about 200 people used chopsticks to munch on sushi and spring rolls as Charlotte Murphy, executive director of the non-profit National Association of Artists' Organizations, tearfully told the gathering that her group would press ``the fight against censorship, especially censorship based on politics, racism and homophobia.'' Public performances by such ``solo performance artists'' as the four rejected NEA grantees frequently include monologues or songs with explicit sexual content that deal with politics, racial bigotry and sexual oppression. Each of the four had received NEA grants in the past, but their performances have been singled out recently by conservative lawmakers and religious fundamentalists as examples of the arts endowment's willingness to subsidize offensive material. Ms. Hughes said the four rejected grants totaled about $23,000, a minuscule share of the NEA's current $171 million budget. The next time she needs financial support, Ms. Hughes deadpanned, she will skip the NEA and apply to the Silverado savings and loan in Denver for $100 million to build a resort hotel, with a multimillion-dollar golf course financed by the Department of Housing and Urban Development. ``When the whole thing goes belly-up, it'll be the taxpayers' problem,'' she said with a laugh. ``The government will bail me out, and I'll be free.'' Silverado, whose directors included President Bush's son, Neil Bush, is a prominent casualty of the current S&L crisis. Silverado's collapse in December 1988 will result in an estimated $1 billion in bailout costs to the taxpayers.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Aunt Marie helps them with their voice projection and Uncle Donny wrote them a song, but the Osmond Boys say they're working on their own image. ``We grew up around music but we're not trying to copy anybody,'' leader Michael Osmond, 15, said Saturday before a performance at the Michigan State Fair. The four brothers, Michael, Nathan, 13, Douglas, 12, and David, 11, are sons of Alan Osmond, at 41 the oldest of the defunct Osmond Brothers, who themselves got their show biz start as youngsters. The Osmond Boys are on a 70-city tour that ends in mid-November, when they return home to Utah. ``There's a lot of screaming girls,'' Michael said. ``It makes it a lot more fun on stage.'' They released an album, ``The Osmond Boys,'' last month that includes a song written by Donny Osmond, ``Wait on Love.'' They're developing their own style _ no flashy costumes _ but Alan Osmond, who manages his Osmond Boys, said it's like reliving his past. ``Everyone says they've got the Osmond smile,'' he said. ``We've had a lot of screaming girls on this tour.'' He said he's trying to keep things as normal as possible, keeping them in their schools back home and faxing homework to their teachers.

Six years ago Andrew Dice Clay was banished from the Las Vegas Strip after one performance because his act was too raunchy. But the Diceman returneth. Clay had three sellout shows at Bally's resort last week and if Dice fans were fearful of him cleaning up his act, they need not have worried. One woman in the front row became a target for the evening of sexually explicit shots by the comedian as he graphically described his sexual appetite and questioned hers. Clay said he considers himself ``greatest comic that ever lived.'' ``I've created something so unique, so special, people are just going crazy for it,'' Clay said. ``I'm going to be around for a long time.'' He wasn't so confident six years ago when he was bounced from the lineup at the Comedy Store at the Dunes Hotel, across the Strip from Bally's, because of his foul language. He vowed he would be back and would someday see his name on the marquee of one of the Strip's glitzy resorts. He realized that goal when he returned Thursday. ``I figured the town just wasn't ready yet,'' he said of his first experience with Las Vegas. When it comes to Dallas, however, Clay apparently feels that city isn't ready for him. He canceled his Dallas concert because he's afraid of violating Texas' strict anti-obscenity law, his publicist said Friday. Michael Levine said Clay canceled the show, scheduled for Sunday, because ``we feared the possibility that Dice might be subject to arrest, embarrassment and subsequently jailed.''

Country music star Ronnie Milsap says in a new book that he has no love for his mother, who abandoned him. Milsap, who was born blind, said in his autobiography ``Almost Like a Song'' that she abandoned him when he was a 1-year-old infant. ``I don't hate her,'' he wrote. ``I have no feelings for her at all.'' Milsap said his mother once asked him for money after he became a successful entertainer. ``Why would I want to see her? Motherhood means more than just giving birth,'' he writes. The book, published recently by McGraw-Hill, is named after one of Milsap's hit records.

A television news helicopter crashed while filming the crowd at a concert by the New Kids on the Block. Two men aboard the aircraft were injured, officials said. The KTBS-TV Channel 3 helicopter apparently clipped a power line and crashed outside Independence Stadium about 6 p.m. Friday as crowds were gathering for the concert. No one on the ground was injured. Helicopter pilot Scott Wallace and KTBS photographer Norris Carden, both of Shreveport, were flying about 15 feet off the ground around the stadium to film the 25,000 fans arriving to see the 8 p.m. concert. ``They were doing traffic reports and Norris was shooting video of the lines,'' said KTBS news producer Sharon Rambin. ``I know they were landing but I don't know what happened.'' Hana Kanagawa, with a cinematic group from CBS-Sony Japan, saw the crash. ``I saw the helicopter flying, then bursting into the wires,'' she said. ``It wouldn't move. I saw sparks from the wires, and then it crashed.'' Wallace suffered cuts and bruises; Carden complained of severe back pains, said KTBS News Director Andrew Pontz. The men were kept overnight Willis-Knighton Medical Center for observation. The $75,000 helicopter was a total loss, Pontz said. The New Kids on Block, known for their intricately choreographed routines, their cheerful outlook and their anti-drug message, have had hits such as ``This One's For the Children,'' and ``I'll Be Loving You Forever.''

DOC.HEAD: Conservation `SWAT Team' Finds Scientific Riches And Plague In Forest
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: A conservation ``SWAT team'' has returned from an unexplored Bolivian forest with plants unknown to science, tales of spectacular animals, and a case of bubonic plague. The team's trip to northern La Paz province, Bolivia, was the first test of a method for surveying wilderness areas to determine whether they are deserving of protection or further study, said Russell Mittermeier, president of Conservation International in Washington, D.C., which devised the method. The month-long trip by four American field biologists and three of their counterparts in Bolivia revealed an area with one of the richest collections of plants and animals on Earth. ``It's really confirming that the region may be as diverse as the Manu National Park (in Peru), which is known to be the richest protected area on Earth in terms of biological diversity,'' Mittermeier said. The SWAT team _ known more properly as a ``RAP team,'' for rapid assessment program _ found 403 species of birds and 45 species of mammals, including three not previously known to exist in Bolivia. They were the spiny tree rat, the big-eared bat and the short-eared dog. ``For me, the most exciting thing was the sighting of this short-eared dog,'' said Mittermeier. It was spotted by Louise H. Emmons of the Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History. ``It's an extremely poorly known animal. She actually got a look at one with a frog in its mouth.'' That was the first observation ever of the animal feeding in the wild, Mittermeier said. Emmons also found something she wasn't looking for: fleas carrying bubonic plague, the black death of the Middle Ages. ``She came back and got sick, and they said `You've got the plague,''' Mittermeier said. ``They cured it, but she was out of it for a few weeks.'' The team also came back with hundreds of plant specimens, which they are now studying. ``Some of them are likely to be new to science,'' the team said in its report. The RAP team was led by Theodore A. Parker III of Conservation International and Louisiana State University, who is able to identify tropical birds from their songs. He concluded that the forest in La Paz may contain as many as 1,000 species of birds, or 11 percent of all the species on Earth. As a result of the RAP team's findings, ``the idea is to recommend some sort of protection for the area,'' said Mittermeier. The development of the RAP teams is part of Conservation International's effort to rapidly assess and protect what it calls the world's most important conservation hot spots. ``Science can proceed at a glacial pace, but forest destruction is spreading like wildfire,'' Mittermeier said. The RAP teams, he said, are ``cutting-edge biology'' that ``can put us one step ahead of deforestation.''

DOC.HEAD: State Denies Convicted Judge A Pension
DOC.TEXT: A judge who was convicted of corruption charges that included haranguing an aide into loaning him $500 was denied his pension and had more than $150,000 seized. The State Employees Retirement Board announced Friday it was denying pension for former Cambria County Judge Joseph O'Kicki. His retirement fund from 17 years on the bench, totaling $156,299, also was seized. The money will be used to pay $50,000 in fines O'Kicki owes and other costs, the board said. State Attorney General Ernie Preate Jr. has filed a claim in county court asking O'Kicki be held liable for $96,351 in investigative costs and $42,725 in trial costs. Board counsel Abbott A. Leban said he expects the attorney general will present those costs for payment from O'Kicki's pension contributions. O'Kicki, 59, was convicted in December 1989 for corruption charges and was sentenced in June to two to five years in prison. Prosecutors said the judge improperly solicited a lawyer for a $500 loan that never was repaid, asked for $500 from an aide who was promised a promotion that was never granted and had court aides, clerks and secretaries perform personal chores, such feeding his dogs and chopping wood. Senior Judge Richard Grifo of Northampton County has ordered O'Kicki to reimburse the state for about $140,000 in salary he received while he was suspended from the bench. O'Kicki has been free on $10,000 bond and planned to appeal his conviction. His lawyer, James Yelovich, was not in his office Friday afternoon and could not be reached for comment. The board said it had not calculated what O'Kicki's pension would have been if he had been eligible for benefits. The state contributes an amount equal to 12.3 percent of salary. O'Kicki made $80,000 a year.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Try To Reassure Smokers over Cigarette Shortage
With AM-Soviet-Mood, Bjt
LaserPhoto MOSB4
DOC.TEXT: Soviet authorities on Saturday sought to reassure smokers that there will be enough tobacco soon, following increasing public outrage over the worst cigarette shortage in decades. State-run newspapers reported that a Moscow factory had produced 45 million cigarettes in the previous 24 hours. The newspapers said a special command post was ensuring that the packs made it to tobacco kiosks instead of black marketeers, and that authorities were cracking down on such speculators. Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov tried to calm the nation's smokers _ estimated at 70 million out of a population of 285 milion _ on national television Friday night by similarly pledging that more cigarettes, both domestic and imported, were on the way. Ryzhkov also dodged responsibility for the crisis, saying that the shortage was not the fault of the central government but the leadership of the individual Soviet republics. He also blamed panic-buying by the public. Beneath a banner headline pleading ``Government, give us a smoke!'' Saturday's Komsomolskaya Pravda newspaper devoted its entire front page to the crisis, chronicling the various ``tobacco rebellions'' around the Soviet Union since July and reporting that an American pack of Marlboros would bring up to $32 on the black market in Moscow. The actions underscored how seriously national and local authorities are taking the summer-long cigarette shortage, especially after an upsurge in street demonstrations by angry smokers in Moscow and Leningrad. On Wednesday, scores of people blocked a street next to the Kremlin, the seat of Soviet power, until a nearby tobacco kiosk was restocked. The newspaper Moskovskaya Pravda reported that Muscovites will be getting ration coupons for tobacco products as a temporary, two-to three-month measure to combat hoarding and black market speculation. The newspaper also said one black marketeer killed a buyer over a pack of cigarettes in Moscow, but it provided no details. Komsomolskaya Pravda said that in the central Siberian city of Barnaul, one brand of Soviet cigarettes was being sold for 7 rubles ($11.20) on the black market. Soviet cigarettes usually sell for about 45 kopecks (about 80 cents) per pack. The Java cigarette factory, the main one in Moscow, turned out 45 million cigarettes since Friday and a freight car full of cigarettes from Bulgaria arrived Saturday, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda reported. ``We are trying for the most rational distribution,'' Pravda quoted Moscow City Council member A. Bobkov as saying. ``We're sending the bulk of the supply directly to workplaces and residential areas.'' In addition, he said the City Council has a ``special duty car'' to deliver a load of cigarettes to any ``hot spot,'' Pravda reported. Police arrested one cigarette delivery truck driver who made an unscheduled stop and was selling five cases of cigarettes at higher prices, the newspaper said. He was turned in to police by the distributor who was to have been the legitimate recipient of the cigarettes. Pravda said a criminal case was opened against a store owner who had stashed about 16,000 packs of cigarettes under the counter for resale at higher prices. In an interview with Pravda, L. Sinelnikov, director of the Java factory, disputed the central government's disclaimer of responsibility for cigarette production. He said half of his plant's equipment is obsolete and more than 20 years old. When he informed communist central planners, he said, he was told the problem was not serious and that the Soviet people should cut down on their heavy smoking anyway because it is a health hazard. In one corner of its front page, Komsomolskaya Pravda provided a 4-by-4{-inch blank spot to be cut out and used by its readers to roll their own cigarettes out of the loose, coarse tobacco that is being sold at some cigarette shops in the absense of proper paper and filters. Printed beneath the blank spot was a sardonic proviso: ``Typographic ink is hazardous to your health. Smoke only in the appointed place!''

DOC.HEAD: Rikers: `Every Day, a Slowly Brewing Riot'
DOC.TEXT: Correction officers at Rikers Island call the 3-to-11 shift at the nation's most populous jail ``the war tour.'' And they say the prisoners hold every advantage: in numbers, weapons and rules. Two weeks ago, about 600 guards tried to change the rules. For two days they blockaded the lone bridge to the island, turning back food, medical supplies and even the corrections commissioner. They relented only after city officials agreed to ease restrictions on use of force against inmates. ``Every day, Rikers is a slowly brewing riot,'' said Robert Gangi, director of the Correctional Association, a private research group that studies the jail. ``Usually it's the inmates who blow up, but here it was the COs who blew (by erecting the blockade). I've never heard of anything like it.'' The night the blockade ended, inmates in one unit rioted, and guards who quelled the rebellion allegedly lined up prisoners and systematically beat them with nightsticks. ``We control the jails, not you!'' guards were said to have shouted. When it was over, the injured included 142 inmates and 20 guards. Also hurt during that tense two days were eight emergency medical technicians _ the victims of attacks by guards at the blockade. A second major incident occurred this past week, after an inmate was stabbed by an unknown assailant Tuesday night. A group of inmates refused to return to their cells and began setting fires. By the time order was restored, 25 guards and four inmates had suffered minor injuries, mostly smoke inhalation. Although the blockade seemed to bring the jail to the edge of chaos, a union spokesman said it was a symptom, not a cause, of Rikers' malaise. ``The officers had come to the conclusion they were in danger,'' said Jim Grossman. ``They simply didn't feel safe anymore.'' Many never felt safe at a jail where the population doubled to 14,000 in 10 years, where prisoners routinely carry knives and homemade weapons, where there's an average of a stabbing a day. Each month for the past year and a half, the city's jail system has set a new record for violent incidents. Officers who directly supervise prisoners, meanwhile, carry no weapons. ``We don't scare anyone anymore,'' says Phil Seelig, president of the officers' union. The penal complex occupies 440 acres on a chunk of land in the East River. It houses all sorts of inmates: men and women, juveniles and adults, the convicted and the accused, the celebrated and the unknown. Always a violent, crowded place, Rikers in recent years has been flooded by an influx of drug outlaws, many of whom form gangs within the jail. Increasingly, the balance between order and anarchy has been determined by the prisoners themselves. Confronted with an exploding jail population, the city opted for relatively inexpensive and easily constructed open dormitories rather than conventional concrete and steel cell blocks. Each dorm accommodates about 50 inmates. In an interview published in Saturday's editions of The New York Times, Allyn R. Sielaff, who took over the city's jail system in March, criticized previous administrations for what he sees as spending too much energy expanding the jails and not enough on programs to make it safer. ``The dormitories were the quickest structures to put up, and the cheapest,'' he said. ``But they're the toughest structures to supervise.'' He also said he intends to reverse conditions at Rikers Island in which guards are swiftly punished for the most minor infractions while inmates get put on a waiting list. ``When an inmate stabs or slashes somebody, when he attacks an officer, one should expect he would be taken out of the general population,'' Sielaff said. ``We had 500 stabbers and slashers mingling with the rest of the population.'' But he also said that hiring standards for corrections officers have been too lax in recent years. Meanwhile, a federal judge is considering a new set of rules on the use of force by jail guards. The revised guidelines, agreed to by the Correction Department and Legal Aid attorneys, were submitted for approval Friday to U.S. District Judge Morris E. Lasker of Manhattan. Lasker scheduled another hearing next week. The Legal Aid Society began the court proceeding after the city decided to replace a 27-page directive on the use of force with a streamlined nine-page version as part of a settlement to a job action by guards at Rikers Island. Legal Aid had complained that the nine-page guidelines went too far in relaxing restraints on guards. The subsequent compromise list of rules, said Legal Aid attorney John Boston, ``restores all the important restrictions while removing excess verbiage. It is appropriate and serves everyone's purpose.'' But Ernesto Marrero, a lawyer for the officers' union, objected to specific language in the new directive as ``unduly restrictive.''

DOC.HEAD: Police: Hostage Taker Who Got $2,000 Ransom Thought He Would Get To Keep It
DOC.TEXT: A man who held a former business adviser hostage with a hunting rifle for three hours, saying the man's advice had not paid off, thought he would get to keep the $2,000 he received as ransom, police said. After Charles Edward Jordan accepted the cash from authorities, he tossed it inside his house, locked the door and surrendered. ``I'll be ready to go in a minute,'' Jordan reportedly told tactical officers who had their weapons leveled at him as he secured his house Friday in the South Oak Cliff section of Dallas. His hostage, Bruce Henry Humphrey of suburban Carrollton, was released unharmed. Jordan knew he was going to jail, ``but he thought he got to keep the $2,000,'' said Cpl. Joey Fox. Police later retrieved the money. Jordan was charged with aggravated kidnapping and was jailed on $25,000 bail Saturday. The hostage's wife, Fay Humphrey, said that Jordan, using another name, had called her husband repeatedly last week asking him to come to the house. Mrs. Humphrey said she and her husband work for a company that helps people prepare business plans to present to banks for financing. In 1988, Humphrey prepared a business plan for Jordan, charging him $2,000. Jordan used the plan but failed to find financing. The fee for producing the plan was non-refundable, police said.
