DOC.TEXT: Nations around the world hailed the United Nation's approval of force to back its embargo of Iraq, praising the decision as an act of international solidarity against Baghdad. However, Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi called the resolution a very dangerous endorsement of a ``fait accompli which is imposed by force.'' He was referring to the military buildup in the region by the United States, Britain, France and other countries opposed to Iraq. The Libyan leader sent a message to U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar complaining that ``this is very dangerous for it is a patched-up resolution taken under American pressure. ...,'' Libya's official JANA news agency said. The U.N. resolution, adopted 13-0 with Cuba and Yemen abstaining, authorized the various nations' navies assembled in the gulf region to use force if necessary to stop Iraqi trade. The White House hailed the U.N. resolution as strengthening ``world resolve to force Iraq out of Kuwait.'' President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, said the United Nations has given the Bush administration a free hand to enforce the economic embargo on Iraq. But he sidestepped a question of how much force America was willing to use. Scowcroft said on Cable News Network that the U.N. action ``means no commerce should go in and out (of Iraq) by sea, and that means that vessels will be stopped and inspected,'' effective immediately. In Moscow, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze warned Iraq to heed Saturday's U.N. vote: ``The results of the voting ... show the unanimity of the council with regard to measures to be taken in the existing situation. We hope that the Iraqi leadership will draw proper conclusions from this fact, will take steps to deescalate the conflict. ...'' France said the resolution was ``a very important act which is testimony to the international community's firmness and solidarity.'' It said French forces would apply the resolution ``with the necessary resolve.'' France has said its forces remain under French command, though they are coordinating with other countries. The U.N. Security Council decision was ``an act of historic significance and a landmark in the further course of international relations,'' Greek government spokesman Vyron Polydoras said. ``It demonstrates the will of the international community to serve justice and ethics,'' he said in a statement. Britain said that the U.N. decision displayed vital international unity. ``It is important that, contrary to what some people might have expected _ I think what Saddam Hussein expected _ the unity of the international community is not fraying; it is actually getting more close as time goes on,'' said William Waldegrave, second-ranking official in Britain's Foreign Office, during a news conference. In his comments, Waldegrave would not say what force British vessels in the gulf region would use. ``We will use, obviously, the minimum force necessary,'' he said. Saddam, Iraq's leader, ignited the international uproar with his Aug. 2 invasion of neighboring Kuwait. Iraq later annexed the oil-rich state. In a statement carried by Iraqi News Agency, Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz said the U.N. resolution ``did not come as a surprise to us, considering the frenzied efforts that have turned the Security Council into a tool for America's aggressive and unjust policy.'' In Venice, Italian Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis said the agreement of China and the Soviet Union was especially significant. He said Italian military authorities would give orders to the three Italian navy ships headed to the gulf ``on the basis of the U.N. resolution.'' He said rules of engagement would be discussed Monday among navy officials of the countries of the nine-nation Western European Union. Spain, Denmark and Canada were among the other nations that applauded the U.N. decision.

DOC.HEAD: Navajo Leader Pledges Support to U.S. Troops
DOC.TEXT: The interim president of the Navajos is encouraging members of the tribal nation to extend spiritual support to troops in the Middle East. ``In time of conflict or crisis, the Navajo People must unite and provide spiritual support for our Navajo brothers and sisters now awaiting warfare in the Middle East,'' Leonard Haskie said Friday. ``I urge each citizen of the Navajo Nation to pray for our loved ones who are out there to defend this country.'' An estimated 100 of the 1,000 Navajos in active duty are believed to have shipped out to the Middle East, the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: and Kuwait.
DOC.TEXT: Waldheim, the first Western leader to meet Saddam since the invasion, has been shunned by Western leaders because he concealed his links to a German army unit in World War II that has been implicated in atrocities. Saddam did not hesitate to use the visit by Waldheim, a former U.N. secretary-general, to again reject demands by the United Nations that he restore Kuwait's sovereignty and free the hostages. Saddam, at a news conference with Austrian reporters, said Iraqi troops will not withdraw from Kuwait and repeated that foreigners have been moved to strategic points, including missile bases and oil refineries. ``I shall say that whatever collides with Iraq will find columns of dead bodies which may have a beginning but may not have an end. We want the Americans to live. We do not want them to die. In the same way, we want the Iraqis to live and not die,'' Saddam told the Austrian reporters. ``So it is the duty of Americans now to bear in mind that they must resort to a political solution and not to force, and to end this tendency they have that they can have anything they want,'' he said. After leaving Iraq for Jordan on Saturday, Waldheim gave a lengthy interview to Cable News Network in which he said of Saddam: ``I have the impression that he still wants a negotiated settlement. ... I personally insisted that one should try to find such a settlement,'' Waldheim said. ``He realizes, of course, that the situation is very dangerous. ... He expressed his concern about the possibility of a military confrontation, saying that he would be prepared for that, but that he wants a negotiated solution and that he is still trying to get this.'' Saddam has repeatedly threatened to use trapped foreigners as human shields to protect Iraqi installations against an attack by tens of thousands of U.S. forces deployed in Saudi Arabia to contain Iraqi aggression. In another indication that Iraq is carrying out that plan, Japan's Foreign Ministry said 20 of its nationals and 20 other foreigners, mostly Caucasians, were moved by bus Saturday from a Baghdad hotel to an undisclosed location. The Security Council vote Saturday was a major victory for the United States, which had sought U.N. authority to use force in stopping trade with Iraq and thus force Saddam to end his 3-week-old occupation of Kuwait. The resolution allows navies in the gulf region ``to use such measures commensurate to the specific circumstances as may be necessary under the authority of the Security Council to halt all inward and outward maritime.'' Moscow had held up the resolution but later changed its position and said it may even join the naval force. Because it is one of five permanent Security Council members, the Soviet Union could have vetoed the measure. The United States says Iraq is still receiving goods and even military equipment. Iraqi oil tankers have recently anchored in Yemen's harbor, and Iraqi goods are still passing through Jordan's Red Sea port of Aqaba. It was not immediately clear what effect the U.N. resolution would have in Aqaba, where Iraqi and Jordanian imports are difficult to differentiate. The resolution covers only maritime shipping and not airlifts to Iraq. Yemen and Cuba were the only countries that abstained from the Security Council vote. Yemen's ambassador, Abdallah Saleh Al-Ashtal, warned that any military action backing the sanctions might lead to war. Yemen said Saturday that it was fully committed to honoring the U.N. embargo and denied reports it serves as a base for Iraqi warplanes. But diplomatic sources in the gulf region say Iraq has flown 12 captured Kuwaiti jet fighters to Yemen, and that prior to the invasion it had based 36 Soviet-made Iraqi jet fighters at Ta'ez south of Yemen's capital, San'a.

DOC.HEAD: National Parks Warned To Brace for Cutbacks, Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: National parks are being warned that they may have to fire some employees, put others on unpaid temporary leave or even shut down completely because of the federal budget crisis. ``We've sent a memo to every park superintendent telling them to dust off their contingency plans to reduce operations,'' said Harold Danz of Denver, the National Park Service's associate regional director for administration. ``That could come to even include closing of parks.'' Yellowstone National Park managers said Friday they had received the memo. Grand Teton National Park in Wyoming and Bighorn Canyon National Recreation Area and Glacier National Park, both in Montana, received similar memos and letters for employees, the Billings (Mont.) Gazette reported Saturday. The federal budget, already bogged down by a huge deficit, is being further stretched by the mounting costs of the massive U.S. military buildup in the Middle East. Unless Congress and the White House compromise on a budget by the end of next month, $100 billion in automatic cuts would take effect. Federal agencies have therefore taken the unusual step of warning employees that they might have to take unpaid furloughs of up to 22 days to keep costs down. National Park Service employees should receive the warning letters Monday, Yellowstone spokeswoman Marsha Karle said. U.S. Forest Service, Bureau of Land Management and other agencies will distribute similar letters next week. All federal workers are expected to receive similar letters by the end of the month. The last time a furlough was threatened was in 1982, when several thousand employees were kept from work for a few days. Cutbacks could hit Yellowstone especially hard. The summer staff is far smaller than in previous years snd rangers are struggling to keep up with a record number of visitors. ``We have fewer people doing more with less,'' Karle said. ``This is all going to be hard for folks to take with morale already down.'' Congress is far behind this year in passing an appropriations bill for the Department of the Interior. ``If there are no funds, there is no legal way to spend money,'' Danz said. ``But we have to look at an orderly closure.'' During World War II, he said, similar cutbacks were required because of military expenditures. National parks kept skeleton staffs in parks but shut down most of their public services. Karle said if reductions come, only top Yellowstone Park administrators and law enforcement rangers would probably continue working. ``We're going to keep the park open as long as we can,'' Karle said. ``But if we do run out of money, we may have to take hard steps to cut down.''

DOC.HEAD: Irish Hostage Says He Saw Americans During Captivity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to ADD new quotes from Keenan, sister; details; EDITS to trim; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DAM1
DOC.TEXT: Freed hostage Brian Keenan, who flew home to Ireland Saturday, said he saw American hostages Terry Anderson and Thomas Sutherland during his four-year captivity in Lebanon and that both had been well. ``It's an understatement to say I'm delighted to be home,'' he said, his voice breaking as he read a statement in Dublin. ``It's where the heart is, you know.'' Keenan, 39, looking pale but otherwise physically fit, earlier had an emotional reunion with his two sisters in the Syrian capital, Damascus, almost 24 hours after he was freed by his captors in Beirut. In his comments in Damascus, he did not say when he had seen the two Americans. He described Anderson as being comforted by a picture of his daughter, Sulome, and said Sutherland entertained his fellow hostages with jokes and stories. He said he had seen British hostage John McCarthy only two days ago, but did not mention any other hostages. His hair cut short and his beard neatly trimmed, Keenan struggled to hold back tears as he sat between his sisters, Elaine Spence and Brenda Gillham. He read the statement to reporters in Dublin but took no questions. Keenan said he had spent ``a long 4{ years (in captivity) and it sometimes seemed like 4{ lifetimes.'' ``On my way here, I thought of what I was going to do,'' he told reporters. ``And finally, I said to myself I would eat all the food in the world, drink all the drink in the world and make love to all the women in the world, and then maybe I'll get a good night sleep.'' Keenan said he was overwhelmed by his homecoming, ``but another part of me goes back to those men who are left behind. ``They're somewhere out there; somewhere in here,'' he said, pointing toward his heart. After Keenan left, his sisters spoke briefly with reporters. ``As you see he still has his wit and his humor. His character is still very strong. He is the same Brian that left us 4{ years ago,'' said Mrs. Spence. Asked why her brother's voice was so weak, Mrs. Spence said he spoke in a whisper because he communicated that way with the other hostages and hasn't gotten used to raising his voice yet. Keenan's sisters arrived in Syria with Irish Foreign Minister Gerry Collins and a doctor and a nurse. They all flew back to Ireland three hours after Keenan was formally turned over to Collins at the Syrian Foreign Ministry. A welcoming cheer went up as Keenan stepped off a government jet at Dublin airport onto a red carpet. He was warmly embraced by Prime Minister Charles Haughey. Keenan opened his arms to the crowd and then clasped his hands over his head in delight. Keenan, wearing a sweater his mother had knit for him, clasped his two sisters to him and blew kisses to the crowd of about 500 before going into the VIP lounge for a private reunion with more than 20 relatives. In Damascus, he told reporters, ``I saw Terry Anderson some time ago. ``He's in good form ... and he appreciates the letters that he received from his family.'' Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest held of the 13 Westerners believed held captive by Moslem extremists in Lebanon. He was abducted March 16, 1985. Anderson and Sutherland are among six Americans remaining in captivity, along with two West Germans, an Italian and four Britons. Of Sutherland, 56, of Fort Collins, Colo., Keenan said: ``He's well.'' ``He has told us an entire repertoire of jokes ... and Dr. Sutherland is in good health and regularly exercising,'' Keenan said. Sutherland was kidnapped June 9, 1985. Anderson has never seen his 5-year-old daughter, who was born almost three months after he was kidnapped. But Keenan said, ``He has a picture of his daughter, Sulome, which is some great companionship for him.'' Keenan also said he had seen McCarthy, a reporter for the London-based Worldwide Television News, two nights ago. He said McCarthy was well. ``John's good humor... was very much appreciated and brought in all of us who came in contact with him a real sense of the outside world,'' Keenan said. McCarthy, 33, was captured April 17, 1986. The other Britons are Terry Waite, the envoy of the Archbishop of Canterbury, and Alec Collett and Jack Mann. Waite disappeared in Beirut on Jan. 20, 1987, while seeking the release of other hostages. Anderson's sister Peggy Say, told of Keenan's comments, said: ``I'm anxious to talk to Brian and to get more details about Terry's mental, emotional and physical health.'' ``Of course, I'm very pleased for the Keenan sisters and their family. But unfortunately, our experience has been in the past that when a single hostage is released, that doesn't necessarily mean that we are going to see another one for some time,'' she said by telephone from her home in Kentucky. Keenan was handed over Friday to Syrian army officers in Beirut, the Lebanese capital, after a little-known group calling itself The Organization of the Islamic Dawn said he would be released. Until the kidnappers' statement Friday, no group had claimed responsibility for Keenan from the time he was abducted until he was freed. The fifth Western hostage freed in as many months, Keenan was kidnapped April 11, 1986, in west Beirut while walking to the American University where he taught English. He was born in Belfast and was traveling on an Irish passport, but he has dual Irish-British citizenship. Prior to Keenan's release, the only other statement on hostages from The Organization of Islamic Dawn was when it announced April 30 it was releasing Frank Reed, an education administrator from Malden, Mass. Hostage Robert Polhill of New York was freed April 22, and two Swiss Red Cross workers, Elio Erriquez and Emmanuel Christen, were freed this month.

DOC.HEAD: US Forces Mark Iraq Targets: `If We Go, We'll Go All Out'
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 2nd graf to insert dropped word ``City'' after Kuwait and shortens lead by deleting reference to specific potential targets, which are mentioned lower; Note language in 12th graf, bgng: ``I came ...
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: The following is based on a pool dispatch.

The map of Iraq is elaborately marked and circled, pinpointing potential targets if shots are fired in the Persian Gulf standoff. Until recent days, U.S. military planners focused on Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's troop positions, including a concentration of forces along the Kuwait-Saudi border, a crescent-shaped formation further north near Kuwait City and supply routes back to Iraq. Now convinced there is enough U.S. firepower on the ground to thwart any Iraqi attack, strategists at the American command post here are mulling ways to use their might against Iraq should hostilities erupt. ``Right after the invasion of Kuwait, we had to hurry, so it was a come-as-you-are war,'' a Pentagon source said. ``That was more than two weeks ago. Now, for us, it's a do-as-you-please war.'' There are numerous political, economic and military factors that would influence any decision to make an all-out assault on Iraq, an attack that American officials stress is highly unlikely unless Iraq fires first. Complicating all planning is Iraq's grasp on some 10,000 Western hostages, including 3,000 Americans. But it is clear from interviews and reviews of U.S. intelligence and planning over the past week that such a plan is in place and being refined virtually daily, as spy satellites, AWACS tracking planes and other intelligence sources provide information on Iraqi military activities. After spending their first week here reluctant to discuss contingency plans, many officers in the past week, at several command levels, have discussed such plans privately, if for no other reason than to send a signal to Saddam. ``We know when they are loading gas into their trucks,'' an Army colonel said Friday. ``We'll be ready if they come, and ready to go after them too.'' Vietnam-era generals leading the deployment in Saudi Arabia favor an overwhelming attack on Iraq if fighting erupts. That would include destruction of key government facilities in Baghdad, Iraqi oil fields and military installations and infrastructure used to resupply Iraqi forces in Kuwait and near Iraq's border with Saudi Arabia, according to a number of military sources here. The command post for the Persian Gulf deployment, dubbed Operation Desert Shield, has been at the Central Command headquarters in Florida, but a makeshift war room will be opened in Saudi Arabia within days. ``I came out of one briefing the other day hearing B-52s humming in my head,'' one senior officer said this past week. A field commander privy to some of the contingency plans put it this way: ``These guys have decided if we go, we go all out, none of this halfway bull shit.'' The options, according to the officials, include bombing runs, use of naval firepower from a battleship and other ships in the Persian Gulf, and even ground forces if necessary to knock out key Iraqi installations and block supply and communications routes. American aircraft have been flying 24 hours a day on practice missions and to counter Iraqi air patrols. Elements of the 82nd and 101st airborne divisions have been briefed on possible Iraqi targets. The 82nd consists of paratroopers; the 101st has attack helicopters and can deploy infantry from helicopters as well. Members of the 82nd have been told their division might be dropped into Iraq or just over its border with Kuwait to cut off supply routes, according to the sources. Massive amounts of U.S. military force continue to pour into Saudi Arabia and the waters that surround the Arabian peninsula. For example, the first shipments of huge M-1 tanks are just offshore and once unloaded will immediately move to forward positions in the Saudi desert. The M-1s, from the Army's 24th Infantry Division (Mechanized), will join Marine M60-A1 tanks already on the ground. Backing up the tanks are formidable deployments of tank-fighting helicopters, A-10 planes and other heavy weapons stationed in the Saudi desert _ some at airstrips not even on most maps. These strips are well within striking distance of Iraqi targets in both Kuwait and Iraq. A ground war against entrenched Iraqi positions in Kuwait would be bloody, planners say, and the air attacks necessary to support the ground troops likely would level much of Kuwait. Kuwaiti government officials, now living in exile in Saudi Arabia, have implored U.S. officials not to wage such a fight. Less bloody, and potentially devastating to Saddam's power, would be a direct assault on selected Iraqi targets, which if successful would create chaos in the government and choke off supplies and reinforcements to the Iraqi forces in Kuwait. Air Force jets stationed in Saudi Arabia and on Navy carriers in the Persian Gulf and Red Sea are within range of Iraqi targets, as are F-111 bombers in Turkey and long-range B-52s from Diego Garcia. The Pentagon said Saturday that more F-111s, which the United States has used previously against Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi, were being moved from Britain to Saudi Arabia. U.S. officials believe there is enough firepower here to defend Saudi Arabia from any forward attack from Kuwaiti territory during such an assault on Iraq. There are concerns that Iraq would launch chemical-carrying Scud missiles into Saudi Arabia if the United States moved against Iraqi targets. But American and Saudi military officials say the missiles travel slowly, and jets and ground-to-air missile systems should be able to destroy them in flight. Saudi officials this week confirmed reports that Scud launchers had been moved into Kuwait. However, an American military intelligence source disputed that, while acknowledging that Scuds stationed in southern Iraq still could reach Saudi targets.

DOC.HEAD: GAO: U.S. Information Agency Overrated Viewership
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `The station...' with 2 grafs to CLARIFY that jamming does not totally eliminate signal, explain hours for programming
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration has vastly overestimated the viewership of TV Marti, whose broadcast since March has been marked by Cuban government jamming, according to a report Saturday. The U.S. Information Agency estimated that 1 million to 7 million Cubans watched the new station, which broadcast American entertainment and news shows to the communist-ruled island from Florida. But the General Accounting Office, in an unpublished report obtained by The Miami Herald, cited notes by U.S. diplomats who estimated an audience of only 50,000 to 70,000. The GAO, the investigative arm of Congress, faulted the USIA's methods in two viewership surveys, which polled Cuban refugees and emigres arriving at Miami International Airport between March 28 and May 12. The survey subjects ``would be more interested in and aware of TV Marti than the general population'' because they were leaving Cuba, the GAO report said. The first report prepared by USIA's Radio Marti research and policy staff in Miami concluded the station was ``received in practically all of the Cuban territory with acceptable quality'' for potential viewing by 7.3 million Cubans. A second report prepared by a research firm under contract to USIA estimated 1 million to 1.3 million Cubans tuned in during the station's first six weeks on the air. The station began transmitting on March 27. Its signal frequently is beamed to Havana from 3:45 a.m. to 5:59 a.m., when state-run stations are not transmitting. Officials have said TV Marti's directors do not want to overlap with Cuban stations both for technical reasons and to avoid further aggravating the Cuban government. TV Marti's signal often is partially blocked by Cuban jamming. GAO investigators said 21 percent of the 112 airport arrivals who responded to the USIA survey said they watched TV Marti on four days when there were no broadcasts. The GAO report was requested by U.S. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the House Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations. TV Marti is an extension of the Radio Marti coverage launched by the Reagan administration in its campaign against Cuban president Fidel Castro.

DOC.HEAD: South African Soldiers Join Crackdown on Factional Street Fighting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 16 grafs for 5-16 bgng `Police said...' to UPDATE with grenade blast at train station, one killed; defense minister's comment; pickup graf 17 pvs `Zulu leader...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto JOH3
DOC.TEXT: Elite army troops joined police patrols in black townships Saturday as part of a government crackdown on factional fighting that has killed more than 500 people. Soldiers wearing full combat gear went door-to-door at migrant worker hostels in the Vosloorus township southeast of Johannesburg, confiscating the crude weapons used in street fighting between Zulus and township residents. Armored police vehicles stood guard as the soldiers rounded up spears, knives, machetes, clubs and other weapons. No serious fighting was reported for a second straight day in the townships near Johannesburg after almost two weeks of clashes between Zulu backers of the conservative Inkatha political movement and Xhosas mostly loyal to the African National Congress. However, a grenade exploded late Saturday at a train station east of Johannesburg, killing one person and injuring two, police told the independent South African Press Association. Several recent blasts in the Johannesburg area have been blamed on extreme right-wing whites opposed to government moves toward sharing power with the disenfranchised black majority. Police said two more bodies from the factional fighting were found Saturday, increasing the death toll to 514 since fighting erupted Aug. 12. Government officials said 18,000 people had been left homeless by the conflict. On Friday, the government declared the townships around Johannesburg ``unrest areas,'' giving police widespread powers to suppress violence. It also ordered in more soldiers and police to control the chaos. Demonstrations against the violence and alleged police bias toward Inkatha were held in several cities Saturday. In Cape Town, about 250 members of the ANC Women's League marched to criticize the government for waiting so long to curb the fighting. The Soweto Civic Association called a work stayaway in the township for Monday to ``protest the violence, police behavior and to mourn our dead.'' More than 120 people have died in Soweto since the fighting began. Police have denied accusations that they sided with Inkatha fighters in the clashes. President F.W. de Klerk said Friday that while a few individuals may have acted improperly, the force as a whole followed orders to be impartial. Army commanders said three elite paratroop and infantry battalions were being sent to the townships to aid police, along with a battalion of exiled black Angolans who fought that country's communist government in the mid-1970s. The ANC has charged that some members of the Angolan battalion terrorized South African blacks in Natal Province earlier this year. Army officials declined to say how many troops were involved, but most South African battalions have at least 500 soldiers. About 1,000 police and troops raided Kagiso township late Friday and seized a large number of weapons, officials said. Police Capt. Eugene Opperman said such raids might be conducted regularly. The government lifted a nationwide state of emergency in June in all provinces except Natal, where fighting between Inkatha and ANC forces has claimed about 5,000 lives in the past five years. The ANC had demanded lifting of the state of emergency as a condition of formal talks with the white-led government on a new constitution. ANC leader Nelson Mandela said Friday the new emergency measures were unnecessary but would not derail negotiations with the government on ending apartheid and sharing power with the black majority. On Saturday, Defense Minister Gen. Magnus Malan said the ANC continued to advocate violence, despite telling the government it had suspended its armed struggle. Malan also said black leaders should quit blaming each other for the violence and work together toward peace. Zulu leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi on Saturday accused the ANC of starting the Johannesburg area violence. It was the latest in a series of charges and counterclaims by the rival black opposition movements. Buthelezi says the ANC is terrorizing Inkatha members to try to wipe out any competition for power among black groups. The ANC claims Inkatha spread the political violence from Natal to the Johannesburg area to try to broaden its constituency.

DOC.HEAD: Quintuplet Families Gather to Swap Tales
DOC.TEXT: The worst part about being a quintuplet isn't the stares and finger-pointing of strangers. It's wearing the same clothes as four other kids born at the same time who look like you. ``Whenever one of us spilled, all of us would have to go back home and change,'' said Chanda Davis, 15. Davis, of Winnsboro, Texas, is literally one in a hundred. There are only 20 full sets _ meaning all five children are still alive _ in North America. Nine of those families gathered in Chicago's Grant Park Saturday in a promotional event for New Jersey-based Tyco Industries, Inc., which was introducing its new line of dolls, The Quints. Seventeen of the 20 mothers took fertility drugs, said Helen Kirk, a board member for the Center for Study of Multiple Birth. The Chicago-based center is an information and research center for mothers carrying more than one child. The quintuplets and their parents spent the day tossing water balloons, picnicking and talking about the trials and joys of family life times five. Raising quintuplets is much like raising any other large family, parents said. Many said they don't dress young quintuplets alike out of spite _ it's an easy way to keep track of them in a crowded mall. ``I know immediately what to look for,'' said Amy Chikaraishi of Glenview, a suburb north of Chicago. ``I just do a quick head count and if I'm one short, it's easier to find them.'' Making sure each of his five-year-olds receives an equal amount of attention and affection is one of the biggest chores for Gregory Miller, a truck driver and supervisor in Bennett, Colo. ``Because they're all the same age, you can't spend time with one-on-one activity, then time with another one doing something different,'' Miller said. ``At the same time, you can't just treat them as a group. ``We noticed that they were individuals with different personalities right away, so we started treating them like that,'' he said. In the past five years, Miller said he's learned to be more patient. ``Forget taking family pictures _ it's ridiculous,'' Miller said, as event organizers frantically tried to round up all 45 children and keep them in one place long enough for photographers to snap a picture. Not all quintuplets look alike, but those who do say outsiders have trouble keeping them straight. ``Our teachers give up on our names,'' Davis said. ``They wind up just pointing or saying, `You, there.''' It's not the only time Davis minds someone pointing at her. ``We hate it when people talk about it too much,'' Davis said. ``People still point and stare.'' But she and her four identical sisters, Christa, Casey, Charla and Chelsa do have some advantages. ``We get to share clothes,'' she said. ``And we spend a lot of time together as a family. We've always done that.''

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Storm Gustav, Depression Continue to Strengthen
DOC.TEXT: Two storms were gaining strength in the eastern Atlantic Ocean Saturday _ Tropical Storm Gustav and the ninth tropical depression of the season, forecasters said. ``Both are Cape Verde-type storms,'' said hurricane specialist Noel Risnychok of the National Hurricane Center in Coral Gables. ``They are typical for this time of year.'' Cape Verde storms _ named for a chain of islands off the west coast of Africa _ have been some of history's most destructive, he said. Gustav slid west at 15 miles per hour Saturday toward the Lesser Antilles and the depression moved into the open Atlantic, forecasters said. Gustav, the seventh named tropical storm of the 1990 Atlantic hurricane season, had top sustained winds of 50 miles per hour at 6 p.m. EDT and was centered near 14.0 north latitude and 53.1 west longitude, or about 515 miles east of the Lesser Antilles, Risnychok said. Gustav was expected to maintain that motion through tonight and no change in strength is expected, Risnychok said. The depression formed Friday morning, meanwhile, by Saturday was located near 13.7 north latitude and 40.0 west longitude, or about 850 miles west southwest of the Cape Verde Islands. It was moving west with maximum sustained winds of 35 mph and had a chance of strengthening into tropical storm Hortense late Saturday night, Risnychok said. ``It only has to increase a few miles per hour, so the chances are good,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Customers Spooked by Alleged Ghost in Disney Video
LaserPhoto SAN1 of Aug. 24
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Jon is CQ in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: Stories of a ghost lurking in a scene in the movie ``Three Men and a Baby'' are scaring up business for video stores nationwide. ``I was never a firm believer in ghosts or anything, but I'll tell you the truth, it made the hair stand up on my arms,'' said Jon Roup, who works at Network Video in Pittsburgh, which was besieged by requests for the movie. Staff and customers of Music Plus in Marina del Rey, Calif., looked for the eerie figure Friday before all copies of the comedy were rented. ``Everybody who's walked into the store today wants this movie,'' said operations manager Ryan Bicknell. Viewers are transfixed by a scene in which Ted Danson and Celeste Holm, co-starring as Danson's mother, walk by a window in a home shared by characters portrayed by Danson, Tom Selleck and Steve Guttenberg. Partially obscured in the window is what appears to many viewers to be a young boy hiding behind a curtain. Some callers claim the figure is the ghost of a child who died in a home where the film was shot. But Disney spokesman Steve Feldstein said viewers actually are looking at a cardboard cutout or standee of a man in top hat and tails. The 1987 movie was filmed on a Toronto sound stage, not a private home, he said. Feldstein said the cutout was part of the set; a promotional device for Danson's character in the movie. ``It doesn't look like a ghost,'' said Aaron Chu, the sales rep at Movies and More in Los Angeles, which rented all eight of its copies. ``There's no third dimension to the figure.'' Despite Disney's explanation, many customers cling to their ghostly beliefs. After all, ``Three Men'' was directed by Leonard Nimoy, the former host of ``In Search Of,'' a television show tracking strange phenomena. ``I believe it's just some kind of freak of nature or something,'' said Tony Hostler, an employee at the Best Video Rentals store in Pittsburgh. ``I put standups up all the time in here, and it isn't big enough. You can't make out the kid's face, and on a real standup they make sure you can.'' Even before the craze, ``Three Men and a Baby'' was the No. 1 rental title in video history, according to Billboard magazine.

DOC.HEAD: `Other' Jogger Rape Trial Doesn't Provoke Racial Outcry
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, `The situation.. and 15th graf, `The passage...' to CORRECT name to Robinson sted Johnson
Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: As jurors in New York City weighed the fate of three teen-agers charged in the Cental Park jogger case, a jury 300 miles away heard the gruesome details of an attack on another jogger raped and left to die. Two days after the three teen-age defendants in New York were convicted for the Central Park attack, jurors in Syracuse on Monday found 23-year-old Erwin Williams guilty of the 1986 rape and attempted murder of a suburban woman. Both victims were women running alone, attacked by strangers they were later unable to identify. Both trials involved black or Hispanic defendants charged with attacking a white victim. But the Williams trial aroused little of the outcry that grew up around the Central Park case. The New York trial was marked by national media attention, demonstrations outside the courthouse and accusations of racism by some black New Yorkers. In Syracuse, ``the racial thing has not come up at all,'' said county legislator William Sanford, the first person to see the jogger after the attack. ``It was bigger than that. It wasn't black or white, it was just two animals out there ... nothing but animals.'' The 40-year-old woman was raped, stabbed 11 times with a penknife and left tied to a stake in the ground on Sept. 20, 1986. As her attackers left, one said ``Die, bitch, die,'' she testified in court. With the knife still protruding from her neck and one lung partially collapsed, the woman freed herself and walked more than a mile along the trail to Sanford's boathouse home. A second defendant, 32-year-old Ronald Jock, pleaded guilty in July to attempted murder and testified against Williams. Even the plea bargain agreement with Jock, who is white, drew no protest except from Williams' relatives, said defense attorney William Rose. Williams is black. Assistant District Attorney Mary Felasco said the plea bargain was offered to Jock because the victim did not want to testify at two trials. Jock said his only involvement was tying the woman's hands together and the victim's statements corroborated that, Felasco said. ``It wasn't a racial issue,'' she said. ``Throughout our investigation, Ronald Jock appeared to be the less culpable of the two.'' The situation in New York was one of a series of highly publicized, racially charged incidents that have plagued that city, said Van Robinson, president of the Syracuse branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. While Syracuse is not immune to racial conflict, he said, ``you don't have the heightened racial tensions here that you have in New York.'' Some 150,00 people live in Syracuse and of them, roughly 16 percent are black. The passage of time between the attack and the arrests also helped calm emotions, Robinson said. Arrests in the Central Park case came within days of the April 1989 incident. In Syracuse, it was more than 3{ years after the September 1986 attack before Jock and Williams were arrested. Police received anonymous tips fingering the pair shortly after the attack, but it was not until March 1990 that Williams' estranged wife came forward with evidence that would end the investigation. Outrage over the crime has not diminished, but has been tempered by time, Sanford agreed. ``You go back four years, there was community response,'' he said. ``The outpouring was tremendous.'' Williams was 19 when he and Jock attacked the woman as she neared the end of a 9-mile jog along the running trail at Onondaga Lake Park in Geddes, a suburb of Syracuse. There in the leafy woods beside the trail, the jogger was raped and stabbed. The woman testified that the man who tried to strangle her said, ``She just won't die. She won't die.'' ``She's an amazing woman,'' said Sanford. ``I don't think I ever saw her in a situation where she wasn't in control. I think she was an unbelievable example of the extent that a person can control her destiny, whether she was going to live or die.'' Sanford said the arrests and convictions give him a feeling of relief that he hopes the victim shares.

DOC.HEAD: Scowcroft: U.S. Now Has Free Hand To Enforce Embargo
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts grafs 7-9, ``Meanwhile, the New York xxx to include report of possible political asylum for Iraqi tanker crews
DOC.TEXT: The United Nations has given the Bush administration a free hand to enforce the economic embargo against Iraq, President Bush's national security adviser said Saturday. But Brent Scowcroft sidestepped a question of how much force the United States was willing to use to choke off commerce to and from Iraq. Asked during a Cable News Network interview whether the United States planned to board, seize or even sink ships moving goods between Iraq and other nations, Scowcroft said only that American vessels will use ``the minimum amount of interference with traffic in order to make the sanctions effective.'' The U.N. Security Council early Saturday adopted a resolution calling for military enforcement of the embargo against Iraq. The resolution was approved 13-0, with Cuba and Yemen abstaining. Scowcroft said the U.N. action ``means no commerce should go in and out (of Iraq) by sea and that means that vessels will be stopped and inspected,'' effective immediately. Asked whether the United States now had a free hand in the Persian Gulf to do as it wants in enforcing the blockade, he said ``I believe that's the case.'' Meanwhile, the New York Times reported in Sunday's editions that the administration is studying the possibility of offering political asylum to the crews of Iraqi vessels to persuade them to cooperate with the embargo. The idea is to persuade the crews to give up without resorting to violence, the paper reported, quoting administration and Pentagon officials who spoke on condition of anonymity. American intelligence officials say the tanker crews are under orders from Baghdad to ignore warnings to halt, even if fired upon, and face execution if they allow U.S. forces to board, the paper said. At the Pentagon, a senior official who spoke on condition of anonymity said he did not foresee any immediate conflict involving ships, and that the two Iraqi ships the Navy fired upon last weekend were continuing to be monitored. ``I don't sense that there's anything out there about to happen'' because of the U.N. action, the official said. Scowcroft's comments came as administration officials protested the interruption of electricity to the U.S. Embassy in Iraqi-occupied Kuwait and as Iraq's ambassador to the United States said the wives and children of American diplomats who fled Kuwait to Baghdad were free to go. U.S. officials said Iraqi soldiers maintained their blockade of the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait City and the embassy was operating on generator power. Water also had been cut off. White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk said the administration had expressed its objections through diplomatic channels in Baghdad, Kuwait and Washington. ``The embassy continues to function. It is carrying out its consular functions,'' said Popadiuk, in Maine with the vacationing Bush. He added, ``A small contingent of Iraqi soldiers ... continues to maintain its presence outside the embassy.'' Bush received an intelligence briefing and monitored the situation while continuing his three-week vacation. The Voice of America radio advised the 2,500 Americans trapped in Kuwait not to go near the embassy while the soldiers remained, even though there appeared to be no attempt to take over the compound. The State Department broadcast on VOA said the embassy was ``determined to continue working for your release from Kuwait and your safe return to your families.'' Scowcroft said the power had apparently been returned to the British embassy but that it was ``a very fluid situation'' at all the western diplomatic missions. U.S. officials said telephone service to Kuwait was sporadic, but they were maintaining phone contact with Ambassador Nathaniel Howell and his staff of about 10 diplomats, who stayed behind to keep the embassy open in defiance of Iraq's order to close it on Friday. Scowcroft said negotiations were under way in Baghdad to permit the departure of some 100 U.S. diplomats and dependents who were being detained after they evacuated the embassy in Kuwait on an Iraqi promise they could leave from the Iraqi capital. Mohamed Sadiq al-Mashat, Iraq's ambassador to the United States, said Saturday in Washington the wives and children of American diplomats who fled Kuwait to Baghdad were free to go but that the diplomats would be treated ``just like anybody else.'' He did not register any direct threat to the diplomats or any of the more than 3,000 U.S. citizens trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, in a television news conference Saturday, warned the United States to pursue a diplomatic solution to the volatile situation or risk great bloodshed. The White House welcomed the U.N. vote. In a statement from Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater, the administration singled out Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev for praise. Moscow voted for the resolution after balking for several days. Gorbachev sent an urgent message Friday to Saddam urging him to comply with the U.N. orders to get out of Kuwait. Gorbachev's statement ``was a very important development,'' Fitzwater said. Meanwhile, the Navy announced Saturday that it had called up 127 reserve units from 34 states and the District of Columbia. In addition, the Army released a list of 173 National Guard and reserve units from 37 states, Puerto Rico and the District of Columbia it said might be called to duty before Oct. 1. In Omaha, Neb., the Air Force's Strategic Air Command confirmed that it sent B-52 heavy bombers from two U.S. air bases overseas two weeks ago. SAC did not, however, indicate how many had been dispatched or where they had been sent. The U.S. response to the Persian Gulf crisis sparked a demonstration Saturday in front of the White House. The National Park Service said there were about 140 participants.

DOC.HEAD: Arts Organizations Stop Shows To Protest NEA Cuts And Censorship
DOC.TEXT: The Boston Symphony Orchestra players tuned, then laid down their instruments before a note had been played. Stage lights blinked off during a performance of Shakespeare. Unemployed ballet dancers lighted candles in a vigil. All around the Berkshire hills, at precisely 8:30 p.m. Saturday night, about 30 groups taking part in the traditional summer festival stopped dead for three minutes to protest reduced government funding and censorship of the arts, said ``arts blackout'' organizer Frank Bessel. ``The primary consideration is to recognize culture as a priority, even as an election issue. More and more people are not getting (a moral education) or they're getting it from television sitcoms,'' said Bessel, artistic director of the Berkshire Public Theatre in Pittsfield, in western Massachusetts. The protest also was aimed at the National Endowment for the Arts, which has cut the funding of some controversial artists. At Tanglewood, a retreat for The Boston Symphony Orchestra, Managing Director Kenneth Haas stopped the musicians shortly after they tuned their instruments, said BSO spokeswoman Kim Smedvig. Haas told the audience of 10,000 that ``across the Berkshires at this moment, theater, dance and musical performances are being interrupted or delayed to request a few minutes of reflection on the importance of art in our lives and the problems we are facing as result of a loss of government support.'' The symphony, the most popular cultural attraction in the Berkshires, has spent each summer since 1937 at the former country estate in Lenox, about 130 miles west of Boston. Lenox' population of 6,500 doubles each summer as urbanites arrive to beat the heat and immerse themselves in the arts.The local economies rely heavily on the tourist trade. In nearby Pittsfield, about 100 members of Berkshire Ballet and their supporters held a candlelight vigil. The dancers lost their jobs when the summer season was canceled because of cuts in federal and state arts funding. At Shakespeare & Company in Lenox, the stage lights went down and actors stopped the comedy ``As You Like It'' at the end of a wrestling scene. ``Because we're outdoors, it was in complete darkness. (The audience) could see the outline of the white clothing of the actors on stage. And when the lights were restored, the audience applauded,'' said Dennis Krausnick, the company's managing director. The last line before the blackout was ``bear him away,'' said Krausnick. ``We thought it was appropriate because that's what might happen to the arts.'' The Hubbard Street Dance Company from Chicago, performing at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in nearby Becket, delayed the start of ``Read My Hips,'' an American jazz dance piece choreographed by Daniel Ezrlow, said Sam Miller, a festival spokesman. The Berkshire Public Theatre is showing Larry Gelbart's ``Mastergate,'' a political farce based on the Iran@Contra scandal. The lights went down just as an actor portraying a senator investigating the scandal rapped his gavel three times.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqis Detain Pregnant Woman, More Britons; Teen-ager Returns Home
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi troops detained four Britons, including a pregnant woman, in Kuwait on Saturday, but a British teen-ager returned home after being released on orders of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher condemned the detention of the pregnant woman as ``totally contemptible behavior.'' The woman, who is due to give birth in two or three weeks, was stopped by Iraqi soldiers at a roadblock in Kuwait City as she was returning from a checkup at a clinic, the Foreign Office said. She is being held with her husband at a hotel, the Foreign Office said. Three other Britons were also detained in Kuwait City. That brings to 139 the number of Britons seized by Iraqis since they invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and annexed the oil-rich emirate. A protest about the detentions was lodged by the remaining officials at the British Embassy in Kuwait City, which was surrounded by Iraqi troops armed with machine guns and mortars. Meanwhile, in London, 15-year-old Alan Barnett enjoyed a reunion with his parents at Gatwick Airport. He was one of the British hostages shown meeting Saddam in a tape broadcast Thursday on Iraq's state television and shown worldwide. The 15-year-old said he had brought a package of letters from other hostages to be delivered to their relatives at home. He said he and the other hostages were not mistreated by the Iraqis. ``We were given a fair amount of freedom, and the Iraqis were quite nice to us. They didn't push us around or anything like that,'' he said. He said the people he left behind ``are close together and fine. But they are expecting to be held for several weeks or even months.'' The teen-ager said he had been traveling alone on a British Airways flight heading from London to Madras, India and Malaysia that was stranded in Kuwait City during the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion. He was later taken to Baghdad with other Britons and Americans on the flight. In Baghdad, the hostages met with Saddam. ``Everyone was happy that their questions were answered on the video,'' he said. ``We didn't know in advance we were going to be filmed. Everyone at the recording was quite relaxed.'' He said his release followed an order from Saddam. ``One of my friend's mothers told the president I was 15 years old and unaccompanied,'' he said. ``The president, through a translator, asked me if I wanted to leave. I said `yes.' The next thing I heard was that I was going home.'' He added: ``I just wish they had let everyone else go as well.'' He flew from Baghdad to the Jordanian capital of Amman on Thursday and then waited for a flight home.

DOC.HEAD: Haiti's President Replaces Five Ministers After Resignations
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot replaced five Cabinet members who resigned amid growing dissatisfaction with her administration, the independent Radio Inter reported Saturday. The five ministers resigned Friday, and their replacements will be sworn in Monday. On Thursday, seven of the 12 political organizations that appointed Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot president in March called for her resignation and the postponement of elections scheduled for Nov. 4. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, a former Supreme court judge, came to power after a weeklong popular uprising toppled military ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril. She heads a caretaker interim government whose main task is to organize elections. But the president has been seen as weak and unable to control the army. The last attempt at free elections in Haiti in November 1987 collapsed when attackers supported by the army killed at least 34 voters. On Saturday, Jean Claude Bajeux, co-leader of the socialist Congress of Democratic Movements and a member of 12-party Unity Assembly, criticized Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot for her quick appointment of the five new Cabinet members. ``Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot has aggravated the crisis, since she has appointed her Cabinet without the advice and consent of the Council of State,'' he said. In a statement Aug. 15, the Council of State, which was set up in March to govern alongside Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, said the president was an obstacle to holding free elections. At least two of the ministers said they were resigning because of their unhappiness with the government. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot has also been criticized for not doing enough to enforce two arrest warrants issued for former officials linked to the 29-year Duvalier family dynasty that ended in 1986. Roger Lafontant, the reputed head of the dreaded Tonton Macoutes paramilitary police, and Williams Regala, a retired army officer who has been linked to the November 1987 election massacre, remain at large. They returned from exile in July, leading many citizens to think there will be an attempt to disrupt the upcoming elections. Haiti has had five governments since Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier fled to France in 1986. Replacing the five ministers who resigned on Friday are Andre Jean-Louis in Agriculture, Jean Mainville in Commerce, Chavannes Douyon in Education, Alex Toussaint in Foreign Relations and Carlo Desinor in Foreign Affairs. All are career civil servants except Desinor, the outgoing information minister. He will be replaced in that post by Alfred Mentor. Onill Millet, former director of the Central Bank, was named minister of finance, filling a post that has been vacant since July 23.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf in final item to restore dropped word `game.'
DOC.HEAD: Thomas Willson McKnew
DOC.TEXT: Thomas Willson McKnew, chairman emeritus of the National Geographic Society, died Friday of pneumonia. He was 94. McKnew participated in financing hundreds of research projects in geology, archaeology, anthropology, botany, astronomy and related sciences since joining the National Geographic in 1932. He was named chairman emeritus in 1987. As assistant secretary of the society, McKnew served as project officer in man's first venture into the stratosphere. The society and the Army Air Corps in 1935 launched the giant manned balloon EXPLORER II from the Stratobowl near Rapid City, S.D. Captains Albert W. Stevens and Orvil A. Anderson piloted EXPLORER II and its pressurized, instrument-filled gondola to the then-record height of 72,395 feet. The curvature of the Earth was photographed for the first time. A veteran of World War I, McKnew was awarded the Navy's Distinguished Service Award and the Air Force's Exceptional Service Award, the highest civilian awards given by the Navy and the Air Force.

Sergei Dovlatov, a Soviet emigre author who wrote about his homeland with irreverence and sly humor, died of heart disease Friday at age 48. Dovlatov died at Coney Island Hospital in the borough of Brooklyn. A former journalist and Siberian prison camp guard, Dovlatov became involved in dissident literary circles as attempts to publish his fiction in the Soviet Union met resistance. He emigrated to the United States in 1979 because of harassment from Soviet authorities. He published several books, including ``The Compromise,'' and ``Ours,'' and his short stories have appeared in the New Yorker magazine.

Claude L. ``Tiny'' Day, a sport journalist who played and promoted country music, died Friday at age 63 of a heart attack. Day, sports editor of The Greeneville Sun for more than 40 years, suffered the heart attack at Greeneville High School during a preseason football game and was pronounced dead at Laughlin Memorial Hospital. A country music fan, he performed with a country-western group known as The Sauceman Brothers and The Hillbilly Ramblers for four years after World War II. He served with the Marines during the war. Day also performed with groups at the Grand Ole Opry until recent years and served as a part-time promoter of area appearances by top country-western entertainers. He is survived by his wife, Imogene Sauceman Day; sons, Michael A. Day and James A. Sauceman Jr.; sisters Helen Bradley and Mary Ann Smelser, and brother LaVerne E. Day.

DOC.HEAD: Cosby Beats Bart in TV Face-Off
DOC.TEXT: Yo, Bill. Rest easy, dude. You're still No. 1. In the most-hyped family feud of the new TV season, overnight ratings released Friday showed that venerable Bill Cosby and the genteel Huxtables thrashed skateboarding Bart Simpson and his acid-tongued cartoon family. NBC's kinder, gentler ``The Cosby Show'' averaged a 15 rating for Thursday night. Fox Broadcasting Co.'s grousing, dysfunctional ``The Simpsons'' captured an 8.4, according to the A.C. Nielsen Co. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. Thursday's national overnight figures marked the highest showing all summer for Cosby, which ranked 12th in last week's standings. ``The Simpsons,'' in its old Sunday night time slot, ranked fourth for the same period. Since Fox announced this summer that ``The Simpsons'' would go toe-to-toe with NBC's longstanding ``Cosby'' hit beginning Thursday night, the showdown has taken on new proportions in television hype. Cosby, wearing a Bart T-shirt captioned ``Yo, Bill,'' is on next Friday's cover of Entertainment Weekly. NBC entertainment president Brandon Tartikoff walked into a press conference last month and was greeted by more than 100 television critics wearing Bart Simpson masks. In typical television spin control, both networks claimed victory in their first round of battle. ``We're thrilled,'' said Brad Turell, a spokesman for Fox, which has 75 fewer affiliates than NBC. ``You're not the No. 1 show of the decade for nothing,'' said Preston Beckman, NBC vice president of audience research. Thursday's ``Simpsons'' offering in its new, 8 p.m. time slot was a third repeat of an episode highlighted by the decapitation of a city hero's statue by 10-year-old Bart. ``The Cosby Show'' was a rerun of a bloopers special first telecast during the February sweeps period. ``What we saw last night is there's room for Cosby and there's room for Fox and there's room for the other networks,'' said Beckman. Fox, which has said all along its strategy was not to topple Cosby, but to come in second, achieved that. ``Father Dowling Mysteries'' on ABC and ``48 Hours'' on CBS tied for last place with a 7.4 average. Both Fox and NBC said they expected their Thursday night ratings to change when original episodes begin airing. Both expect an increase. ``The Cosby Show'' premieres its new season on Sept. 20. ``The Simpsons,'' because of the time-consuming animation process, won't debut until late October. Cosby is ``working his butt off to make this a great year,'' Beckman said. ``We acknowledge and respect `The Simpsons' as a legitimate hit show.''

DOC.HEAD: FEC Sues Republican Fundraising Group
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Election Commission sued the National Republican Senatorial Committee Friday, accusing it of illegally funneling nearly $2.7 million raised through solicitation letters from George Bush to a dozen GOP campaigns in 1986. The suit, filed in U.S. District Court, accuses the Senate campaign arm of the National Republican Committee, of violating a contribution ceiling of $17,500 that party organizations can make to a single candidate. All 12 of the GOP Senate candidates subsequently lost to Democrats in the November general election. The commission filed the suit in U.S. District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell's court in response to his ruling last January reversing the FEC's decision to dismiss a portion of a complaint by Common Cause against the Senate GOP committee. Common Cause, a citizens lobbying group, filed the complaint with the FEC a week before the 1986 general election. It alleged that the Republican committee's ``bundling'' of contributions raised from Bush's letter and dispersing them to the 12 candidates circumvented the party spending limits. In September 1986, the committee mailed out in mass some 24 different versions of Bush's solicitation letter _ each mentioning four states in which Senate campaigns were occurring but not the names of the GOP candidates. Bush was vice president at the time. The returning checks from donors were made out to the National Republican Senatorial Committee or an organization under its control _ such as the ``Inner Circle'' or the ``Republican Presidential Task Force'' _ rather than the individual candidates' campaigns. The committee, however, reported the contributions as going directly from original donor to candidate. ``In some cases, individual donors had never even heard of the candidates to whom they supposedly had earmarked contributions,'' the FEC said in its lawsuit Friday. The FEC's general counsel said the committee's fundraising tactics on behalf of the Senate GOP candidates violated the Federal Election Campaign Act. However, the commission _ reflecting its composition of three Republicans and three Democrats _ deadlocked on most of his recommendations, effectively rejecting them in July 1988. However, the panel did find that the $534,000 the GOP committee spent on the mass mailings without listing the money as a contribution to the candidates violated the law. Five months later, the Republican committee agreed to pay a fine of $20,000. However, Common Cause opposed the settlement and filed suit in Gesell's court to reverse it. ``Our position is that this matter was closed in 1988,'' Bill Canfield, the Republican committee's legal counsel, said Friday. ``We paid a civil penalty and we have a letter from the general counsel of the FEC saying the matter is closed.'' Canfield described the FEC as being ``caught between a rock and a hard place'' because of Gesell's ruling last January. He said any adverse ruling by Gesell _ ``who happens to be no friend of Republicans'' _ in the suit filed Friday will be appealed by the committee.

DOC.HEAD: Case Dismissed For Spray-Painting Millionaire
DOC.TEXT: A judge Friday dismissed charges against a Greenwich millionaire who became the hero of sign-haters after he was arrested for spray painting a real estate sign. Rene Anselmo, 64, said after the 10-minute hearing that he had accomplished his goal of bringing attention to the proliferation of signs in exclusive Greenwich, even though he didn't get to argue his case before a jury as he had wanted. ``I'm going to concentrate on working on a new ordinance that would totally ban the signs,'' said Anselmo, owner of Pan American Satellite Co., which leases satellite time to television networks. Anselmo's lawyer, Philip Russell, said his client's conduct had brought the sign issue up for public debate, ``which is what it was intended to do.'' Anselmo was arrested July 3 for painting a Coldwell Banker real estate sign. ``A police car came by and the officer said `Do you need help?' I said, `No, I've just been spraying this sign,' '' he said. Since then, public opiniohn has grown against advertising signs commonly placed in front of homes by real estate and construction companies. At a forum last week, hundreds of Greenwich residents cheered when Anselmo said the town was drowning in a ``sea of signs.'' Only one, a real estate broker, came out against Anselmo, calling him a ``Robin Hood with a Bentley.'' Zoning officials are considering the issue. Judge Sandra Villardy Leheny dismissed the charges against Anselmo after prosecutor Steven Weiss argued the case belonged in small claims court because it was a property damage dispute. Anselmo said Coldwell Banker sent him a bill for $108.10 after he was arrested. He said he wouldn't pay the bill but offered to treat Coldwell Banker officials to a lunch or dinner of the same value.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Service Advises Against Sending Packages to Soldiers in Mideast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 11 grafs to UPDATE with mailing addresses. Azeezaly in 2nd graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Postal Service is advising people not to send packages through military mail address to soldiers in Saudi Arabia. Spokesman Azeezaly Jaffer said Friday the only mail accepted at military post offices (APO or FPO addresses) for those assigned to Operation Desert Shield will be first-class letters up to 12 ounces. Items that don't meet the requirement or fail to pass Saudi Arabian customs will be returned, Jaffer said. If packages eventually are accepted, they may not contain alcoholic beverages or pork products, he said. The restriction to letters is imposed by the Defense Department, which has put a priority on shipment of military supplies, Jaffer said. Mail to military post offices for soldiers serving abroad is sent at regular domestic mail rates. Regular mail to Saudi Arabia or other Mideast addresses is not affected by the restrictions, Jaffer said. The Pentagon said Friday it had established special addresses for mail sent from the United States to U.S. soldiers, sailors and airmen in Saudi Arabia. Mail for members of the Army, Air Force and Marine Corps may be directed to Operation Desert Shield, APO New York 09848-0006. Mail for Navy and Marine Corps members on ships around the Arabian Peninsula may be addressed to Operation Desert Shield, FPO New York 09866-0006. Mail to individual Army members identified by name, rank and service number may be sent directly to an Army Post Office number set up for six of the Army units in Saudi Arabia. They are: _For the 101st Airborne Division, APO 09309. _For the 82nd Airborne Division, APO 09656. _24th Infantry Division, APO 09315. _1st Corps Support Command from Fort Bragg, APO 09657. _197th Infantry Brigade, APO 09315. _11th Air Defense Artillery Brigade, APO 09656. _3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment, APO 09209.

DOC.HEAD: Social Workers Oppose Physical Punishment of Children
DOC.TEXT: Parents were advised Friday by a national organization of social workers to stop spanking their children because mild physical punishment could quickly escalate into abuse. An anti-spanking policy was adopted on a voice vote by the primary governing body of the 130,000-member National Association of Social Workers. The policy is an expansion of one opposing physical punishment in school adopted six years ago. ``We are not simply trying to circumvent child abuse,'' said Isadora Hare, the group's education commission staff director. ``We also want to reverse the acceptance of using physical means to resolve conflicts. There are more effective ways to discipline children without using physical punishment.'' Hare said that physical punishment is deeply ingrained in the United States. A recent study showed that 81 percent of U.S. parents use physical punishment on their children during 1982. More than 60 percent spanked at least once a week. An estimated 3 million children have been kicked, bitten or punched and about 2 million have been ``beaten up'' by parents some time in their lives. The association said research has demonstrated that most physical child abuse is an escalation of what a parent intends only as discipline. Several European countries have laws banning parental use of physical punishment. Sweden prohibited physical punishment of children in 1979. Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Austria have since passed legislation. England has launched a parent-focused campaign called End Physical Punishment of Children. The idea to expand the 1984 ban of physical punishment in school came last February when the association participated in a meeting involving researchers and other national agencies that issued a position statement opposing parental use of physical punishment. Hare said the latest action is ``a tremendously important statement of principle. In terms of impact, it will be a slow process of changing the way people feel about raising children.'' The association is the world's largest organization of professional social workers with members in the United States, Puerto Rico and Europe. Social workers provide more than half of the mental health counseling in this country.

DOC.HEAD: Sullivan Imposes HHS Hiring Freeze
DOC.TEXT: Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan imposed a hiring freeze Friday as officials laid plans for dramatic cuts that would be necessary if no federal budget agreement is reached by Oct. 1. In a memorandum to the department's 118,000 employees, Sullivan said the reductions under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law would ``seriously affect this department's many programs, the people we serve and our employees.'' No budget compromise between the Bush administration and congressional leaders is in sight. Even if the freeze on hiring from outside HHS and other money-saving steps are taken, ``furloughs may still be necessary,'' Sullivan said in the memo. Kevin Moley, HHS assistant secretary for management and budget, said most federal departments and programs would see their budgets reduced by 31.9 percent if no agreement is reached. However, government officials believe that the required across-the-board spending cuts of more than $100 billion would be so severe that they would not remain in effect for long. In past years, lawmakers and the White House have agreed to roll back Gramm-Rudman cuts after leaving them in place only briefly. In addition to furloughs at HHS, payments for such programs as Medicare and Social Security would be delayed, and Medicare payments would be cut by 2 percent, Moley said. Social Security Commissioner Gwendolyn King told Moley in an internal memo that a $1.3 billion cut in personnel and administrative costs would leave the agency too shorthanded to keep up with changes in the benefit rolls, an agency spokesman confirmed. Social Security benefit payments would not be affected by the Gramm-Rudman cuts.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Not Ready To Blame Deaths On L-Tryptophan
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration said Friday it is too early to blame the deaths of 27 Americans who took L-tryptophan directly on gene splicing. ``We are still not sure what caused the problem,'' said FDA spokesman Jeff Nesbit. The FDA will review a petition filed by biotechnology watchdog Jeremy Rifkin asking the agency to put on hold further approvals of genetically engineered products, Nesbit said. Rifkin, president of the Foundation on Economic Trends, filed his petition Friday, saying the L-tryptophan-linked deaths are the first cases on record connecting a genetically engineered product with human deaths and injuries. The 27 who died were among more than 1,500 Americans who developed a rare blood disorder called eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome, or EMS, after taking L-tryptophan. Until the FDA ordered all L-tryptophan off the market in March because of its link to EMS, the dietary supplement was sold in health food stores as a remedy for insomnia, appetite control and depression. An Aug. 9 article in the New England Journal of Medicine concluded that the Japanese chemical company whose product had been linked with most of the EMS cases had made two changes in its manufacturing process that could have caused the problem. The company, Showa Denko K.K., introduced a new strain of genetically altered bacteria at about the same time it changed its purification process for L-tryptophan. The changes occurred in 1988. ``The data from the New England Journal of Medicine article suggest but don't prove a relationship of illness with ingestion of tryptophan made with the aid of a bacillus that is bioengineered,'' the FDA said in a paper put out Friday. The agency also noted that ``a great number of products (medicines and foods) continue to be made by fermentation processes, many involving bioengineered organisms, with no apparent deleterious effects on the health of people that use them.'' But the FDA also said problems with their use must be thoroughly investigated.

DOC.HEAD: Task Force Says Role is Largely Morale-Boosting
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Efforts to help Americans trapped in Kuwait and Iraq and provide information to family members in the United States have largely boiled down to trying to improve morale, the State Department said Friday. The information offered to families is generally limited because of the nature of the situation, the department said, adding there is no information on the whereabouts of Americans rounded up by the Iraqis and detained. ``I think the American community in Iraq and Kuwait is very tense, concerned,'' said Nicholas Ricciuti, director of the Citizens Emergency Center of the department's consular section. ``I think morale is probably the most practical purpose'' of the State Department communication effort, he said. However, Ricciuti said the department had provided repatriation money and emergency loans. ``We assist the Americans any way that we can,'' he said. At a briefing, Ricciuti said more than 25,000 phone calls had been received by the Kuwait Task Force since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion inquiring about the well being of Americans in the two nations. The task force, staffed by more than 100 people in three shifts, 24 hours a day, has made more than 10,000 calls to families and friends to relay information, Ricciuti said. The State Department says there are about 2,500 Americans in Kuwait, of whom 1,984 have been identified by the U.S. Embassy. There are some 500 Americans in Iraq. Gathering information has become difficult because of restraints placed on U.S. diplomats in the two countries and because of the belief that Iraq is monitoring telephone calls to learn the locations of Americans, Ricciuti said. He said calls are kept short. ``We never say where they have moved for obvious reasons,'' he said. ``We have been able to pass messages to families in the United States and vice versa.''

DOC.HEAD: Decatur Family Finally Makes It Home From Kuwait
LaserPhoto HUN1, LaserColor HUN101
DOC.TEXT: A family who fled across the Kuwaiti border under the gunfire of Iraqi soldiers arrived home Friday, waving American flags and hugging relieved relatives. Ray and Annette Shoopman, their daughter Kay Rashid and Mrs. Rashid's two young children were welcomed with tears and hugs at Huntsville's airport. Shoopman, 52, who was in the oil business in the Middle East, said the family left behind all their belongings and escaped with only the clothes they were wearing. After Iraq's invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2, the family decided to make a run for the border when a Kuwaiti friend invited them to meet to take part in a convoy of cars. Shoopman said the convoy took back roads along the Kuwaiti border. The cars were stopped at one point by an Iraqi patrol and told to turn around. He said they turned back, but took another route toward the border. Mrs. Rashid said Iraqi patrols shot over the tops of the cars as they approached the border. ``Yes, we were scared, but we didn't stop,'' she said. ``We knew if we stopped they had us _ and we had come too far to stop.'' Mrs. Rashid's husband, Adnan, escaped with the family from Kuwait but remained in Saudi Arabia to help other relatives escape from his native Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Block Bucharest Traffic, Fight Police
DOC.TEXT: Riot police tangled Friday with dozens of anti-government demonstrators, who for a third straight night occupied central University Square and blocked traffic. Protesters _ estimated by the Soviet news agency Tass as ``several hundred'' _ took over the square in the early evening, shouting slogans demanding the resignation of President Ion Iliescu. They blocked traffic and attacked a delivery truck that tried to drive through. On Wednesday and Thursday evenings, demonstrators had voluntarily dispersed when police arrived. On Friday, however, hundreds of riot police were called in to form a rectangle around the square's perimeter when protesters stood fast. Fellow demonstrators blocked off another section of the boulevard about a half-mile north, burning piles of garbage on the road. Police marched in formation up the boulevard and cleared that area. Later, most of the demonstrators cleared the square, allowing traffic to flow once more after a confrontation with the police that at times broke into jostling and shouting between police and demonstrators who charged them. Demonstrators threw rocks at police. One man hurled fire bombs and then fled. No one was hurt. At least one man was arrested, police said. Police helicopters flew over at low altitude, drawing a chorus of boos. Several anti-government demonstrations have occurred at the square since June 13, when club-swinging police broke up 53-day occupation. The police action led to violence in which six people were officially reported killed. Unlike the previous demonstrations, organized by students and others who accuse Iliescu and his associates of being thinly veiled Communists, this week's rallies appeared mainly motivated by the deteriorating economic situation and attracted mostly lower-income workers. In December, Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was overthrown and executed in a violent revolution. In Sibiu, 150 miles northwest of Bucharest, on Friday, a military court heard closing arguments in the trial of Ceausescu's youngest son, Nicu, who is charged with genocide in resisting the popular uprising.. The five-judge panel postponed its verdict until Sept. 21, when the court will reconvene in Bucharest. Nicu Ceausescu led the former Communist Youth League until 1987, when he became party secretary in Sibiu. He is formally charged with ``complicity to genocide,'' accused of ordering ordered security forces to fire on anti-government demonstrators in Sibiu during the December revolution. Fighting in Sibiu killed 89 people.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Destroys New Orleans Wharf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with fire controlled, wharf destroyed, two injured, description, potential damage, and adds byline.
DOC.TEXT: Fire destroyed a wharf and a warehouse full of rubber in the Port of New Orleans on Friday, sending black smoke billowing over the Mississippi River and threatening nearby docks and stores of coffee. Two firemen were injured fighting the blaze, which took four hours to control and went to seven alarms. ``It is one of the largest fires in the history of the New Orleans Fire Department,'' said Fire Superintendent William McCrossen.
