Smoke from the burning Orange Street wharf engulfed the twin spans of the Crescent City Connection bridge, which crosses the river a few blocks downstream from the fire. Adjacent wharfs were evacuated, among them the Robin Street wharf, where the paddlewheelers Delta Queen and Mississippi Queen dock. Neither boat was in port. About 115 men, 25 fire trucks and other equipment were sent to the scene. Port officials asked every available fireboat on the lower Mississippi to pump river water onto the blaze, said port director Ron Brinson. The cause of the fire was not known. Brinson said workers at Colley's Warehouse on the Orange Street wharf found a small blaze and were unable to put it out before it spread. As the blaze roared out of control, small explosions could be heard inside the warehouse. The building collapsed about an hour and a half after the first alarm, about noon. After that, firefighters concentrated on containing the fire. The contents of the warehouse continued to burn and spew clouds of heavy black smoke after the fire was declared under control. Brinson said the damage toll for the 150,000-square-foot, 70-year-old warehouse and its contents would be ``in the millions.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Candidate Demands Probe of Simon's S&L Intervention
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Paul Simon, a frequent critic of the government's handling of the savings and loan crisis, said Friday he did nothing wrong when he helped a developer who owed millions of dollars to a troubled thrift. But it quickly became a campaign issue as Simon's Republican election opponent, Rep. Lynn Martin, sought an ethics investigation. Simon last month asked a California bank president to seek a settlement of a lawsuit against a Chicago developer who raised thousands of dollars for the senator's past three campaigns. Martin said she will file a formal complaint asking the U.S. Senate Ethics Committee to determine whether Simon violated Senate rules. Simon said Friday he was unaware the lawsuit against the developer involved a troubled savings and loan, and did nothing he hasn't done for thousands of constituents. First Nationwide Financial Corp., the bank that sued Simon supporter Stephen Ballis, was trying to reach a settlement long before Simon contacted them, a bank spokesman said. But Martin said the senator improperly used his influence on behalf of Ballis, who raised as much as $10,000 for the senator. ``How often does Paul volunteer to call a bank president to forestall foreclosure and negotiate deals for people who are not raising money for his campaign?'' Martin said. ``This is not normal procedure for members of Congress. You don't call bank presidents to talk about loans.'' Ballis, president of Dayton Resources Ltd., defaulted on a $5 million loan to Chicago-based Pathway Financial, F.A. San Francisco-based First Nationwide received a $255 million pledge from federal thrift regulators in December, 1988, for agreeing to take over Pathway. In May, First Nationwide officials sued to foreclose on the loan. After meeting with Ballis in Chicago, Simon called First Nationwide President John Devine and asked if the bank could seek a settlement. ``I said, `If you two can get together and work it out and avoid litigation, it seems to me that it's in everyone's best interest,''' Simon said. ``The taxpayers aren't out a penny.'' The settlement's details were complete, but the agreement has not yet been approved, said Dan Brigham, First Nationwide spokesman. Ballis' wife Elizabeth contributed $1,800 to Simon's re-election and 1988 presidential campaigns, records indicate. Ballis' total fundraising efforts for Simon totalled less than $10,000, said campaign spokeswoman Ellen Golin. Simon, who held hearings on the savings and loan crisis in Chicago last week, says he would make the same phone call today. ``Public relations-wise, you might reconsider it, but it was clearly a proper thing to do,'' Simon said. Martin said Simon's intervention will become an issue in her campaign to unseat him. ``I believe he is beatable on the issues. I believe he is beatable on philosophy,'' she said. ``But it would be just as wrong not to talk about this as it would be not to talk about the other things.''

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Invokes Legal Authority To Spend Unappropriated Money
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Department on Friday invoked a law that will enable it to spend money it doesn't officially have to pay for its operations in the Middle East. The law, the Feed and Forage Act, give the Pentagon the authority to finance Operation Desert Shield until Congress can appropriate the money, the department said in a statement. Congress is in recess until after Labor Day. The Pentagon has estimated that the operation will cost some $1.18 billion through the end of September. The law invoked by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney will allow the department to spend money for ``clothing, subsistence, forage, fuel, quarters, transportation and medical and hospital supplies,'' necessary for the rest of the year, the statement said. The fiscal year ends on Sept. 30. The Pentagon plans to pay for chemical protection and combat clothing, ship and aircraft fuel, medical supplies and food and shelter for the U.S. forces, the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Clay Cancels Dallas Concerts, Citing Fear of Arrest
DOC.TEXT: Raunchy comedian Andrew Dice Clay has canceled a Dallas concert because he's afraid of violating Texas' strict anti-obscenity law, his publicist said Friday. Michael Levine said Clay canceled the show, scheduled for Sunday, because ``we feared the possibility that Dice might be subject to arrest, embarrassment and subsequently jailed.'' The promoters of the concert announced Thursday that no one under 18 would be admitted _ even with a parent. Dallas County Assistant District Attorney David Pickett had said the performance could violate state obscenity laws. A woman at Pickett's office said he had left for the day and no one else was authorized to discuss the cancellation. Larry Fontana, manager of the Starplex Amphitheatre where Clay was to perform, said the cancellation is ``just one of the things that happens in this business.'' He estimated promotion losses would be ``in the low five-figures.'' Fontana said 6,000 of 7,000 available tickets were sold at $22.50 each by Friday afternoon. They went on sale July 28. Clay, whose comedy act includes graphic descriptions of sex, ethnic slurs and descriptions of women as ``whores'' and ``pigs,'' said in a statement: ``America is where people have always come for freedom, and it's a shame that a noisy minority is now attempting to tear down the right of free speech.'' Members of several local civil rights groups had promised to protest Clay's appearance. On Monday, the last local sponsor of the concert, radio station KTXQ-FM, withdrew its support. Pickett's office has filed nine misdemeanor obscenity charges against the music store chain Sound Warehouse for selling the rap group 2 Live Crew's recording, ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be.'' Fontana said Pickett's office placed ``an informational call'' to him a few days ago, ``saying citizens groups had contacted them, concerned about the fact that Mr. Clay's material might be obscene.'' Fontana said he didn't take the phone call as a warning. ``We contacted Clay's people and our attorneys had discussions with the district attorney's office, but the cancellation was straight from Mr. Clay,'' Fontana said. Earlier this year, ``Saturday Night Live'' cast member Nora Dunn and Irish pop singer Sinead O'Connor refused to appear with Clay on the NBC program. Clay appeared in ``The Adventures of Ford Fairlane,'' this summer but 20th Century Fox has decided not to release a planned Clay concert film.

DOC.HEAD: Central Asian Republic of Tadzhikistan Declares Sovereignty
DOC.TEXT: Tadzhikistan declared sovereignty on Friday after a stormy six-hour parliamentary session in the Soviet Central Asian republic, the independent news service Interfax reported. A measure passed by the republic's Supreme Soviet, or parliament, declared that Tadzhikistan's laws will take precedence over Soviet laws, it said. Tadzhikistan thus became the 13th of the Soviet Union's 15 republics to move toward greater autonomy. Only Kazakhstan and Kirghizia have made no such moves. Tadzhikistan said its declaration would be the basis for a new constitution and treaty of union with the central Soviet government, Interfax said. The agency said the parliament rejected a proposal to create a separate army, saying Tadzhikistan has no money for its own army. On Thursday, Soviet Armenia took a more defiant step, declaring independence on the same day the republic of Turkmenia declared sovereignty. The declarations bring the Soviet Union closer to fragmentation. The three Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia insist they want independence and want no part of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan to restructure the nation into a looser confederation with more local autonomy. The Central Asian republics, which are predominantly Moslem, have been more cautious to embrace the more radical course pursued by nationalists in other republics.

DOC.HEAD: Third Pilot Pleads Guilty to State Intoxication Charge
DOC.TEXT: A former Northwest Airlines pilot convicted in federal court of flying while intoxicated joined two co-defendants Friday in pleading guilty to a similar charge in North Dakota. Joseph Balzer of Antioch, Tenn., agreed to enter the plea on the condition that it can be withdrawn if his federal appeal is successful, said Cass County State's Attorney Robert Hoy. Norman Lyle Prouse of Conyers, Ga., and Robert Kirchner of Highland Ranch, Colo., entered similar pleas with the same conditions Thursday. Hoy said the appeal process could take eight to 10 months. The three were convicted in Minneapolis of flying a passenger plane with 91 people aboard from Fargo to Minneapolis in March while under the influence of alcohol. Cass County Judge Frank Racek on Friday sentenced Balzer to six months in jail but suspended the sentence for one year. He was ordered to pay a $500 fine and $500 to cover the costs of prosecuting the case. Prouse and Kirchner received identical sentences Thursday. Hoy said the state dismissed a second count against the defendants, which charged them with acting as aircraft crew members within eight hours of consuming alcohol.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Official Asks Church Leaders To Condemn U.S. Mideast Stand
By GEORGE W. CORNELL
AP Religion Writer
DOC.TEXT: An American Islamic leader on Friday urged religious officials to repudiate the United States' military buildup in the Middle East. Mohammad T. Mehdi, secretary-general of the National Council on Islamic Affairs, called the military buildup ``a threat to international peace'' and said it would ``create greater hostility against America throughout the Moslem world.'' In messages to various Catholic, Protestant and Jewish leaders, Mehdi said: ``Peace in the Middle East and the world depends on the religious community and our opposition to the war hysteria created by President Bush.'' So far, Christian and Jewish leaders have shown support in principle for the U.S.-led actions against Iraq's takeover of neighboring Kuwait. The American military establishment has been idle since the Vietnam war and was ``itching for action to justify its existence,'' said Medhi. American and other military forces were sent to Saudi Arabia at that Islamic country's request, to prevent further agression by Iraq. The United Nations approved economic sanctions against Iraq. The National Council of Churches, which includes most major Protestant and Orthodox denominations, has denounced Iraq's invasion and supported international resistance against it. However, it expressed hope for diplomatic solutions. Similar stands have been taken in recent days by Roman Catholic and Jewish leaders. The Associated Press' attempts to those religious leaders for comment on Mehdi's appeal late Friday were unsuccessful. Mehdi termed absurd President Bush's claim that Operation Desert Shield was needed to protect the American way of life, and said, in apparent reference to the monarchies of Saudi Arabia and Kuwait: ``The protection of a few medieval kingdoms and princedoms can never be vital for the protection of the American way of life.'' The ``free flow of oil in world markets is assured, regardless of who controls the Arab oil resources,'' Mehdi said. Whoever rules will ``either have to sell the oil or drink it.'' Mehdi urged religious leaders ``in the name of the one God we worship to do your utmost to pressure the President to withdraw American forces.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds item on Rose and CORRECTS name in previous editor's note to Spear sted Rouse. A separate moved on Spear for AMs as a0699.
DOC.TEXT: Former Ambassador James W. Wine died Thursday of natural causes at age 71. Wine served as U.S. ambassador to Luxembourg in 1961 and the Republic of the Ivory Coast in 1962. He was also special assistant to the secretary of state serving as chief of the U.S. delegation to several international bodies engaged in the negotiation of treaties and agreements. He was a special circuit judge and member of the Judicial Reform Commission in Kentucky. He practiced law in Europe and retired from the firm of Martin & Smith in Washington, D.C., and Reston, in 1984. Wine was designated a distinguished alumnus of the University of Kentucky in 1967. He was a member of the board of directors of the International Bank of Washington, D.C., Wheeler Industries Inc. and Enterprise Banking Corp. He also was a member of the World Association of Lawyers and was a teaching fellow at Oxford University.

Michael D. Spear, president of The Rouse Co. which has overseen high-profile property developments around the country, died Friday in a plane crash at age 49. Spear joined the company as director of market research and project evaluation in 1967. From 1971 to 1978, he served as general manager of the Columbia project. Spear was named executive vice president for development in 1978. Spear has been president of Rouse since 1986. The company, based in Columbia, Md., is the largest publicly held real estate development firm in the country.

Dr. Bennett J. Cohen, a University of Michigan veterinarian who specialized in the treatment and care of animals used in research, died Thursday of cancer at age 65. Cohen retired in 1985 after 23 years as director of the Unit for Laboratory Animal Medicine at the university Medical Center. The unit oversees the treatment of the thousands of chimpanzees, dogs, cats, birds, fish, rodents and other animals used annually in research at the Ann Arbor school. He co-founded the American College of Laboratory Animal Medicine, which certifies veterinarians as specialists in laboratory animals' care. After stepping down as head of the laboratory animal medicine unit, Cohen became a research scientist at the university's Institute of Gerontology.

Patrick E. Malloy Jr., the retired night managing editor of The Tribune-Democrat in Johnstown, died Thursday of lung cancer at age 82. Malloy began his newspaper career in 1927 as a copy boy for the Johnstown Democrat. He served as the newspaper's sports editor and night city editor. He retired from the Democrat, later called The Tribune-Democrat, in 1973.

Harold Masursky, a pioneer space scientist who spent 43 years with the U.S. Geological Survey, died Friday of diabetes at age 66. Masursky joined the Geological Survey in 1947 and began his career in the exploration for fossil fuels in the western United States. He joined the astrogeology branch in 1962. In 1976, Masursky was one of the scientists who helped select the landing site on Mars for the Viking flight. He also helped set up Viking's experiments. In the early 1970s, Masursky was one of a small group of U.S. scientists who began a quiet exchange of space science information with the Soviet Union. In 1987, he was the host when Soviet scientists Alexandzer Basilevsky and Neon Armand visited the branch of astrogeology and unveiled much of the Soviet plan for a major unmanned exploration of Mars. Masursky had been a member of 41 scientific groups. He received four awards of excellence from the Geological Survey and in 1988 won the Smithsonian Institution's National Air and Space Museum Award for Achievement in Lunar and Planetary Exploration. He retired in February.

Television and film composer David Rose, who composed the theme music for ``Bonanza'' and other television shows, died Thursday of heart problems at age 80. Rose's 65-year career was marked by four Emmys, 22 Grammys and an Oscar nomination for the 1945 film ``Wonder Man.'' He also was the orchestra leader for ``The Red Skelton Show'' from its early days in radio through its 20 years on television. Rose was the musical director of ``Bonanza'' for 14 years. In addition to the ``Bonanza'' music, Rose also composed music for episodes of Michael Landon's ``Little House on the Prairie'' and ``Highway to Heaven.'' His motion picture scores include ``Please Don't Eat the Daisies,'' (1960), ``Rich, Young and Pretty,'' (1951), and ``Port Afrique'' (1956). Rose's gold record ``Holiday for Strings'' was actually a theme of Red Skelton's show. He conducted and composed the music for more than 50 albums, scored 36 films and supplied themes and background tunes to 24 television series.

DOC.HEAD: Film and TV Composer David Rose Dies
DOC.TEXT: Television and film composer David Rose, who penned famous TV themes such as ``Bonanza,'' has died from complications from a heart problem. He was 80. He died Thursday at St. Joseph's Hospital. Rose's 65-year career was marked by four Emmys, 22 Grammys and an Oscar nomination for the 1945 film ``Wonder Man.'' The London-born composer also was the orchestra leader for ``The Red Skelton Show'' from its early days in radio through its 20 years on television. Rose was the musical director of ``Bonanza'' for 14 years, said publicist Paul Marsh. Rose also composed music for episodes of Michael Landon's ``Little House on the Prairie'' and ``Highway to Heaven.'' His motion picture scores include ``Please Don't Eat the Daisies,'' (1960), ``Rich, Young and Pretty,'' (1951), and ``Port Afrique'' (1956). Rose conducted and composed the music for more than 50 albums, scored 36 films and supplied themes and background tunes to 24 television series. The composer was survived by his wife, Betty, two daughters, two granddaughters and a grandson.

DOC.HEAD: President Says Mexico Willing To Join U.N. Gulf Force
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari says Mexico is willing to send troops to the Persian Gulf if the United Nations asks its help in a multilateral force. ``We would be ready to participate in any manner that the United Nations Security Council would decide,'' Salinas said in an interview with syndicated journalist and cartoonist Ranan R. Lurie. ``If they consider that the presence of Mexico in a multilateral force would be needed, it would be ready. ``We participated in World War II with a force with the Allies and we would certainly respond to any request from the U.N.'' Salinas' remarks in the interview this week were made available to The Associated Press on Friday. The president was restating general government policy, but it appeared to be his most direct comment on Mexico's approach to the Persian Gulf crisis since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The U.N. Security Council has ordered an embargo on all trade with Iraq, but has not called for a multilateral U.N. force to join Western and Arab forces already arrayed against Iraqi troops. Salinas did not respond directly when asked if he would send troops if asked by the United States or Saudi Arabia, but indicated he would need broad global backing for such a move. ``We are part of the world community and we will act along with the world community,'' he said. ``I wouldn't hesitate to participate with the rest of the world in what the world considers a just act.'' The turmoil in the Persian Gulf has affected world oil supply. Mexico is one of the largest crude oil producers outside the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Salinas said his country ``immediately opened the capacity of oil production . . . to its limits, increasing it by 100,000 barrels per day in order to make a contribution to a stable world market.'' Asked what he expected of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, Salinas replied: ``He will not pull out of Kuwait.''

DOC.BYLINE: Man Sentenced to Probation for Plotting to Kill Abusive Priest
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted of plotting to kill a Catholic priest who sexually abused him when he was a teen-age altar boy was placed on three years probation Friday. Gregory J. Riedle, 26, of St. Paul, Minn., was arrested in May after police got a tip he had come to this town in northern Wisconsin with the intention of killing the priest, Thomas Adamson. Police found a butcher knife and a 4-foot long wooden club in Riedle's car. In his hotel room, they found a letter addressed to Riedle's girlfriend saying Adamson ``had to die.'' District Attorney Raymond Pelrine said he recommended to Eau Claire County Judge William O'Brien that Riedle be given probation because no violence actually occurred. Police arrested Riedle before he could find Adamson. Riedle had been charged with attempted first-degree intentional homicide, but the charge later was reduced to attempted felony battery. In an interview last week with the Eau Claire Leader-Telegram, Riedle said he did not plan to kill Adamson, only to confront the priest who sexually abused him when he was a 14-year-old altar boy. He said Adamson first approached him in a St. Paul YMCA whirlpool and they had a sexual relationship for two years until his family moved. ``As God as my witness, I would not have done anything,'' Riedle said. ``I ain't got it in me to hurt people ... physically. I was mad at him. I won't deny that. I've always been mad at him.'' Riedle told police he brought the knife to commit suicide and the club to protect himself from Adamson. Adamson moved to the Eau Claire area several years ago when he was deactivated by the church after revelations of sexual liaisons with Riedle and another altar boy. Riedle won a settlement from the Twin Cities archdiocese in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Dairy Princess Gets Life for Killing Ex-Boyfriend's Fiancee
DOC.TEXT: A former beauty queen convicted of strangling her ex-boyfriend's fiancee begged for mercy Friday before being sentenced to life in prison with no parole for at least 13 years. Lori Esker, 21, pleaded for a ``chance to start paying back all the people I hurt so bad'' with the Sept. 20 murder of Lisa Cihaski. ``If I could trade places with Lisa, I would in a minute,'' Ms. Esker, choking back tears, told Marathon County Circuit Judge Michael Hoover. Hoover sentenced Ms. Esker to the required term of life in prison and granted her request that she be eligible for parole in 13 years, four months, the minimum. The judge said her otherwise clean record prevented him from setting a harsher minimum. A Circuit Court jury ruled in June that Ms. Esker killed Ms. Cihaski, 21, because she was jealous of the victim's relationship with her former boyfriend, 26-year-old Bill Buss, a dairy farmer. The Sept. 20 strangulation is something ``I will be punishing myself for as long as I live,'' said Ms. Esker, the Marathon County dairy princess last year. ``There isn't a day that goes by that I don't think about what happened.'' After sentencing, she was taken to the Taycheedah women's prison near Fond du Lac. Her conviction was to be appealed. Ms. Esker, of the tiny farming community of Hatley, a few miles from here, was convicted of first-degree intentional homicide, which carries a mandatory life sentence. But Hoover was allowed to set the parole limit. ``It's as much a tragedy that has befallen the defendant's family as the Cihaski family,'' Hoover said. ``No one expects the Cihaski family to fully understand that, at least not today.'' The Cihaskis declined to comment. Buss, who dated Ms. Esker for more than a year before becoming engaged to Ms. Cihaski, also refused to comment. Ms. Esker, a junior at University of Wisconsin-River Falls, strangled Ms. Cihaski with a belt after the two women met in a car outside a Wausau motel where the victim worked, according to testimony. She confessed to the murder but her lawyers claimed that she killed Ms. Cihaski in self defense after the two women argued.

DOC.HEAD: Space-Science Pioneer Dies at 66
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LesLee in last graf is correct
DOC.TEXT: Harold Masursky, a pioneer space scientist involved in the Mercury and Apollo programs and the Viking experiments on Mars, died early Friday at his home. He was 66. Masursky had diabetes and his health had declined over the past few years. A cause of death was not immediately released. Masursky retired in February after 43 years with the U.S. Geological Survey. His death coincided with the first transmission of images of Venus from the unmanned Magellan flight, a mission he began advocating in the 1960s. Born in Fort Wayne, Ind., Masursky joined USGS in 1947 and explored the western United States for fossil fuels. He transferred to the astrogeology branch in 1962. In the early 1970s, he was one of a small group of U.S. scientists who began a quiet exchange of space science information with the Soviet Union. In 1976, Masursky helped select the landing site on Mars for the Viking flight. He also helped set up Viking's experiments. Masursky was a member of 41 scientific groups and received four awards of excellence from the geological survey. In 1988, he was awarded the Smithsonian Institution's National Air and Space Museum Award for Achievement in Lunar and Planetary Exploration. He is survived by his wife, LesLee, four children, two grandchildren and three sisters.

DOC.HEAD: White House Condemns Saddam's TV Appearance With Britons
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts 2 grafs after 8th grasf, The spokesman, with Post report on chances of standoff as great as those of war
DOC.TEXT: The White House on Friday condemned Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's TV appearance with Britons he won't allow to leave Iraq as ``sick beyond expression.'' Meanwhile, President Bush prepared to interrupt his vacation and personally brief members of Congress on the Persian Gulf crisis. In Kuwait, Iraqi troops blocked off the U.S. Embassy that Saddam has ordered closed, while in Baghdad more than 100 Americans who had left compound on Thursday were kept from continuing their trip and leaving Iraq. Though the embassy standoff was tense, there were indications the president did not want military action there. ``Our purpose is not to create a confrontation or to create a threat,'' Bush's press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, said when asked why it was decided to pull out the embassy's Marine guards in Kuwait City while defying the Friday deadline to close the embassy. Fitzwater said Bush had watched a TV broadcast Thursday in which Saddam told a group of British citizens that their presence helped to prevent a U.S. military attack. The spokesman said Saddam's broadcast ``shows the cynical and inhumane view that he holds for human life. To hold men, women and children up for viewing as targets for destruction is sick beyond expression.'' The Washington Post reported in Saturday editions that U.S. officials believe the situation along the Kuwait-Saudi Arabia border has stabilized and that the likelihood of a prolonged military and diplomatic standoff between the United States and Iraq is at least as great as war. The newspaper, in a story from Kennebunkport that cited no sources, said the possibility of a lengthy standoff has raised concerns about how long economic and military pressure can can be maintained against Iraq. Bush will fly to Washington on Tuesday afternoon to meet with congressional leaders and members of key foreign policy committees. Although Congress is still in recess, ``several Congress members indicated they would like to come back to Washington for a face-to-face briefing,'' Fitzwater said. As for the embassy standoff, Fitzwater was asked what would be the appropriate response by Ambassador Nathaniel Howell and his staff if the Iraqis forced their way in. ``I can't get into specific instructions, but he is staying there to help out as he can,'' Fitzwater said. ``Force has not been applied. Should he be subject to that, he will have to act accordingly. But those are judgments that he is authorized to make in many cases, and beyond that, I couldn't go into specific discussions we have had with him.'' Tensions also were high in Persian Gulf waters where U.S. vessels trailed a number of Iraqi and other ships. The United States so far has declined to forcibly interdict any ships for violation of the United Nations-endorsed trade embargo against Iraq. But Fitzwater said ``we are monitoring all of them'' navigating in the region. Bush has said he was willing to give the United Nations a little time to work out agreement on a resolution backing military enforcement of the sanctions. But he also was prepared to go ahead with military interdiction without that approval, officials have indicated. Fitzwater expressed confidence the U.N. concurrence would come. He said Iraq continues to try to circumvent the U.N. sanctions. Among its efforts, he said, are ``aviation shipments into Baghdad of one kind or another, materiel that appears to be coming in through some routes and also the procurement of chemical warfare products, which we have great concern about.'' The spokesman declined to give further details ``because we are still working to resolve the matter and put an end to this.'' However, in answer to a question, he indicated the source of the materiel was not the Soviet Union, long a major supplier of armaments to Iraq. The vacationing president spent most of Friday morning with his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, taking him out on Bush's speedboat to continue discussions of the Persian Gulf developments, Fitzwater said. Turning to domestic issues, Bush also met Friday with Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and budget director Richard Darman. They were discussing new administration proposals on reducing the national deficit.

Scientists who successfully bonded metal ions to an antibody say it's the first step toward creating super-antidotes that could neutralize chemical weapons, drug overdoses and most poisons. The metal ions act as catalysts that can convert poisons to harmless substances inside the human body, said Stephen J. Benkovic, a chemistry professor at Penn State. ``It could be used as a detoxifying agent for people who have taken a drug overdose and can be used against environmental pollutants,'' Benkovic said in an interview. When the U.S. military learned of the early laboratory success, it asked for a briefing about applications in chemical warfare, he said. The ``metalloantibodies'' can be made by altering the amino acid sequence of protein to make it easier to bind with a metal, said Sheila A. Iverson, working on the project at the Research Institute of Scripps Clinic at La Jolla, Calif.

A judge's rejection of provisions in Pennsylvania's restrictive abortion law provides a chance for the Supreme Court to review its 1973 decision in Roe vs. Wade that legalized abortion, both sides in the case said. Senior U.S. District Judge Daniel H. Huyett on Friday struck down provisions in the 1982 state law, saying much of it was just a repeat of provisions previously ruled unconstitutional. The state said it would appeal to the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals and, if necessary, to the Supreme Court. ``If the (Supreme) court is looking to overturn Roe v. Wade, this case provides an opportunity to do that,'' said Linda Wharton of the Women's Law Project, an attorney for the plaintiffs in the case. ``Everything is happening the way we thought it would happen,'' said Republican Rep. Stephen Freind, the leading anti-abortion voice in the Legislature. ``No doubt we are going to win in the Supreme Court.''

A sizzling abortion debate in both East and West Germany threatens to hold up a treaty that would merge the laws of the two states. The newly adopted Oct. 3 unity date is not endangered, but failure of the treaty would leave a number of legal issues to be settled by an all-German parliament. All-German elections are not set until Dec. 2. The opposition Social Democrats have threatened to torpedo the treaty following a government decision that West German women who after unity try to take advantage of East Germany's permissive abortion law can be prosecuted. The Social Democrats have insisted West German law should only apply to West German turf.

Operation PUSH says it will keep urging a black boycott of Nike after a three-hour meeting with executives of the sports shoe company produced no promise of a comprehensive affirmative action program. The meeting Friday was ``congenial, amiable,'' PUSH founder Jesse Jackson said afterward. But he said Nike executives showed no willingness to yield to the black self-help group's demands for more minority representation in the company. Nike officials and Georgetown University basketball coach John Thompson, who has an endorsement contract with Nike, said progress had been made in the talks. But they declined to predict how the conflict will be resolved. ``Obviously, we're encouraged,'' said Nike President Richard K. Donahue. ``If this meeting had taken place first, there never would have been a boycott.''

Lawyers for four ``performance artists'' who were denied federal grants say they will take the National Endowment for the Arts to court for making what they call a political decision that violates the First Amendment. The lawyers from the Center for Constitutional Rights said a federal court case is the only option because the NEA on Friday rejected an appeal of its decision in June to turn down the grant applications. ``As in its initial denial letters, the NEA gives no substantive reasons for the denials,'' the non-profit center said in a statement from its New York headquarters. The four performers in question are Karen Finley and Holly Hughes of New York, and Tim Miller and John Fleck of Los Angeles. Their solo stage acts consist of songs and monologues on such themes as sexual oppression, politics and racism. The acts sometimes include explicit sexual content.

DOC.HEAD: A Week of Gulf Jitters, Trump and More Bad Economic News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This week begins a new format for this feature, which will round up the week's news from the markets, economy, companies and people in business. A version also moved on financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: Friday's mild updraft in the markets was little relief to those nursing the wounds inflicted so far by the Persian Gulf crisis. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2: _ Nearly half a trillion dollars has been stripped from the value of U.S. stocks, roughly equaling the damage done on Black Monday in 1987. _ Oil prices have leaped above $30 per barrel, pushing unleaded gasoline prices up more than 15 cents per gallon at the pumps. _ Mortgage rates have moved back over 10 percent as yields on Treasury securities have risen in the bond market. _ Gold has soared well above $400 per ounce. _ The dollar has tumbled against other major currencies in foreign exchange, tarnishing its image as a safe haven in times of world turmoil. The crisis has proved an unusually heavy burden for the markets by striking at a time when recession worries already were eroding confidence. The situation also recalled unhappy memories of the sour investment climate that accompanied Mideast troubles in the 1970s. There was some good financial news on the military front, however. A World War II-era statute makes reservists summoned to active duty eligible for an interest-rate cut to 6 percent for a wide range of debts incurred before being called up.
DOC.HEAD: ECONOMY: The Bad News Keeps Coming
DOC.TEXT: The economic news from Washington continued to paint a bleak picture. A report on the second-quarter gross national product pegged growth at a paltry 1.2 percent. The report showed the economy was weakening well before the Mideast crisis. The wealthiest fraction of America is still doing splendidly well by the latest government measure. The Internal Revenue Service said the richest 3.3 million people in the country held $4.3 trillion in 1986, exceeding the value of the GNP that year. An auto sales report from Detroit showed mid-August sales fell 4.7 percent. It was the first report since the Gulf erupted, but it showed no rush yet to fuel-efficient cars.
DOC.HEAD: COMPANIES: Lincoln, Layoffs, A New Turner Venture
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge upheld the government takeover of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, saying the operation of the notorious thrift by Charles H. Keating Jr. and his associates ``amounted to looting.'' National Semiconductor and Data General Corp. both announced big layoffs, amounting to about 2,000 workers each, deepening cost cuts in the technology sector. Elsewhere, USAir said it was issuing pink slips to 1,500 probationary employees and canceling a planned expansion. The move was blamed on the sobering outlook for the economy. Procter & Gamble said it would drop a plan to market the popular Maalox antacid and other Rhone-Poulenc Rorer products rather than fight a federal antitrust suit. CBS turned over the presidency of its troubled news division again, moving Eric Ober in and David Burke out. MCI Communications said it would take a writedown of at least $500 million to cover the costs of speeding up its conversion from analog to digital technology. Ted Turner, meanwhile, started a modest _ by his standards _ new venture in book publishing tied to television programming. Set for release on Valentine's Day is ``Kisses,'' a photo collection including the steamy embrace of Clark Gable and Vivien Leigh in ``Gone With the Wind.''
DOC.HEAD: PEOPLE: Trump Gets A Second Roll
DOC.TEXT: For Donald Trump, it was another humbling week. He found the fate of his complex debt restructuring being decided by casino regulators for the state of New Jersey, who put their stamp of approval on a new loan from his banks. Trump himself was relegated to spectator status at several days' worth of state hearings, where he was reduced to conducting business by pay telephone during breaks in the proceedings. Adding insult to injury, Fortune magazine on Tuesday dumped the ex-billionaire from its annual list of the world's richest people. Trump, worth $1.7 billion by Fortune's estimates last year, now could have a negative net worth according to the documents released by New Jersey gambling regulators. Although mildly humiliating, the agreement reached with the Casino Control Commission at least helped Trump avert disaster. The bank deal gave him $65 million in new credit and put a moratorium on some other pressing loan payments. Trump, in turn, promised to make payments on bonds financing his casinos and live within a strict budget. With fresh capital in hand, he took the Trump Shuttle off the market for the time being. Also during the week, he peddled a new book, titled ``Surviving at the Top.''
DOC.HEAD: NEW PRODUCT OF THE WEEK: Roach Repellent
DOC.TEXT: ``There's no silver bullet,'' lamented Richard Brenner, who has spent the past six years trying to invent a more potent cockroach repellent. But Brenner and Air Vent Inc. of Peoria Heights, Ill., may have developed the next best thing. Air Vent said it envisions bringing a new repellent to market in insulation and other construction materials within a year _ raising hopes for enlarging the $1.5 billion business of controlling roaches.
DOC.HEAD: BIZSPEAK: Some New Cliches for Cocktails
DOC.TEXT: Lest you be caught cliche-less at the next board meeting or cocktail hour, Working Woman magazine issued a dispatch on what's new in the lingo of movers and shakers. Among the words and phrases being culled from cool-speak are ``fast-trackers,'' ``I hear you,'' and thankfully, ``user-friendly.'' Additions for the '90s include ``lean and mean,'' ``cross-training,'' ``right-sizing,'' and ``comfort level.''
DOC.HEAD: NEXT WEEK: New Leads on the Economy
DOC.TEXT: The leading economic indicators for July are due out Wednesday, containing more hints on the direction of the sluggish economy.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Books and Authors: My Grandmother the Spy
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Author Dorothy Gilman gets letters from readers who love her books about Mrs. Pollifax, who travels through exotic places on missions for the CIA looking more like a grandmother on holiday than a secret agent. She also gets letters from people who've discovered her five non-Pollifax novels, saying how much they enjoy those. Few letter writers like both. Gilman made her first author's tour this summer, promoting ``Mrs. Pollifax and the Whirling Dervish,'' published by Doubleday. She doesn't speak against her creation of 26 years ago, even then an intrepid widow in her mid-60s. ``She supported me and my two boys and put them through college.'' But, she admits, Mrs. Pollifax does get a bit confining to write. ``Now that I'm in my later years, I'm insisting on doing more books I really want to do. But I always feel when I do a non-Pollifax, someone is looking over my shoulder saying, `This is nice but when are you going to do the next Mrs. Pollifax?' '' ``The Clairvoyant Countess'' is about a clairvoyant who helps the police. ``A Nun in the Closet'' is her only funny book, about two cloistered nuns who get embroiled in the outside world. ``Incident at Badamya'' was published last year. ``Its heroine is 16. There are people up through their 60s,'' she said. ``It's not a mystery. It's an adventure story. A lot of strangers are captured together in Burma, telling their stories. It has some mysticism in it. I've been told there's a little mysticism in all my books.'' Gilman's books are set in exotic locales, which she visits, finding that more fun than pounding her manual typewriter. Before Mrs. Pollifax met the Sufi dervish in her ninth CIA assignment, Gilman toured in Morocco with a dozen people, two of whom spoke English. ``For the first book, I was too poor to travel,'' Gilman says. ``I had her in Albania. I couldn't go to Turkey for the second but for the third I went to Bulgaria. I've been to the country of all the Mrs. Pollifaxes since _ Switzerland, Thailand, China.'' She usually isn't in danger. ``I went to Kenya and Tanzania and nothing happened. In Zambia, bombs were going off. There were freedom fighters from what is now Zimbabwe. While I was there, somebody was blown up. That trip was for `Mrs. Pollifax on Safari.' '' Gilman says, ``The books have to have something political. America is supporting the Moroccan king in his fight to take over the western Sahara from the Polisario. In 1975, the U.N. promised the Polisario a plebiscite. ``It appalled me. There was my plot. I do have a bit of trouble with plots _ so I lean on the political. The political part of the book is still up to date. No vote has been taken.'' There were more beggars in Morocco than Gilman has seen anywhere else. ``It made me even angrier at the king and at our government for supporting him. He is spending $1 million a day on this war. ``I didn't know about the war until I looked into Morocco. I love the research on these books.'' She finished ``Mrs. Pollifax and the Whirling Dervish'' last summer, now is working on a non-Pollifax. ``For six years I've been collecting material on the Sahara Desert and tribes. I haunt second-hand bookstores. When I find something, it's a big event. Now I'm finally putting it to work.'' Many writers start with a protagonist similar to themselves. But only now is Gilman catching up to Mrs. Pollifax in age. ``I think I was hiding behind her,'' the New Brunswick, N.J., native says. ``I was a minister's daughter. The church had so many eccentric, wonderful elderly ladies. It just seemed natural that Mrs. Pollifax would be a little quirky like them. She gave me a good cover. ``I had a need for escape in that horrible year (1964) when I had to leave my husband. I had a lot of trouble doing that, actually. ``I was caught in a very confined marriage, getting very depressed. You weren't supposed to leave husbands. This was my escape. She traveled, which I had always wanted to do. I think growing up I wanted to be a spy or a deep sea diver and write about those things.'' Gilman had gone to art school in Philadelphia, and was married to a seventh grade teacher. ``The Unexpected Mrs. Pollifax'' was published in 1966. ``Then I wrote `Uncertain Voyage.' It was psychological suspense, about a woman recovering from a nervous breakdown and testing herself by a trip to Europe. She has to find herself. There was some intrigue. Somebody said it was pre-women's lib,'' she said. ``I never thought Mrs. Pollifax would be a series. Then they wanted another one.'' It isn't surprising, since the day ``The Unexpected Mrs. Pollifax'' was published Gilman received a phone call that Rosalind Russell wanted to star in a movie of it. She departed from the book and wore designer clothes in the 1970 ``Mrs. Pollifax _ Spy.'' It wasn't a hit. Gilman had previously written a dozen young adult books. ``My income from those had risen to $5,000. Here I was with three of us to support.'' She calls the movie sale ``kind of a neat rescue.'' The author, whose sons and infant grandchild live in New York, rents a condo in Portland, Maine.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, Aug 31 to Sept 2 and Thereafter

DOC.TEXT: Stock prices rose today in what analysts described as a technical rebound from the market's free-fall slide of the past several weeks. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 173.02 points over the past three sessions, recovered 30.94 to 2,514.36 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 8 to 7 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 821 up, 720 down and 444 unchanged. Analysts said buyers were encouraged by hopes that the markets had gone too far in their appraisal of the potential calamities resulting from the showdown in the Middle East. But by near-unanimous agreement the mood in the marketplace remained cautious and touchy. It will take months, economists observe, to gauge the effects on business aactivity of the upsurge in oil prices and interest rates that followed Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Even without that disruptive influence, the domestic economy was widely believed to have been verging on a recession as it began the second half of 1990. Among actively traded blue chips, General Electric rose 1[ to 59|; International Business Machines 1] to 98\; Boeing 2} to 45\, and American Telephone & Telegraph } to 31\. Federal National Mortgage gained 1} to 28]. The stock traded as low as 24~ Thursday before the company announced that it had earmarked as much as $500 million for buybacks of its common shares and warrants. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 1.07 to 169.95. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 1.14 at 314.71. Volume on the Big Board came to 169.08 million shares with an hour to go.

DOC.HEAD: Investors, Faced With Crisis, Look To Bottom Line
DOC.TEXT: Whatever the outcome of the showdown in the Persian Gulf, Wall Streeters believe the stock market now is reconciling itself to the prospect of a long dry spell for corporate profits. As the summer began, hopes had been spreading among U.S. investors that earnings would soon start pulling out of a slump that set in at mid-1989. Even in a relatively weak economic environment, the reasoning went, bottom lines at many businesses stood to benefit from moves by the Federal Reserve toward a more stimulative credit policy. Such visions faded fast, however, with the Aug. 2 strike on Kuwait by Iraq under President Saddaam Hussein, and the resulting upsurge in oil prices and interest rates. ``The economy looks bad,'' said Suresh Bhirud, chief portfolio strategist at the investment firm of Oppenheimer & Co. ``What Saddam has done,'' summarized Barton Biggs at Morgan Stanley & Co., ``is boost oil prices, diminish economic growth, raise inflation and increase budget deficits (particularly in the U.S.) at a time when economic engines were beginning to sputter anyway.'' At Wright Investors' Service, a Bridgeport, Conn., investment management firm, analysts have pushed back their projections of any pickup in profits to the second half of 1991. They add, ``this reduced estimate may still prove to be too optimistic if the U.S. economy does indeed enter a recession. ``Over the next few quarters, stock prices will get little support from the overall corporate profit performance.'' Some favorable resolution of the Middle East crisis, it is widely presumed, would logically cause oil prices to drop back significantly from the recent peaks they have reached of $30-plus per barrel. But even then energy costs are expected to settle at a point higher than they would have been otherwise, increasing many companies' operating costs and hurting businesses that depend on car travel and on consumers' disposable income. The increase in interest rates looms as another negative in the cost of doing business. Not so incidentally, it enhances the comparative allure of interest-bearing investments that compete with stocks for investors' favor. As the stock market struggled to cope with such unsettling thoughts, it took a steep drop in the past week to its lowest levels in more than a year. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials closed Friday at 2,532.92, down 111.88 from the week before. The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 10.04 to 171.05; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market dropped 26.16 to 367.33, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was down 17.32 at 316.29. Volume on the Big Board averaged 189.86 million shares a day, against 147.95 million the week before. Late in the week, a flurry of stories crossed financial news wires carrying word of companies budgeting money to buy back shares of their stocks. That was reminiscent of the aftermath of the 1987 market crash, when buyback plans sprang up by the hundreds. In one of the most notable early instances this time, Federal National Mortgage Association announced that it had earmarked as much as $500 million for purchases of its common shares and warrants. Buybacks, by themselves, are far from any assurance that the worst of a market decline is over. But they provided one sign that stock prices had at last fallen far enough from their July peaks to attract a few venturesome buyers operating from a long-term point of view.

DOC.HEAD: Corn Prices Remain Low Despite Tight Stocks
DOC.TEXT: While the Middle East crisis holds profound implications for the economy, grain and soybean prices seem to have been little moved by the Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. It's not that what's going on in the Persian Gulf and other financial markets is unimportant to farm commodities. Rather, the crisis is sending a mixed message. ``They're getting inflation and recession signals at the same time,'' said Walter Spilka, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. The higher oil and precious metals prices are inflationary and should be pulling grain prices higher. ``But if we do have a recession, people will be going out to dinner less and switching more to chicken,'' Spilka said. ``The things that use up corn the most are steaks and hamburgers.'' The worldwide supply of corn and other grains contains other puzzling elements. In the United States, corn supplies are tight. ``In lots of areas, there just isn't any,'' said analyst William Biedermann, research director of Allendale Inc., a futures brokerage in Crystal Lake, Ill. ``In other areas there is some corn, but farmers just aren't selling. ``For the last three years, we've been consuming more than we're producing,'' he said. The result, Biedermann said, is that for the first time in the nation's history, corn stocks have dropped four years in a row. The supply of corn on hand at the end of this marketing year is expected to be 1.33 billion bushels. By September 1991, corn supplies are expected to be down to 1.2 billion. Yet, the price of corn, $2.57} on the Chicago Board of Trade Friday, is low. ``I'd say it costs more than $2.40 to grow it now,'' Spilka said. The tight corn supplies happen to coincide with a little more wheat in the nation's storage bins than a year ago and with better than average crops being reported in much of the Northern Hemisphere this season. With the price of wheat not much above that of corn, livestock growers will be feeding a lot more wheat than normal, which depresses the price of corn. Overseas sales aren't likely to help much either. ``We have to export this stuff,'' Spilka said, ``but there are better crops this year in the Soviet Union and a big wheat crop in China.'' The fact that grain prices remain depressed seems to be an indication that the trade believes there is going to be plenty for what demand develops. ``The ending stocks we're seeing now is not the final number,'' Spilka said. ``The market probably is saying that the stocks are not going to be this tight.'' ``If the country was booming, the stock market going up, gas prices OK, then there would be an explosive potential on the up side,'' he said. But under present conditions, he said, there's no anticipation of renewed demand.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Keeping Dearborn Assembly Plant Shut for Two More Weeks
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. said Friday an engine parts shortage will force it to extend a two-week shutdown of its Dearborn assembly plant for another two weeks. Originally, the factory that makes Mustang automobiles was closed for a week because of a shortage of dealer orders. The shutdown this week was blamed on the parts shortage. On Friday, Ford said the parts shortage for the 2.3-liter standard engine continues and would force the plant to remain closed until Sept. 10. The plant employs about 2,100 hourly workers, most of whom will be on temporary layoff. Others will be used from time to time to maintain machinery in the factory.

DOC.HEAD: United Airlines to Impose Fuel Surcharge on Freight Shipments
DOC.TEXT: United Airlines will increase its air freight rates 5.3 percent on all domestic flights effective Oct. 1 to cover rising jet fuel costs, the airline announced Friday. United was also considering a similar fuel surcharge for international freight shipments, according to a prepared statement released by the suburban Chicago-based airline. ``This modest charge is necessary to offset escalating fuel costs. (Those) costs are being closely monitored, and should prices decline, the fuel surcharge will be removed,'' said Carl Norris, United's director of cargo. The company will impose a 5.3 percent fuel surcharge on passenger flights beginning at the end of August, said company spokesman Rob Doughty.

DOC.HEAD: Financial Adviser Admits Losing $100 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS three grafs with Weyerhaeuser comment after 5th graf pvs, He said; picks up 6th graf pvs, Donahue sent. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A financial adviser afraid to face his clients admitted in a videotape message that he lost about $100 million of investors' money by making risky trades in stock options. More than 1,000 investors may be affected, according to lawyers. Included are several large retirement funds. ``Words aren't adequate to express my regret and sorrow,'' said Jim Donahue, head of the Hedged Securities Associates limited partnership, based in the Denver suburb of Englewood. ``I feel terrible remorse for the things I've done to you.'' H. Alan Dill, attorney for the partnership, said the organization has about $5.25 million in assets remaining and will seek bankruptcy protection to sort out investor claims. He said the biggest loser was the retirement fund of Weyerhaeuser Co., of Tacoma, Wash., which lost about $30 million. In a statement, Weyerhaeuser said, ``Only a small percentage of our total pension funds was invested there, and our pension funding continues to be very sound.'' The company said aggregate assets of its pension funds exceeded $850 million at the end of 1989. ``The facts in this situation are still unclear and since a legal evaluation is under way, we cannot comment further,'' the wood products company said. Donahue sent a videotape to an investor meeting Thursday instead of appearing personally because he feared for his safety, according to aides. While the 18-minute message was played to an overflow crowd, security guards walked through the audience. Donahue, 62, was known as an aggressive trader in stock options, contracts to buy or sell a stock for a specified price in the future. During the past 11 years, he claimed annual returns of 20 percent or better by hedging his bets in the options market. Donahue ran into trouble when he bet on an upturn in the shares of United Airlines' parent company, UAL Corp. The stock turned down after an employee group failed to line up financing to buy the company, and on Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``The loss is extensive, and involves most of the total assets of the fund,'' he said. ``My words cannot possibly alleviate the emotional or financial impact on each person involved.''

DOC.HEAD: Sun Microsystems Withdraws Plan to Offer Common Stock
DOC.TEXT: Deteriorating market conditions resulting from the Middle East crisis prompted Sun Microsystems Inc. to withdraw its planned offering of common shares on Friday. The worldwide supplier of general purpose computing systems had announced Aug. 13 that it would sell 5.9 million shares of common stock and 1.1 million shares offered by various stockholders. ``Financial market conditions clearly have deteriorated since we announced this offering,'' said Scott McNealy, president and chief executive officer of Sun Microsystems. ``We do not believe it is in the best interest of our stockholders to sell additional shares under current market conditions,'' McNealy said. Sun shares closed at $27.62{ Friday on the New York Stock Exchange, up $1.25. The stock had been trading as high as $36.62{ on July 13. Sun Microsystems earlier this month reported $111.2 million in profits during the 1990 fiscal year, an 83 percent jump over the previous year. Revenues for fiscal 1990, which ended June 30, were $2.47 billion, a 40 percent increase over $1.77 billion reported a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Yen Trader Pleads Guilty
DOC.TEXT: A former Chicago Mercantile Exchange trader pleaded guilty Friday to charges of fraud and violating commodities exchange regulations, a government prosecutor said. Aric March, one of 21 yen traders indicted in an FBI investigation into corruption charges at the Merc, pleaded guilty to one charge of mail fraud and one charge of violating the Commodities Exchange Act, Assistant U.S. Attorney Dan Gillogly said. March has also agreed to cooperate with federal prosecution efforts, Gillogly said. Fifteen other yen traders are scheduled to go on trial beginning Sept. 5. Earlier this year, another yen trader, Gary Wright, was indicted and charged with trying to persuade March not to cooperate with the government.

DOC.HEAD: To Cut 2,100 More Positions
DOC.TEXT: USAir Inc. said Friday it will eliminate 2,100 more positions during the next four months, bringing to 3,600 the total number of layoffs announced this week. The layoffs were ordered to cut operating costs before 1991, when the rate of business growth is expected to decline, USAir spokesman Mike Clark said. ``We expect softening passenger demand, poor economic conditions generally, escalating fuel costs,'' Clark said. USAir currently has about 54,000 employees. Workers to be laid off include 500 managers, 211 pilots, 650 flight attendants and 2,100 reservation clerks and other fleet service employees. The carrier previously forecast 6 percent growth for next year, but recently completed reviews have reduced that number to 2 percent. ``So what we have is people who were hired pretty much in anticipation of a continuing growth rate that has been scaled back, and we just simply do not need that many people,'' Clark said. Company officials do not know whether any more layoffs will be ordered before the end of the year, he said.
